TALK.START.PARA: —At the end of the consideration of this matter last night, Senator Evans made an important statement about addressing some of the concerns that I and Senator Bishop had raised regarding the appropriate forms of accountability for performance based cash bonuses. I welcomed the statement that Senator Evans made; it was an important statement. In order to conclude this particular section of the report from my point of view, I would like to raise a couple of matters. Firstly, I ask: what steps will Senator Evans now take to put into effect his responses to the concerns I raised last night so that this matter can be speedily resolved and the next time the issue of performance based cash bonuses comes up we will be better able to address the accountability issue?

PARA.TAB: The second issue is also important. Last night, in relation to the SES performance based cash bonuses, Senator Evans said, `There is some way to go before these issues are resolved'. As far as the SES is concerned, the key issues were effectively addressed in the original agreement signed by the Government and the ACTU in December 1992. On page 53 of the document I am holding, which Senator Evans's department was kind enough to give to me, the SES is specifically mentioned together with the cash bonuses to which officers may become entitled. Can Senator Evans comment on the matters that remain to be resolved because I understood that the key matters, the general principles, were resolved last December?

The third question is: can Senator Evans confirm the figures set out in the document; that is, the maximum cash bonuses which could be received by SES officers at the top level are in the order of $15,000? If Senator Evans could answer those three questions, I will conclude my comments on this area.

TALKER.NAME: Senator GARETH EVANS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Foreign Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —As to how I propose to advance further consideration of the issues of principle that were raised yesterday and indeed previously, it is my intention to write to the Prime Minister (Mr Keating), who is responsible for the Public Service Commission, identifying the issues and seeking a review of them. A preliminary draft of that letter has already been done. I will get that off in the next day or so and we will have a look at that whole issue before the next round of these things comes into effect. I repeat my acknowledgment of yesterday: there are legitimate issues of principle; there are grounds for debate about this; and I think it is appropriate that further consideration of the kind I indicated be given to it—and it will be.

PARA.TAB: On the question of SES performance pay, the answer is essentially as I gave it yesterday: although the decision in principle has been made to move forward with the extension of this to the SES—and that is reflected in some of the material that the honourable senator has—still it remains the case that the specific guidelines for SES level performance pay have yet to be finally resolved by the Public Service Commission. Those guidelines are expected to come down in July. The pool of available money in effect to be distributed for this purpose has yet to be finally determined, and so too have some other matters of internal process involved in these decisions. In particular what has proved a difficult matter already is getting comparability of assessment as between officers based in Canberra and those working in missions abroad. It is that kind of issue that is specifically being addressed at the moment. That is another reason why it was accurate for me to say yesterday that the detail of this has not yet been finally bedded down.

TALK.START.PARA: —There was a third issue that I asked Senator Evans to address his mind to. Could he confirm that the maximum cash bonus that will be payable under the SES performance based cash bonus scheme per person is of the order of $15,000?

TALKER.NAME: Senator GARETH EVANS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Foreign Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I cannot imagine that it would exceed that, but I am not able to confirm any particular figure because a particular figure has not been determined. It is a matter of working out what the pool will be and how that is capable of being distributed individually and then what the precise guidelines are to be to determine that. I am unable to give confirmation of that figure.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bishop Sen B.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was pleased, as was Senator Kemp, that Senator Evans acknowledged that this secret payment of money to individuals is not acceptable in terms of public accountability. Last evening he made the point that maybe it was okay because it was comparable with practice in the private sector. It is very important to have on the record that there is a huge distinction between practices in the private sector and practices in the public sector. Basically, an investor, a shareholder or whatever in the private sector takes his or her own hard-earned after-tax money and makes a decision about what to do with it. If investors do not like the body they have invested in, or how somebody else is dealing with their our money, they may take it out.

PARA.TAB: In the public sector the Taxation Office compulsorily takes the money from the taxpayer via enabling legislation and, of course, the interesting question of rulings. It is then spent in accordance with government policy and administered by the bureaucracy. The individual taxpayer has no right to say, `I don't like your policy; I am going to take my money out'. The taxpayer has no say over it at all. So the waiver system of accountability works. Expenditure by the executive and the bureaucracy is to this Parliament and, through this Parliament, to the tax paying public and the general voting body. That is the way our system works.

Therefore, to have secret payments is simply not a proposition, and I was pleased to hear Senator Evans say that he was going to make a submission to the Cabinet to review this scheme. He says that the guidelines will be laid down by the Public Service Commission. Of course there are already some guidelines in existence. The schedule of guidelines for performance based pay states:

SPEECH.PARA: The performance pay arrangements have been designed to be broadly based with a substantial proportion of staff having access to the performance payments. The amount determined for the lowest eligible rating should be sufficient to provide and maintain the desired motivational and incentive effects, and to provide a tangible reward consistent with the scheme designed.

When we put those guidelines with the minute signed by Mr Richard Woolcott to Mr Costello—who I understand is to be the new head of the department—which says that this is really a bit of a scam to get salary increases, we are even more concerned to have these arrangements fully disclosed so that there is proper accountability.

PARA.TAB: Senator Evans also said, `It's all decided by the Public Service Commission'. Whether or not payments to public servants are to be made and disclosed in the proper way, or whether it is to be a secret pool of money paid secretly to individuals and we never know about it and we never know why they got the money, is a question of policy. That is a matter for government. The Public Service Commission is part of the bureaucracy and it administers the policy, but the decision as to whether or not we are to have secret payments within our system is a matter of government policy. Government must be responsible for that decision and people must know that it is responsible for that decision.

Again, I was grateful to hear Senator Evans say that he has already drafted a letter and that it will be going to the Cabinet. Perhaps then we will see a proper system of accountability, not only in his department but right across the Public Service, where the present arrangements are equally inappropriate.

TALKER.NAME: Senator GARETH EVANS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Foreign Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I will clarify a couple of matters for the record. Firstly, the letter I will be writing will be to the Prime Minister (Mr Keating). Whether the Prime Minister chooses to put that to the Cabinet as a whole is a matter for him. I am not able to refer matters directly to the Cabinet. I just want to explain that matter of process lest there be any misunderstanding, but I do acknowledge the point that what is involved here is an issue of policy and not mere administration and, as such, it is for the Government. I have no doubt that it is in that spirit that the Prime Minister will address the issue, taking such advice as he thinks is appropriate.

PARA.TAB: Secondly, Senator Bishop began by putting some words in my mouth. I did not acknowledge yesterday that this was unacceptable in terms of Public Service accountability. All I acknowledged, and I do so again, is that an issue of accountability principles is involved here which needs to be weighed and balanced against the competing issue of personal privacy which has been referred to as justifying the particular way in which this matter is dealt with at the moment. It is that particular balance of competing interests that needs to be addressed. I certainly do not want to be taken as having hung my hat on either one of those two horns of that particular dilemma.

Thirdly, Senator Bishop referred to guidelines being already in existence. Yes, of course they are, but that is only for sub-SES personnel. A question does arise as to whether there needs to be any variation in those Public Service Commission guidelines so far as SES personnel are concerned. That is a matter being addressed at the moment and it will be resolved by July.

TALK.START.PARA: —All the non-portfolio specific issues were canvassed yesterday. We have now worked down to subprogram 1.1; Senator Crane raised one matter yesterday.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bishop Sen B.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —Very quickly, I want to deal with my reservation in the report dealing with the Gillespie children matter. I want to deal with a particular piece of information that has come to me subsequent to that—that is, information from Ms Barbara Karadin. She says:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . I am a Volunteer Marine Radio Operator and Justice of the peace for New South Wales. I operate what is known as `Bar Point Base, Safe Boating Rescue and Radio Communications Club, Incorporated' from our home. My base radio station is opened on a twenty four hour basis and I am generally available 13-14 hours per day, per week on average.
She goes on to explain what her call signal is. She then says:
I recall the morning of 18 July 1992, when at about 0813 hours my husband told me something and I immediately went to the radio which is situated in our loungeroom.
She then describes the band she was operating and how she is able to pick up long distance messages as far afield as Vanuatu. She goes on:
I have been involved in this activity on an almost full time basis since mid 1984 . . .

She says that after being called on 18 July she went to the radio and noted the receiving channel was set at a particular frequency, which was the emergency distress band used in Australia. She continues:

I heard a transmission from a male with a foreign accent, although I had no difficulty with that accent. This male spoke in English and I heard him say words to the effect that he needed some specialised medicine brought out for a heart condition. I queried his position and was informed he was eight degrees, 54 minutes south, 139 degrees, 2 minutes East.
I said: `where is that?'. He said; `Thirty kilometres south of IRIAN JAYA. I said `Where is that?'
He said `IRIAN JAYA, BOROKA Boat Harbour, south coast of IRIAN JAYA, port of BOROKA, I want the Indonesians to bring the medicine out from MERAUKE'.

At about this stage I contacted the Australian Maritime Safety Authority by telephone . . . and spoke to the male who answered . . . He told me something (that he had been getting reports of this distress call for the past four days and that the AMSA had advised Indonesian authorities of the calls).
Bear in mind that this is all taking place on 18 July. Ms Karadin continues:

That male requested my assistance to continue the transmissions with the male seeking assistance. My telephone is alongside my radio which I continued to monitor and in fact I placed the telephone receiver alongside the radio speaker for a period so that the AMSA male could hear the call.

The AMSA male requested me to tell the distressed caller that they had despatched a patrol boat out to the location and that the patrol boat would arrive at about 1230 hours Indonesian time, that is, local time.

I did so (whilst the AMSA was still on open telephone line), I said: `To the vessel near MERAUKE, do you hear `HAWKESBURY RIVER''. I cannot recall if he acknowledged, but I then said: `Australian patrol boat, 1230 ETA, they are going to rescue the man, they are going to rescue the man'. He then said: `They take us to MERAUKE Embassy'. He then acknowledged that `they' understood and he said words to the effect of: `Will the boat take us to MERAUKE?'.

Acting on AMSA instructions I ignored that question and merely repeated: `Patrol boat arriving 1230', or words to that effect. That was the last radio exchange I had with the man in distress, until about 0826 hours when I heard the same caller transmit words to the effect of: `Everything okay now, no engine trouble, cancel help, cancel help'. At that time I had an open telephone line to the man from the AMSA in CANBERRA and was holding the hand set to the radio speaker. The AMSA man indicated to me his displeasure to that response and indicated that an aircraft had overflown the craft that morning and had only seen one person aboard.

After the last transmission from the distressed caller, acting on AMSA instructions, I transmitted to him: `Okay, Bar Point out', and I heard no further transmissions from him. I had identified myself and provided my telephone number to the AMSA man (whose name I never noted at the time) but did not hear from them again.

I have a practice of taping all emergency calls on a portable tape recorder which is by the radio. The recorder is a Sharp cassette recorder, and in this instance I commenced taping as soon as I responded to the radio call. That taping continued throughout the exchanges until the tape cassette expired.
I have marked that tape `1/6/92 (Indonesia) 2' and signed it with my normal signature. I have handed that tape to . . . for his retention if required. I PRODUCE that TAPE CASSETTE.

During the transmissions, I made rough notes on two pieces of notepaper which I have also handed to . . . I have written my signature on each page along with the date and (3) (3-A). A Logsheet that I used was also handed to . . . and I marked it (3-B). I PRODUCE THOSE DOCUMENTS.

The following day, 19 July 1992 at about 0820 hours, I heard a transmission by radio on the same frequency and I recognised the male caller as being the same person who called on 18 July 1992. He said: `May Day, May Day, there are five aboard'. I then said (at the same time I telephoned AMSA at CANBERRA and told them something at the same time putting the ear piece of the telephone to the radio speaker): `This is Bar Point Base, what's the trouble now?'.
He said: `I am aground on the other side of MERAUKE, no food, no water, tell INDONESIA'. Before I could acknowledge, the `skip' (that type of abnormal radio transmissions) faded and I heard no more.

At that stage, CANBERRA was still on the line and the male there instructed me that he would `inform INDONESIA'. That was the last I heard of the matter. During that exchange, I made rough notes on a piece of notepaper, which I have handed to . . . and signed and dated and marked 19/7/92 (4). I PRODUCE THAT NOTE.

In other words, all these things occurred while those people were still in Indonesian waters before they had left the jurisdiction of Indonesia. There was ample evidence on the record that they were there and action should have been taken. The Maritime Safety Authority was well and truly in the know. This statement was made to the police.

PARA.TAB: Ms Karadin also informs me that she sent a copy of this to DFAT, the Minister's department, and has never had an acknowledgment. She says in her statement:

SPEECH.PARA: On 30 July 1992, I heard a news broadcast, as a result of that I contacted official of the Australian Maritime Safety Authority CANBERRA at about 1718 hours and later the Australian Federal Police, CANBERRA . . . told him something about 2130 hours . . . between the distress caller, myself and the other radio station, which I believe to be at MOOLOOLABA, QUEENSLAND.

PARA.TAB: I cannot assist further, except to explain that the cassette tape was dated . . .

SPEECH.PARA: That was when she had dated that material. Again the matter that concerns me is that there was so much information around on which action could have been taken and was not taken.

PARA.TAB: I think I made quite clear at the time of the estimates hearings that there is a responsibility on the Minister for Foreign Affairs to make sure that his first interest is for Australian citizens. As I said at the time, this is simply more information that has come to hand which surely required from the Minister a much better response than merely raising the matter over the dinner break in a particular conference that he was attending in Manila.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALKER.NAME: Senator GARETH EVANS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Foreign Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Bishop has raised absolutely nothing new. It is perfectly well acknowledged that, around the time that the Gillespies were in fact in the process of transiting Indonesia, there was a whole course of events involving distress calls from a boat, action taken by the maritime safety organisation to follow up and respond to those calls in various ways, including by contacting Indonesian authorities. This further information about this particular radio operator's contribution to that exercise adds a little more information about what was going on during that particular period. But all of this, of course, was without anyone's knowledge that that particular boat did have aboard the Gillespie children or the Prince. It is only with the benefit of hindsight that that connection has been made. Obviously that was who it was on the boat, but nobody at the time knew that.

PARA.TAB: To try to import backwards into this particular circumstance which, on the face of it, must have seemed to the authorities like a routine maritime issue is to invest the whole thing with a degree of significance in the context of the Gillespies which it did not have then to anybody and which it obviously does not have now. I can understand Senator Bishop's scratching around, finding any possible way she can to introduce, hopefully, something new from her point of view into this tale. But it adds absolutely nothing new to our understanding of the general course of events, nor certainly does it add anything to the allegations that have been made about some maladministration so far as the Government was concerned.

The whole question as to whether or not there should have been better coordination between the Australian Federal Police, the coast guard and so on is one that has been addressed in the Glenn report. It is a matter which, if Senator Bishop wants to pursue it, she should do so with the other relevant Ministers. The maritime safety agency is of course a DOTAC responsibility; the Federal Police is the responsibility of the Attorney-General and the Minister for Justice; and so on. But this has been explained often enough in the past and I do not think Senator Bishop is contributing anything helpful at all to this matter by coming at it again in this way today.

As to the general substance of her reservation on which she concluded again her remarks today about the manner of my raising this with foreign governments being inadequate, I make absolutely no apology whatsoever for the way in which I raised it, the degree of specificity with which I raised it or the sense of urgency with which I raised it. All of that was entirely appropriate to the particular circumstances. The insinuation that she continues to make that these were somehow casual discussions over dinner or something, represents—if I can put it at its most charitable—simply an ignorance or a naivety about the way in which multilateral conferences work. This was the ASEAN-PMC meeting. It is a gathering of 13 nations—12 countries and the EC. It is a very high level meeting involving Ministers and literally hundreds of officials with a very jam-packed agenda.

The way in which these conferences work is that we are in a chamber, around a conference table, from early morning until late in the evening. There are extended breaks for meals of a couple of hours and so on, and it is during those breaks that bilateral discussions, both formal and informal, are held. That is the time when people get together with their counterparts to raise particular issues that may be of urgency or importance. It is absolutely familiar routine, well understood, and a perfectly appropriate way of doing it. My particular exchanges with Mr Alatas, my Indonesian colleague, and Mr Abdullah Badawi, my Malaysian counterpart, were conducted during the dinner adjournment—not in fact over the dinner table, as I now better recall, thinking about it, but by taking the Minister aside and sitting down at a coffee table somewhere and talking it through for five minutes or so with notes being taken by officials.

That particular way of doing things is just the way we do things. I know it is hard for Senator Bishop to grasp, but that is the way it works. Moreover, unlike the way in which she puts it in her reservation, it was not a matter of just raising it fleetingly and only once; I raised the issue on at least four occasions with Ministers: with Foreign Minister Alatas during the dinner adjournment on 24 July; during a formal programmed bilateral meeting, which happened to be over dinner, with Foreign Minister Abdullah that same evening, and again with both Ministers on 26 July.

Simultaneously, as I made clear in the statement that I put down in the Senate on 10 May, our embassy in Jakarta and our High Commission in Kuala Lumpur are also vigorously pursuing at senior level the concerns that I had raised at ministerial level. There has been an enormous amount of departmental energy devoted to this both at that time and subsequently. I recorded the number of contacts specifically made with the Malaysians in the schedule that I put down in the Senate on 10 May. There were in fact 30 such contacts going to the question of the whereabouts of the children before 26 July and then, when their whereabouts were clear by their appearance in Malaysia on that day, subsequently the rest of those 30 contacts were made on the subject of consular access. There is no government that could have worked more assiduously or more appropriately to raise the matters in issue.

Might I say finally on this subject that I am a little underwhelmed by the way in which this issue is addressed in the Estimates Committee A report. For a start, I think it is a little unusual in committee reports for the preoccupations of one particular senator, or in this instance the criticisms of one senator, to be recorded as such when they are manifestly not the views of the committee as a whole. But be that as it may, I think it is also a little inappropriate for this to be recorded in a way which really quite inaccurately describes the nature of the exchange and, in particular, my response to it. I refer to paragraph 22 in particular, which states:

SPEECH.PARA: The Minister defended his actions, arguing that the demands of diplomacy limited the extent to which he could press the issue with his Malaysian and Indonesians counterparts:

That clearly implies that there was some extreme delicacy or some sort of caution about the nature of the way in which I pursued this with my colleagues, that I was anxious not to offend. That completely misrepresents the nature of my replies in the estimates committee. It was a straightforward consular matter which I put to my counterparts in a way that made clear the nature of my concern, the Australian Government's concern, with the status situation of particular Australian citizens. There were no ifs, buts or maybes. In my conversation with Minister Badawi I described with some precision what it was that the Australian Government could do in this matter, including by way of seeking extradition if the appropriate criteria were satisfied. All of that was laid out. There was no `diplomacy' in the sense of the caricature use of that expression which is rather the implication that is conveyed here in paragraph 22.

PARA.TAB: I was simply making the point that one does not harangue one's colleagues in this situation in the way that Senator Bishop, in her particular naivety about the way these things are done, seems to think is the appropriate manner of behaviour. Certainly I would not have done that. It is a matter of a polite exchange, but it is also a matter of saying what is necessary to convey the messages that have to be conveyed in the sense of urgency and importance we felt about them. I did all that; I make absolutely no apology.

The other problem with this capsule summary of this exchange in the committee A report is that—as I made extended reference to in the estimates committee—it makes no reference to the statement that I made in the Senate chamber, with its very detailed tabulation of the contacts that were made on this matter, in particular with the Malaysian Government. With the utmost respect to the committee members, for them to record the exchange in this way is incomplete—as this is—and with the clear implication that there was some substance in Senator Bishop's criticisms really is regrettable and does represent some conspicuous inadequacies in the terms of this committee report. It is important that I should have this opportunity to correct the record in that respect.

TALK.START.PARA: —The record does not require correcting; it is an accurate report. I find the Minister's use of the word `charity' rather curious. Quite clearly, when the Minister was speaking about the nice chat he had over the dinner break with his two colleagues attending the same conference, anyone listening got the clear impression that it was all far too important just to worry about two Aussie kids.

PARA.TAB: The bottom line is that there was an enormous mix-up, lack of communication and lack of coordination in the whole sorry episode: police not talking to Coastwatch; people not being made aware of orders; information coming in from people like Ms Karadin and not being used, and her communication to the Minister's department never being acknowledged; and the Minister saying, `Why don't you go talk to DOTAC and AG's'. We have become quite accustomed to Ministers in this Government not wishing to take ministerial responsibility. This is just another example.

The conclusion one cannot help coming to is that the Minister thought the business of getting these two kids back was just too difficult and he was not about to upset his nice relationships. The Minister carefully said that he raised it with these people over the dinner break on 24 July. It was not raised again until the 26th and yet he was constantly with those people in that conference and the 25th could well have been the crucial date.

The Minister's own department contacted the lawyers for the Gillespies and said, `Your children are in Indonesia'. But the lawyers were unable to take any action to prevent those children leaving that jurisdiction for the simple reason that the Minister's department would not give them any more information to physically ascertain where those children were in Indonesia.

The very valid point that I made in estimates is that there was an opportunity to get those children back before they left the Indonesian jurisdiction. As I said, there was never any suggestion that it was Indonesian Government policy to cooperate with the people in Merauke. The point was, however, that the Minister's department knew they were in Indonesia. The fact was that the Minister had an opportunity to do something quite strong about it and he failed to do it. Having a chat over the dinner break is not enough. No matter how important the conference is, the rights of Australian citizens come first.

I understand how those other ministers from Indonesia and from Malaysia stand up for their citizens because they are Ministers of those countries. All I ask is that the Minister does the same. It is not up to the Minister to make a decision in his head about what he perceives to be the justice or injustice of this case and whether or not it is too difficult to do something to get those children back. They are Australian citizens, they were taken unlawfully from this land and the Minister has a responsibility to do something about it.

The reason that I raised this report from Barbara Karadin today is that it is simply another piece of evidence—and I understand more will be coming forward—as to just what a mess it was. There was no coordination and no proper oversighting of the way in which various agencies acted. How are we to know it is still not going on? How do we know there are not other illegal acts going on which are not caught up because there is no proper coordination between government agencies?

Not only did Senator Evans miss an opportunity to bring home these two Australian kids, but there is also the question of other illegal activities, such as drug running, that may be going on in that part of the world. We have had no reassurance from Senator Evans or anybody else that proper systems have been put in play to ensure that there is coordination between government agencies.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Childs Sen B.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —I intervene briefly to make it very clear that I differ very strongly from what Senator Bishop has said. I believe that anybody who heard the long, bitter, angry attacks that Senator Bishop made on Senator Evans at the Senate estimates committee hearing—the attack probably lasted for over an hour, during which time Senator Bishop inevitably made reference to a conspiracy and all the other things that are synonymous with her questioning—would acknowledge that the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Senator Evans) and the department have acted very properly.

PARA.TAB: This morning the Minister again elaborated on the assistance that the Gillespie's received from the Australian Government: the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade directed 200 telephone calls and faxes to the lawyers and 30 attempts were made to get consular access. The Minister also pointed out the specific way in which those discussions took place, giving the lie to the suggestion that Senator Bishop keeps repeating; that is, a certain chat took place over dinner. She has referred to other matters, but the Minister's denial of them and his putting the facts straight do not seem to have any effect. At the estimates committee, Senator Bishop said to the Minister:

SPEECH.PARA: Well, Minister, the tugging of that forelock to foreign nations is becoming rather obvious.

That sums up the attitude of Senator Bishop. I then said: Senator Bishop, you may ask for explanations, but I do not think you should lace your questions with arguments, inferences and imputations all the time.

I then asked her to get back to the point. That is continually happening with Senator Bishop on this issue, as with other issues. Although Senator Evans is unhappy with the estimates committee report, I can assure honourable senators that the record of the estimates committee hearing is an accurate reflection of the way in which the Minister answered the questions raised by Senator Bishop. Senator Evans has complained that Senator Bishop was being critical. I would have thought that he would know that everything that Senator Bishop does is based on a critical style. I thought that was an axiomatic part of Senator Bishop's presentation.

TALK.START.PARA: —Are there any further matters in relation to subprogram 1? There being no further matters, we move to subprogram 1.3—relations with South Pacific, Africa and the Middle East.

—I wish to follow through on the points that I raised under this subprogram in Additional Estimates, particularly the live sheep trade. I am sure that the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Senator Evans) will be pleased that we are having a spell from wool for a couple of minutes.

PARA.TAB: I am absolutely staggered by the answers that have been given to us. I raised a very specific matter in the estimates committee, and I then put three questions on notice relating to the live sheep trade, particularly in the Middle East and Saudi Arabia. It amazes me that the department has made no attempt to answer those questions. The department sent a letter back to me suggesting that these questions would be more appropriately answered by the Department of Primary Industries and Energy. I accept that the Department of Primary Industries and Energy has a very important and significant role to play in that respect, but so does the Department of Trade.

Point 3 of the reply acknowledges that the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade, through its missions abroad, has sought to facilitate the resolution of the live sheep issue. Yet it has declined to answer the particular questions that I put on notice on that. I ask the Minister whether the Senate could have a report from the Department of Trade with regard to negotiations, or attempts to facilitate the problems that exist with live sheep in the Middle East, particularly with Saudi Arabia.

I want to know why the Department of Trade bypassed and refused to answer the questions I raised, which were perfectly legitimate, particularly in view of the fact that we have been in competition with New Zealand for a significant number of years in the same market. While we have not been able to get access for a significant number of years to that market—I know the reason given is that there is a disease problem, but that is not the whole story—New Zealand, for similar types of animals, receives two or three times more in value than our producers do, despite the fact that we have a significant freight advantage, particularly from Western Australia.

I request an answer from the Minister as to why the department was not prepared to pass on the information that it had on this particular matter, and whether it has forwarded these questions to the Department of Primary Industries and Energy for answers.

TALKER.NAME: Senator GARETH EVANS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Foreign Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am a little puzzled by Senator Crane's intervention. Senator Crane was written to yesterday by Mr Laurie of my department responding to his questions with information supplied to him by the Department of Primary Industries and Energy. I see Senator Crane indicating that he has not yet received that letter, and I pass a copy to him. It is in my file, it is dated yesterday, and it was obviously sent to him then. It probably should have been hand delivered, given the time frame and the fact that the Estimates were coming on last night and today.

PARA.TAB: As to the reason why the matter was referred to DPIE at all, I am advised that the particular advice that was provided to us by the secretary of Senate Estimates Committee A was that this is the kind of question that probably should be forwarded to the Department of Primary Industries and Energy for an appropriate response. There are two ways of doing these things. One is to respond on the basis of information supplied by the other department with the relevant input into it, the other is to refer it to that other department. Our initial response was to send it off to the other department on the basis of advice received from the secretary of this committee. But it seems that, in a belt and braces exercise, we have now written to Senator Crane giving him the answer that, hopefully, will meet the points he made. That is the explanation for why it was dealt with in that way. I have given him his answers. I hope they are adequate.

TALK.START.PARA: —Unfortunately, in the time I have left I obviously do not have time to study these answers. I would like to emphasise their importance and the necessity for coordination between the departments of trade and primary industries. I am not saying that that coordination does not exist, but I sometimes wonder whether it exists to its fullest extent. As I said last night in the debate on wool, arrangements have been put in place for us to meet with the Department of Trade with regard to wool. Rather than pursuing this matter now with a half knowledge of the answers, not having had time to examine them, maybe I could raise it when we have the meeting with the department to discuss wool or, if necessary, with different officers from the department who are involved in that area.

PARA.TAB: I hope it is possible to have that information prior to the meeting. I acknowledge that the Minister is nodding, so I accept that. I thank the Minister and his officers for that information. If there is further information with regard to the inquiries and the information that was made available in a general sense in terms of the situation that exists in the Middle East, perhaps we could have a look at that it prior to the meeting—which is, I think, on Thursday morning.

TALKER.NAME: Senator GARETH EVANS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Foreign Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I will take Senator Crane's contribution on board and if we can help him further in the ways that he is suggesting we will.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I raise a matter relating to an unanswered question. I refer to the schedule in the Estimates Committee A report to the Senate of May 1993. One of the questions I asked in that estimates committee hearing has not been responded to. I asked: in view of the law as laid down recently in Australia in the case of Rogers v. Whitaker regarding informed consent to medical procedure, what is being done where Australia is helping to fund population control programs to ensure that full and frank disclosure is made to ultimate recipients of the health risks associated with contraceptive medication?

PARA.TAB: That question was not asked of AIDAB; it was asked of the Department of Foreign Affairs when the committee was discussing the particular subprogram with which we are now dealing. The program is entitled `Bilateral relations', and the subprogram is entitled `Relations with the South Pacific, Africa and the Middle East'. That subprogram refers to our contribution to peaceful political and economic development, particularly in Papua New Guinea and the South Pacific, enhancing regional civility and Australia's security.

What I am specifically asking the Minister now, and this was asked of the department in the estimates committee, is whether he is fully aware of the implications of the judgment to which I refer. That judgment actually rewrote the principles of informed consent. If this has been done in Australian law, surely it is important that it be observed by the Department of Foreign Affairs and any of its agencies, or any government agencies, in respect of countries with whom we have bilateral relations.

I refer to that case of Rogers v. Whitaker and the High Court decision of Justices Mason, Brennan, Dawson, Toohey and McHugh. It is interesting that they adverted to the principle previously stated in respect of informed consent, and that was in the case Bolam v. Friern Hospital Management Committee in 1957, case No. 1 WLR 582. That principle stated:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . that the law imposes the duty of care, but the standard of care is a matter of medical judgment . . .
Their Honours in this recent case disapproved of that principle, stating:

. . . that a medical practitioner has a legal duty to warn a patient of a material risk inherent in proposed treatment—a risk being material if, in the circumstances of the particular case, a reasonable person in the patient's position, if warned of the risk, would be likely to attach significance to it or if the medical practitioner is or should reasonably be aware that the particular patient, if warned of risk, would be likely to attach significance to it.

We all know that some of the contraceptive devices and birth control methods—which the Australian taxpayer is funding and which the Government seems hell bent on pursuing in sparsely populated areas such as PNG—very regularly have adverse and traumatic effects. From the material provided to me regarding what needs to be told to the recipients of that attention, it appears that the principle of informed consent, which the High Court considers appropriate for Australians, is not upheld by the department or other government agencies when it comes to dealing with persons in less developed countries. That is why I am drawing the matter to the Minister's attention now, so that he may give the Senate a guarantee that the principle of informed consent, as stated by their Honours in Rogers v. Whitaker, will also apply in respect of our aid and our bilateral associations with persons in other countries.

TALKER.NAME: Senator GARETH EVANS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Foreign Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I apologise to Senator Harradine for the fact that he has not received an answer to his question. I was not aware of his question because it was tabled before the estimates committee hearing and, as I recall, it was not raised in the estimates committee itself, so it did not come to my personal attention.
—Are you sorry I wasn't there?

—I ask the honourable senator not to test me on that subject. Since the matter was not drawn to my personal attention at the committee in Senator Harradine's usual, very direct way, I am afraid I did not appreciate that it had not been responded to. It seems that because the question was raised under program 1.3, which is a DFAT program, rather than under the relevant AIDAB program—without going into all the boring detail—AIDAB thought DFAT was doing it and DFAT thought AIDAB was doing it. In the event, nobody did it. I will have an answer for Senator Harradine as soon as possible which addresses the particular question he raised about the applicability of the Rogers v. Whitaker principle in the context of medical procedures where we are funding population control programs.

PARA.TAB: The most I can quickly tell the honourable senator now is that AIDAB has policy principles for assistance in family planning and those principles have been reduced in the AIDAB programs operations guide used by officers and consultants. These principles advocate quality of care in family planning programs. Some of the elements of that quality of care, as specified by the principles, include: choice of method of contraception to suit individual needs based on the principle of informed consent; adequate information and counselling services; and the improved technical competence of family planning service providers. We recognise that many family planning programs in various parts of the world have serious deficiencies in those and other aspects of care. It is the aim of our family planning assistance programs to help improve the situation through technical assistance, training and other inputs.

What Senator Harradine wants to know with a little more precision is, as he put it in his question, what is actually done when Australia is helping to fund these programs to ensure that full and frank disclosure is made to the ultimate recipients of the health risks associated with the operation of the various contraceptive measures. It is a fair question. How much by way of a detailed answer I will be able to give the honourable senator I am not quite sure, but I will make sure that the question is properly addressed and that he gets his answer as soon as possible.

I would like to have a closer look at the issues of principle involved, at their applicability in other contexts, and at their practicability. Some pretty rigorous standards were set in the High Court case cited. Beyond that, I cannot sensibly comment further at this stage. I can only promise to take Senator Harradine's points on board and to assure him that the principle of informed consent is one that I certainly endorse. How it works in practice is a matter on which I will try to make further response.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to make it clear that one of the reasons I was not at the committee meeting was that there were other matters requiring my attention at that stage.
—I am not being critical, Senator.

—And I am not being critical of the department or of AIDAB in any shape or form. It seems to be a more open approach than that heretofore adopted by the department or AIDAB. I encourage that because it makes our job far easier, and makes us more informed and able to properly consider the matters before us. But this was deliberately asked of the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade. I suggest that it was the department's role to respond—not AIDAB's—because it goes to the heart of the principles that should underline our bilateral relations.
—Are there any further matters in relation to subprogram 1.3? Program 6: Corporate and Public Service; subprogram 3: Overseas Support Service.

—I do not intend to take long. I am still awaiting the advices I was promised in relation to the matter of Mr Peter Dewes. I would like to signify to the Minister that I would be grateful if those advices could be provided to me at some stage this week so that I might be able to fully inform Mrs Dewes of the situation. She is still very concerned about the matter. I appreciate that the Minister is also concerned. Could the Minister give an undertaking that those advices will be available for me at some stage later this week. The advices need not be given to me in the chamber; I am quite happy for it to be done in private, if that is convenient to the Minister and his staff.

TALKER.NAME: Senator GARETH EVANS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Foreign Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —Unhappily, as Senator O'Chee will know, Mr Dewes's remains were found on Mount Fuji on 22 May. The police believe that he may have fallen from a walking track and suffered a head injury. Weather conditions at the time were extreme. His death is thought to have occurred on 2 or 3 January. In terms of the issues raised about the role of the embassy in the search, and matters raised in the letter to me from Mrs Dewes, I have this morning sent off a very detailed reply to her, expressing my and the Government's condolences on the tragedy as it has now been demonstrated to be, and responding in as much detail as we can to the various issues that were raised about the role of the embassy and the coordination of the search and so on. It should be possible, I guess, to get all that same basic information to Senator O'Chee today. Indeed, I have also signed a letter to Senator O'Chee this morning—I have just remembered—not attaching a copy of my letter to Mrs Dewes because that is obviously private correspondence, but setting out a detailed chronology of events, which I hope will be a complete response to the issue that Senator O'Chee raised with me. I think there were also some other honourable senators who have raised this subject with me. I am not sure whether there has been correspondence. Senator Burns certainly has raised the matter. I will also be contacting him with the same information.

—Is the Minister in a position to advise whether an autopsy has been undertaken? I know that in circumstances such as these some of the autopsy results are a little inconclusive because of the temperature, but the results of the autopsy would be quite relevant to the role of the embassy, in particular in relation to the timeliness of actions there.

TALKER.NAME: Senator GARETH EVANS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Foreign Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I have no information on the outcome of any autopsy. The only information that we have is that positive identification was made. That will have to be the subject of a further communication to Senator O'Chee, which I will make available as soon as the information comes to hand.
—I thank the Minister for that and just note that I will await the advice—and I am sure it will be thorough.

TALKER.NAME: Senator GARETH EVANS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Foreign Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am further advised that the cause of death has been identified as a broken neck, which would clearly seem to leave little room for argument about the circumstances of the death. Whether there is to be a formal autopsy, however, or simply a recorded finding of this kind which satisfies everybody, I am not in a position to say. We will check that out and give Senator O'Chee a considered response as soon as we can.
—That concludes the consideration of the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade. The Committee will now consider the Department of Primary Industries and Energy.

—My reservation referred in particular to the Australian Tobacco Marketing Advisory Committee. Perhaps I could be relieved of my ignorance here and be informed. The committee is seeking an increase of $10,000. Quite simply, my question is: is this actually Commonwealth money, is it the forwarding of increased levy income, or is it Commonwealth money which is required to match an increase that was due to—from the explanation that was given—an upward revision of tobacco production estimates from 13 million kilograms to 13,410,000 kilograms? Is this requirement for extra money an immediate consequence?

TALKER.NAME: Senator GARETH EVANS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Foreign Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am advised that it is not Commonwealth taxpayers' money. It does come from the levy. I hope that clarifies that matter.

—Yes; that was as I suspected, but not as I knew. I would like, then, to follow the whole direction here in relation to the Tobacco Marketing Advisory Committee and the operation of the tobacco industry stabilisation plan. We are told, in the list of objectives of the tobacco industry stabilisation plan, that objective No. 6 is to encourage and sponsor the development of an industry strategic plan.

PARA.TAB: I would like to know how far this group has gone with that proposition. To encourage and sponsor the development of an industry strategic plan, we are given hints in documents such as the explanation of variation and the annual report, but we do not have a great deal of indication as to where the strategic plan is eventually going. What is the eventual aim of the industry strategic plan? Are we looking at an industry which has a vibrant and vital future or are we looking at an industry which is taking account of the fact that the industry, by definition, is in decline in Australia? Is the industry looking forward to expansion so that everyone becomes a tobacco consumer? What is the industry strategic plan heading towards?

TALKER.NAME: Senator GARETH EVANS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Foreign Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am told that the objective of this industry strategic plan in short is to make the industry world competitive within two years. I will have to take further advice on how it is going to get there and how well it is succeeding in those steps. But if the honourable senator asks where it is going, what its objectives are and the basic direction that all this is pursuing, that is it in a nutshell. Again, I think Senator Bell realistically might pursue these matters in a more direct way with the Minister responsible if he really does want to get some sensible answers. If Senator Bell's ignorance was evident on some aspects of this, I am afraid mine is of quite gothic proportions by comparison. It is not a terribly satisfactory way of getting detailed information.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bell Sen R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is accepted, Minister. It is helpful to have confirmation of things which have already been confirmed so far. In the annual report of the Australian Tobacco Marketing Advisory Committee, the Chairman, Mr Graham, states:

PARA.TAB: Domestic demand for leaf was down significantly in 1991. If the decline continues it will affect the industry profitability and some farms may become non-viable.

SPEECH.PARA: I would like to know whether any of those farms are being assisted in a search for alternative crops or alternative activities; if so, what assistance has been given to them by way of information. I am not asking for details about financial assistance and that sort of thing; I am asking about what regard is being paid to those farms which may become non-viable. It is important to keep in mind that if we are attempting to be world competitive so that we do not have to buy from overseas, if domestic demand continues to decline—it was significantly down in 1991—by definition the industry will continue to decline. I would like to know what alternative arrangements are being suggested to farmers?

TALKER.NAME: Senator GARETH EVANS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Foreign Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —Again, I am advised that quite a lot of work has been done in trying to help tobacco farmers who look as if they may not be able to sustain viability in the future to find alternative ways of doing so. That effort has been put in particularly in the northern tablelands area of Queensland. The effort in particular so far has been in a variety of horticultural areas—vegetable growing and so on. However, I am further advised that the difficulty has been that the signs are not all that terrific there in terms of being able to sustain viability because of considerations like distance from markets and things of this kind. But those issues are being pursued and that is obviously part of the overall strategy that is being worked up.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bell Sen R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —In the 1991 annual report of the Australian Tobacco Marketing Advisory Committee, under the heading `Functions and Powers' it is stated:

PARA.TAB: The Committee's power to formulate plans with respect to the export of tobacco leaf is not currently exercised because all leaf offered in Australia is sold on the domestic market.

SPEECH.PARA: With that in mind, I wonder what is the purpose of aiming for this world competitiveness. If part of this aim for world competitiveness has the result of making some farms unviable, what is the point? What is the point of becoming world competitive if we are selling all we make within Australia, we are not exporting, we do not look as if we are going to be exporting and, in that process, some of our farms have been driven to bankruptcy?

TALKER.NAME: Senator GARETH EVANS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Foreign Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —There are a couple of dimensions to the reply. Again, I am advised that some intensive effort is being devoted to trying to find where external export markets might be, particularly again so far as those Queensland growers are concerned. When we talk about world competitiveness, of course we are not just talking about a capacity to put onto world markets; we are also talking about a capacity to beat the imports. Of course, it is a crucial element in the survival of the Australian industry that it maintain that capacity to beat the imports. It is in that context also that that particular objective has been described.

—That is evident and sensible, I suppose. What is behind my questioning here, and what seems to me to not be sensible, is that nowhere do we see a recognition of the costs to the community of continuing in this game. Of course we cannot for one moment suggest that the use of tobacco cease tomorrow, forthwith. But it has to be recognised that there has been enlightenment as far as health risks and public risk in general are concerned—and even the use of tobacco in the workplace is becoming to an extent almost totally prohibited. In recognition of that, in recognition of the fact that the production of tobacco for use as snuff or chewing tobacco has declined to almost nil and in view of the strategic plan of the industry for the future of the industry, what recognition is being given to the fact—and I would suggest it is a fact—that eventually the world will become enlightened to the extent that tobacco will not be used?

TALKER.NAME: Senator GARETH EVANS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Foreign Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I happen to share most of Senator Bell's starting points in this respect in terms of dangers associated with smoking and so on. I do not think there is too much argument with him now among policy makers. But the point is that tobacco consumption is, I am advised, going down about seven per cent per annum at the moment as a result of the kind of campaigning that he and I both agree with. But so long as it does remain a legitimate item for consumption—and we are not in the business of banning absolutely—then a question arises as to how to supply that legitimate demand. Obviously it is in our interests as a national government to ensure that that supply is, so far as humanly possible, from viable Australian producers. So long as tobacco continues to be consumed in this country, we would much rather it was being supplied by Australian producers than outsiders. So it is in that context that these questions are being addressed by this department. The other issues Senator Bell raised really are, as I think he would acknowledge, properly and better addressed to the health Minister.

—That answer was welcome, but it did not actually answer one of the several questions I asked, which was: recognising that consumption is declining and recognising that other tobacco uses have disappeared—I gave two examples; there are probably more—eventually, perhaps 30 or 40 years down the track, I do not know, there will no longer be a use for tobacco. I am not canvassing that here. Associated with my question about alternatives being offered for tobacco growers, I have not been able to find in any of the strategic plans or any of the documentation that we have to use here any strategy being developed to take advantage of the recognition of those factors.

PARA.TAB: The Minister said, rightly, that if we are to have tobacco then it should be grown and supplied from within Australia. If that is the case, what will be the situation some years down the track when there is a considerably smaller market? What efforts are being made to incorporate that knowledge in the strategic plan?

TALKER.NAME: Senator GARETH EVANS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Foreign Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —Good democratic socialist though I may be, I think there are limits to the extent to which the state can play nanny to particular components of various industries that may, in fact, be declining industries. People just have to make their own judgments about where the industry will be in 10, 20, 30 or 40 years and whether they want to hang on to a role in what may well be a terminal area. I cannot comment further. It is a matter for the judgment of growers and people on that side of the industry as to how they want to play it. Hopefully, that will be an informed judgment. I guess it is part of the Government's responsibility to ensure that there is as much information flow as possible, and market projections and things of this kind, so that those decisions can be sensibly made.

PARA.TAB: Beyond that, I think the kind of issue that Senator Bell is raising is essentially philosophical rather than practical, and certainly would be perceived as such by the hardheads of DPIE. Under those circumstances I do not think I can contribute much more in my role as ventriloquist's doll which is what I am put into on this occasion.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to make a few comments in relation to this because senators from Queensland—Senator Bjelke-Petersen, Senator Boswell and I—have 75 to 80 per cent of Australia's tobacco industry in our State. I am very pleased to hear the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Senator Gareth Evans) say that if people are going to smoke he would like to see them smoking Australian tobacco rather than foreign tobacco. That is a sentiment with which we actually agree.

PARA.TAB: The only problem, as Senator Evans may be aware, is that there is some concern at the moment that the Government is about to abolish or relax the mixing requirements. This is what keeps the Australian industry going. It is not that we are not producing good tobacco leaf. The leaf that we produce in Queensland, particularly around Mareeba, is the equal of any tobacco leaf to be found anywhere in the world. It is the equal of the leaf that is grown in Virginia. The problem is that enormous subsidies are given to tobacco farmers in Virginia by the United States Government, so they net in the vicinity of $US5,000 an acre. That equates to about $A7,000 an acre as a net return. It is a bit difficult for us to be expected to compete with an unsubsidised industry against a heavily subsidised American industry. The other major supplier of tobacco—

TALK.START.PARA: —What about Rhodesia?
—In answer to Senator Boswell's interjection of, `What about Rhodesia?'—
—Zimbabwe.

—It is coming out of Zimbabwe. The problem with Zimbabwe, as Senator Evans will be well aware, is that in the past it has—and it is likely to continue to do so in the future—devalued its currency solely to ensure that it continues to bring the price of Zimbabwe tobacco in underneath the price of tobacco produced anywhere else in the world, because tobacco is its major cash crop. It is good economics as far as Zimbabwe is concerned to devalue its currency to ensure that it always undercuts everybody else in the market.

PARA.TAB: The only way in which we will protect the Australian industry, which is competitive and world class, is to ensure that we do not relax the mixing requirements. As soon as we relax the 57 per cent mixing requirement the consequence will be that other tobaccos will come into this country. International buyers will see to it that they source more tobacco from the United States where the prices are lower because of the subsidy, or from Zimbabwe where the price is lower because of the devaluation, and we will see a world-class Australian industry go out the back door.

While some honourable senators in this chamber may have difficulties with tobacco, it is a legal product and we have a world-class industry. I do not believe that we should turn our backs on that industry and relax the mixing requirements. That is why I take this opportunity to bring the matter to the Minister's attention, so that he understands at least our position. So far as Queensland is concerned, it is an important industry. In the town of Mareeba it is worth over $47 million a year, and no other industry can give the same returns as that industry, unless something new is on the horizon that I have not seen.

I should make one other point. The efforts that are being made, or supposedly being made, to help growers find additional crops are pretty slim. In fact, we have not seen much evidence of that assistance at all. The only evidence seems to be that growers themselves, looking down the track, are asking themselves what other crops they can grow. That assistance certainly has not been coming from the Government. We would very much welcome any assurance that could be given to us on maintenance of the mixing requirements.

The TEMPORARY CHAIRMAN (Senator Teague)—The Committee of the Whole is, of course, assisted by those who give information on matters before us; but we have before us the adoption of the report from Estimates Committee A. Smoking is a noxious habit. Another noxious habit is freewheeling in the consideration of the Committee of the Whole. If there are no comments on subprogram 1.4, petroleum, we will move on to program 2, industry and community services.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOSWELL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —Before you go on, Mr Temporary Chairman, Senator O'Chee was seeking an assurance from the Minister, Senator Evans, that the tobacco regulations—the 57 per cent mixing rule—would not be altered. Senator Evans should now either give Senator O'Chee that assurance or tell him otherwise.

TALKER.NAME: Senator GARETH EVANS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Foreign Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I apologise to Senator Boswell and to Senator O'Chee. I took Senator O'Chee's question to be rhetorical, as did the Temporary Chairman. Since it is not rhetorical, the answer, as Senator O'Chee is no doubt well aware, is that a task force has been set up to review the whole future of the industry. The question of that mixing requirement is one of the matters that are there being addressed.

PARA.TAB: I am obviously not in a position here and now on behalf of the Government to be more precise than to say the matter is under review. But I am sure the Government will take into account the fierce determination that has been articulated by Senator O'Chee to maintain the mixing requirement.
The TEMPORARY CHAIRMAN (Senator Teague)—We now go to program 2, industry and community services, subprogram 2.2, rural adjustment and services.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOSWELL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —During the debate last week on the wool Bills I made some observations that were to be answered by Senator Sherry. Unfortunately, time ran out. Another Bill had to be introduced before 10.30 p.m. and Senator Sherry's remarks were cut off. I asked Senator Sherry—and he was going to supply me with an answer—how many people are receiving benefits under the rural adjustment scheme at the moment and what other programs are available.

PARA.TAB: The latest edition of Country Life lists some information under the heading, `Help in the rural crisis. What RAS means to you'. I believe that this information would have come from Mr Crean's office; it details his pet benefits. It lists benefits which are available when a person is not eligible to receive other pensions and deals with hardship provisions and emergency relief payment. Obviously Mr Crean has issued the rural press with some information in which he has stated that people can apply for benefits under those three programs.

I sought information and I understand that those programs would not assist primary producers at the moment. Senator Evans is getting some advice from Mr Newton. I seek some information for the record on how these programs would assist. The programs are: the special benefit, the hardship provision and the emergency relief payment.

TALKER.NAME: Senator GARETH EVANS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Foreign Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I will just read what I have here and see how much of this answers Senator Boswell's specific questions, and he can come back to me if it does not meet them. The new RAS arrangements commenced on 1 January 1993 and the new FHS scheme, the farm household support scheme, commenced on 19 March. In 1992-93, 11,500 people received RAS support; in 1991-92, 13,751; and, in 1991, 4,859. Around half of the present RAS recipients are woolgrowers. Commonwealth funding this year is $173.5 million compared with $157.3 million last year and $62.5 million the year before.

PARA.TAB: Since FHS commenced on 19 March, 209 applications have been approved. It is still too early to judge the attractiveness of the scheme as a means of support to farmers in severe financial difficulty.
They are the basic statistics on the operation of those two schemes currently. Is there any other question that is lurking away there to which I have not responded?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boswell Sen R.L.D.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOSWELL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —That is very good information, to a question I did not ask. I thank the Minister for those figures. Three special benefits or special programs are offered and people can apply for them. Mr Crean's department refers to them. An article from the Country Life, entitled `Help in crisis', states:

SPEECH.PARA: People in crisis situations can get help from regional offices of the Department of Social Security. Special financial assistance programs include special benefit, hardship provisions and emergency relief payments.

Can I be given some advice on how many farmers are receiving special benefit. Does that program actually apply to farmers; if not, to whom does it apply? I understand the hardship provision, which I think is the old part C of the rural adjustment scheme which will be abolished in November. I understand that the emergency relief payments are made to St Vincent de Paul, the Salvation Army and similar organisations. It is very difficult to understand how these three programs, which have been advertised and promoted in the rural press, will give some positive benefit to people who are hard-pressed due to the wool crisis and the drought crisis in Queensland.

TALKER.NAME: Senator GARETH EVANS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Foreign Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I do have some information on those three areas. The special benefit provides assistance to people in severe financial hardship who are unable to earn an adequate livelihood due to circumstances beyond their control. The eligibility for that is based on the availability of funds. There are no statistics available on how many farmers have received special benefit, because that is not something which is indicated on the form. I am advised that, in general terms, it is unlikely that farmers would easily come within the relevant criteria.

PARA.TAB: Special hardship provisions enable persons who are suffering severe financial hardship but who have a substantial level of assets, which is much more obviously a farm situation, to obtain DSS assistance. There are currently 244 farmers and/or farmers' spouses receiving support through modified jobstart and newstart allowances in this respect. The applicability of these funds to farmers is scheduled to end on 30 November this year due to the introduction of the farm household support scheme, to which I referred earlier.

Emergency relief is not a social security program. I presume it is administered through the housing and community services portfolio; I am not sure about that. The emergency relief program grants funds to about 1,000 community welfare agencies to provide financial assistance to individuals and families in crisis situations. It is a Commonwealth-State program, and I am advised that quite a number of farm households pick up support through this particular indirect mechanism. But we are unable to quantify that, and detailed statistics as to occupational break-ups are unlikely to be obtainable. I hope that helps a little to clarify the situation in relation to those matters.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOSWELL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer to the emergency relief payments. I am not sure whether the Minister answered this question. Are there any figures or has any forward planning been done in relation to any of the relief which is going into rural or primary industry areas? I know that some sort of financial assistance package has been offered to the Salvation Army and St Vincent de Paul. Are there any figures which show where that money is going? Is any portion of that money being allocated to the primary industry areas?

TALKER.NAME: Senator GARETH EVANS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Foreign Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —We can give only anecdotal information about this. The statistical base is not available. But I have just been advised, for example, that 50 families in the Charleville area in Queensland have received emergency relief program funds administered through St Vincent de Paul and the Smith Family. I presume that example has been replicated in other parts of the country. But we do not have any systematic data on this. It would be a matter of going to the various welfare agencies and finding out from them how they are dispersing the lump funds which are made available to them. Clearly, some of the relief is filtering into distressed rural areas, and I guess we ought to be pleased about that.

—In the estimates committee, I raised the question of farm management bond guidelines. As yet, I do not appear to have received an answer to that question. Is that information in the mail also or is it not available?
—Were those questions tabled before the hearing or were they asked during the hearing?
—I believe they were asked during the hearing.

TALKER.NAME: Senator GARETH EVANS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Foreign Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —We will need to check that. My understanding is that all questions which were asked during the hearing and which were tabulated as such in the report have been answered, in the sense that the information has been provided. That will be checked. If the question has not been answered, the information will be provided as soon as possible. I have been advised further that not all the questions that were thus tabulated have been answered. Some of them depended on information being received from the States, which has not come to hand in all cases. Whether Senator Crane's question is one of those cases, I do not know. But I will get the department to communicate directly with Senator Crane or his office to tell him what the status of that reply is and when he can expect it.

—I thank the Minister. I also asked a question about the availability of jobsearch allowance on a State by State basis. This does not require comment. I assume that information is still being collected. But I would have thought the information on farm management bond guidelines would be readily available.
—As there are no further questions on program 2.2, we move on to program 2.3—quarantine and inspection.

—During the hearing on 12 May, I raised with AQIS officers—and it is recorded in the report of the committee—the issue of the importation of second-hand farm machinery, in particular the matter of the use of private sector contractors' premises for the inspection of second-hand farm machinery. At the time at which the report of the committee was put together, those answers were not available, and, to my knowledge, they have not been provided to my office in the interim.

PARA.TAB: I am concerned about the undertaking that was given to me on 12 May by Senator Cook to provide to me comments from AQIS in relation to this issue, because there have been concerns raised about the manner in which inspections of second-hand farm machinery are done and the fact that importers who, on the whole, tend to be farmers are not allowed to be present during the inspection of the machinery, with the consequence that some parts may be either pilfered or misplaced.

The other concern is in relation to the legal conditions that are placed on the importers by the contractor. The contractor is placed in the position of a legal monopoly by virtue of the legislation and the fact that AQIS only mandates one contractor to handle the inspection. I was promised that the comments of AQIS, as a result of the review, would be made available to me by the time of the Committee of the Whole debate. Accordingly, I would seek the advice of the Minister as to whether those comments, in the fashion they were promised to me on 12 May, are now available for me.

TALKER.NAME: Senator GARETH EVANS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Foreign Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —The matter is currently being checked, but there is a belief by the officers present that an answer to Senator O'Chee's question was signed off on Thursday of last week and it has not made its way to him as yet. There has been some communication problem which we are now trying to trace.

PARA.TAB: I am further advised, however, that the answer may not be entirely satisfactory because the issues that were raised did, in effect, go to customs control issues as well as strictly quarantine AQIS-type issues and, as such, there is a question of whether or not customs needs to be brought into the business of giving Senator O'Chee the requisite response. It appears that Senator O'Chee's particular question may not yet have been finalised, possibly because of this customs issue. But I have just been given an undertaking, which I re-tale to him, that he will get it by the close of business today, and that answer will seek to address the matters with which he is concerned, including those that do impinge upon, strictly speaking, customs issues. I hope that answer is satisfactory. I am sorry that Senator O'Chee did not get it earlier.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Minister for that undertaking, which I am happy to accept. I wish to place on record, though, that it is my understanding that customs does not really have a part to play in it because it is the actual inspection of the machinery versus any customs liability which is dealt with as a separate part of the process of importation. I am informed, and I could be incorrect, that it is an AQIS requirement that the machinery be unpacked and inspected at these particular premises. That is the problem. That information is just for the Minister's assistance and the assistance of the officers present. I thank the Minister for the undertaking and look forward to the advices.
—It seems we have reached the stage where there are quite a few unanswered questions in this section and also in PM and C. Therefore, I move:

PARA.TAB: That consideration of the question that the report of Estimates Committee A be adopted be postponed until questions asked of the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Senator Gareth Evans) are answered.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALKER.NAME: Senator GARETH EVANS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Foreign Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —How many unanswered questions does Senator Panizza think there are? There is this one and also the ATSIC ones we spoke of last night, and we need to come back to those. But what else is troubling Senator Panizza?
—There are no others. There is the one that the Minister has been talking to Senator O'Chee about, and the ones on ATSIC.
—I understand that. We will do our best to get responses to those opposite and postpone it accordingly by consent.

PARA.TAB: Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.PARA: REPORT OF ESTIMATES COMMITTEE B

PARA.TAB: Motion (by Senator Gareth Evans) proposed:
That the report of Estimates Committee B be adopted.

TALK.START.PARA: —The first department to be considered is the Department of Defence. The first matter on the running sheet is all questions taken on notice.

—In relation to questions taken on notice, I received an apology from the department about a question I asked about the cost of the Qantas charter to fly troops to Somalia. The question I asked was this: did the awarding of the contract to Qantas go to tender? I had been advised privately that it had not. At the time I received an assurance from the officers at the table that it had indeed gone to tender and gone to tender with other international carriers. Subsequently I received a letter saying that that advice was wrong. I am grateful that the matter was corrected. But I want to put on record that I view that mistake as rather serious.
