I do not wish to take it any further than that, but it was a matter that should have been quite beyond dispute or confusion in the eyes of the officers at the table at the time. I would ask that more care be taken when questions are asked of officers.

TALKER.NAME: Senator GARETH EVANS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Foreign Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —That point is noted. I will ensure that the attention of the Minister for Defence (Senator Robert Ray) is drawn to it.
—There being no questions on the departments of Defence and Veterans' Affairs, we will move to the Department of Employment, Education and Training.

—Before we deal with specific matters, I would like to draw to the attention of the Senate the fact that of the three departments covered by Estimates Committee B, the Department of Employment, Education and Training was the only department unable to provide answers to questions on notice before the committee reported to the Senate 10 days later. DEET managed to provide answers to the questions on notice 14 days after the estimates committee met. This meant that I was required to place reservations on every subprogram because it was impossible to decide which issues I needed to follow up until answers to questions on notice were provided.

PARA.TAB: This has happened with DEET every year that I have been in the Senate. The department seems to leave it to the last possible moment to provide answers to questions on notice, and often this means the day before the committee of the whole meets. The conclusion to be drawn from this repeated action by DEET is that either the department or the Minister is deliberately trying to avoid the scrutiny of the Parliament. I believe this is not good enough and I ask the Minister to give an undertaking to ensure that in future the department provides answers to questions on notice before the estimates committee tables its report in the Senate, as the other departments under Estimates Committee B have done.

TALKER.NAME: Senator ROBERT RAY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Defence)

TALK.START.PARA: —The circumstances on this occasion are not quite the same as normal. One mitigating factor is that there is usually a much longer period between holding the actual estimates committee hearings and the consideration of the committee of the whole. Sometimes it is in the order of six weeks; this time it was a much more compressed period.

PARA.TAB: Secondly, it is a little more awkward when the Minister is not in this chamber. What happened in the Department of Defence was that I pursued my own department—and I know Senator Faulkner now does the same—to get the answers, and we have had a very good record in the last two or three years in that regard. Because we are the Ministers in charge of the departments we press those matters. There is a slight difficulty when it involves a Minister representing the Minister, because the answers must be cleared by the portfolio Minister before they are cleared by me. When the House of Representatives is not sitting this process is sometimes more difficult.

Nevertheless, I will take an interest in this matter in the spring estimates committee process. We will have more time to get answers and we will be dealing with a different process. I believe it will be more important and more incumbent upon Ministers to get answers before we go into the supplementary estimates process. I say that out of self-interest because I do not want be standing up every five minutes and telling senators why questions are not answered.

The process was slightly unusual this time because we had a much more compressed period to get answers. We had the secondary problem that the House of Representatives was not meeting, and the portfolio Minister is not necessarily full time in Canberra—and I think Senator Tierney would understand why. Therefore, some of those answers are awaiting the Minister's clearance. I think it is a good process for the Minister to clear the answers because it does give them more authority. If there are then problems with the department it gives the Opposition more of an opportunity to follow it through than if one departmental official clears the answers and they do not go through the Minister.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Minister for that answer. I note that even though there was a compressed period this time there were fewer matters requiring additional expenditure. I also point out to the Minister that all other departments in Estimates Committee B have been operating under exactly the same conditions, including the Department of Defence and the Department of Veterans' Affairs, and they have managed to get their programs in on time.

PARA.TAB: I make the fairly obvious point that DEET seems to report at X minus one; whatever the date is that the appropriations come before the committee of the whole, the answers seem to reach the department only a day or so before. It does not allow proper scrutiny by the chamber. I acknowledge that the Minister is going to follow this matter up and take a close interest in it—and I thank him for that—but I make that comparison between DEET and the performance of other departments leading up to the committee of the whole.

TALKER.NAME: Senator ROBERT RAY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Defence)

TALK.START.PARA: —The officials are here and they have noted Senator Tierney's concerns. Mr Deputy President, Senator Crowley will handle DEET for about 15 minutes, and then I will be back.
—The committee is now considering program 2, subprogram 2.1.

—Determination T/93 is the ministerial instrument under the Higher Education Funding Act which distributes funding to Australian higher education institutions. As this is a disallowable instrument, when will it be tabled in the Parliament?
—I am advised Senator Tierney that it will be tabled on Thursday this week.
—I thank the Minister for the answer. As the determination was not gazetted until 3 March this year, under what arrangements did universities receive Federal funding during January and February?
—I am advised that the amending determinations were gazetted yesterday.

—In a question without notice in the House of Representatives on 13 May 1993 Dr Wooldridge asked Mr Beazley about DEET's procedure for funding higher education institutions under the Higher Education Funding Act. Mr Beazley said on that occasion that there had been some `technical irregularities in the way in which funds were paid'. Could the Minister please detail what `technical irregularities' means and whether this problem has been corrected?

TALKER.NAME: Senator CROWLEY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Family Services and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am advised that the Minister has said that there have been some technical irregularities which require further determinations, gazettal and tabling to remedy and that the Minister believes some departmental practices needed to be changed. The Minister undertook to communicate further with the Deputy Leader of the Opposition, Dr Wooldridge, when he was satisfied that processes were in place to ensure that technical irregularities would not occur in the future. I understand that Senator Tierney is still in the process of looking for further information and I am advised that the Minister's response is still coming. The Minister is still seeking that information.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tierney Sen J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Minister for her assurances about the future and that perhaps this will not occur again. My main concern is related to January and February of this year. Given these `technical irregularities', on what legal

SPEECH.PARA: basis were funds distributed to universities before the gazettal of the ministerial determination?

TALK.START.PARA: —I am advised that yesterday's gazettal makes proper all the payments to cover the period Senator Tierney mentioned.

—I take it, then, that this matter is retrospective. Is it not highly irregular to retrospectively do this? We are talking about a Budget of several billion dollars and we are talking about two months out of 12. On a quick calculation we must be talking about somewhere between half a billion dollars and a billion dollars being allocated to the universities of this country without any legal backing, in effect.

TALKER.NAME: Senator CROWLEY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Family Services and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women)

TALK.START.PARA: —I hope that I understood the honourable senator's question. I am advised that the payments were made in line with the amount proposed to be paid. The irregularity referred to was its not being gazetted prior to the payments, and it is that that was amended by the gazettal yesterday.

—As the gazettal did not occur until after the money had been spent, I am still trying to work out the legal basis for the Commonwealth distributing that money to the universities. How did that occur? Who was responsible for allowing up to, I presume, $1 billion in funds to go out across the country to the various universities without any legal basis in respect of the procedures of the Parliament?

TALKER.NAME: Senator CROWLEY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Family Services and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women)

TALK.START.PARA: —I think I have already given the answer to that question; these are matters on which the Minister agreed to seek full information and reply to. It is the matter that is under investigation.

—I thank the Minister for her answer and look forward to her reply, in particular, as to whether it was the Minister's decision or a decision taken within the department of which the Minister was unaware. As Senator Crowley would probably be aware, there was a major change in funding arrangements for universities this year and towards the end of last year with the reforms to the Higher Education Funding Act.

PARA.TAB: What I find particularly disturbing about this matter is that this change escaped the scrutiny of the Parliament. Whereas the money used to be distributed through the States to the universities, the amendment to the Act last year means that the money now goes from the Federal Government directly to the institutions. That amendment obviously has a basis in law because it went through the Higher Education Funding Act towards the end of last year, and that is fine. However, I find it particularly disturbing that, consequent to that massive change and after only two months of operating in that way, in effect, the funding has no legal basis.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crowley Sen The Hon R.A.

TALKER.NAME: Senator CROWLEY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Family Services and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women)

TALK.START.PARA: —My attention has been drawn to page 4084 of the Senate Hansard of Wednesday, 2 December 1992 where Senator Tierney highlights the importance of those amendments in his contribution to the debate at that time. He commented:

SPEECH.PARA: Another measure which I am pleased to see the Government introducing is the provision of direct grants to institutions. This is an excellent idea because it will facilitate the implementation of the Opposition's national education award system when we are in government after the next election.
Sorry, I should have left out the last few words.

TALK.START.PARA: —A bit of point scoring there.

—I had no intention of doing that at all. The passage was not underlined, so I naturally read to the end of the sentence. The passage clearly indicates that Senator Tierney was aware of the proposed changes to the Act. My understanding is that the Minister is seeking further information about the points Senator Tierney has raised and we all wait on the Minister's reply.

—I was not commenting on the changes to the Act that allow direct funding; I was merely pointing out that a major change occurred at that time and that we are now in a position where the first part of the administration of that new Act involves a highly irregular procedure where, before gazettal, the money has been spent during the previous two months. I will not pursue the point any further. I have made the point very clearly. I look forward to the Minister's answer with respect to who is responsible and how the situation came about.
—I presume that is the end of program 2.1. There being no questions with respect to program 3, I move to program 4, with particular reference to subprogram 4.1.

—I have some comments to make with regard to the Hunter landcare and environment action program. In the course of the Estimates Committee B hearing I was informed that the program organiser, Father John McPherson, could not have gained the impression that that program had received the go-ahead. Father McPherson has forwarded to me detailed correspondence from the department which gave him the clear impression that funding for this program would soon be available. Will the Minister explain why emergency funding for Father McPherson was not approved when his entire program was in jeopardy and has now, in fact, possibly closed down—his phone was due to be cut off last Thursday?

TALKER.NAME: Senator CROWLEY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Family Services and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am advised by officers of the department that they have not seen the correspondence to which Senator Tierney refers. That is the most I can say about that. Further, the secretary, Mr Snowdon, has given in-principle agreement for the funding to be coming forthwith.
—Could the Minister explain what `coming forthwith' means in actual time?
—I am advised that, at the very latest, as soon as the appropriations Bills are passed.

—We have almost daily contact with Father McPherson, who is absolutely desperate to get this money. People have lost their homes; major trauma has been suffered by people who have not received income. I asked the same questions in the estimates hearings but did not receive satisfactory answers at the time, mainly because the people answering the questions were not fully aware of the circumstances involved. Since 10 to 12 days have passed since then, I thought that the Minister would have received a very accurate briefing.

PARA.TAB: I am amazed by Senator Crowley's comment that the department was not aware of the correspondence relating to this matter because Father McPherson is in receipt of correspondence from the department. I assumed the officers would have asked for the file so that on the basis of that correspondence they would have been be able to give a more accurate response as to what was promised to Father McPherson and what was not.

TALK.START.PARA: —The correspondence is being sought from the State office and investigations into compensation are under way.
—I find that amazing. The matter was raised 14 days ago and the department is still seeking correspondence from the State office.
—We have fax machines.

—As Senator Kemp points out, we have faxes and, dare I say, e-mail. We are only talking about a file of one case. Even by Australia Post it would get there in much quicker time. Why has it taken so much time for the department to get its mind around this particular issue? I cannot understand why it has taken so much time.

—I believe there has been a misunderstanding here. The State office is—and has been—looking into this matter as we speak. The officers advise me that they have not seen the correspondence, but they will be looking at it. The decision is being made in the State office and that is where the process is happening right now.

—All this month we have had examples of curious processes operating within the Department of Transport and Communications. We seem to have a similar process operating in another government department. The federal officers were aware that we would be considering this matter in the Committee of the Whole today. During the estimates committee hearings I raised this item as a major matter and, given that I reserved it, I would have thought that the federal officers would have sought a briefing from the State officers as to exactly where this matter was up to.

PARA.TAB: It is not a complicated matter. It is just one case study. The correspondence is all there. Surely a one-page briefing could have been provided. We employ thousands of officers and we spend billions of dollars on DEET. Why cannot we get advice more promptly on what is basically a simple and straightforward matter?

TALKER.NAME: Senator CROWLEY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Family Services and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women)

TALK.START.PARA: —I think there is a confusion here and Senator Tierney may be drawing a slightly wrong conclusion. The officers here are aware of the matter, but the process is principally being examined and proceeded with in the State office. Ultimately the information that is being worked on will have to go to the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Employment, Education and Training (Mr Snowdon) for examination. The honourable senator's conclusion is not quite accurate.
—I find it hard to believe why it is not accurate. Given that the matter has been brought up in the Senate, the delay is absolutely appalling. I will leave it at that and move on to the next point.

PARA.TAB: Is the department aware that the Hunter Leap program obtained approval from a bank for an emergency loan with the proviso that the Minister for Employment, Education and Training (Mr Beazley) could provide assurance of funding? Can the Minister explain why the Government failed to provide this assurance; thus forcing Hunter Leap to go without the loan?

TALK.START.PARA: —This is part of the matter under consideration by the Minister and the Parliamentary Secretary. As I have said, the matter will be examined and a response provided in due course.

—I will leave the matter there. I ask that the Senate be provided with a report on this matter. It seems that we have not had answers to these questions because the matter is still with the State department. One wonders why, after 14 days. As this matter is still with the State department, I ask that the Senate be provided with a written report on this matter.
—I am advised yes.
—As there any no further questions in relation to subprogram 4.1, we will move to subprogram 4.3.

—We are dealing here with labour adjustment assistance. Under the Additional Estimates $21.133 million is requested for labour adjustment packages. Approximately 70 per cent of this amount is allocated for Victoria. In its Review 1992 document the department claims that three months after the completion of the programs 47 per cent of participants the textile industry are in full-time employment, and 39 per cent in the passenger motor vehicle industry. Can the Minister explain this low success rate?
—I am advised that in the current economic situation the textile, clothing and footwear figure is average and the other figure is above average.

—I assume the Minister means average for similar types of schemes? Compared with other schemes, such as jobstart, it does not seem to have such a high success rate. Has the department given consideration to diverting the funds to the more successful jobstart program?
—I am advised the answer is no. The mix of programs and the commitment to those programs reflects the Government's broad approach to different needs.

—I find that curious. I wonder why the department would not switch to a program which, according to its claims and according to the statistics available, is a more successful program. Why not just put them on jobstart?

TALKER.NAME: Senator CROWLEY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Family Services and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am advised that it cannot be done in that manner very often. For example, in this particular case many of the people will need English language training before they could actually move into jobstart programs. That takes quite some time. It would have a long lead time. It is a different program targeted to a different outcome.
—We turn now to program 5: education assistance and income support, and subprogram 5.1: education income support.

—During the estimates committee hearing I was told that additional expenditure was required under the Austudy supplement scheme even though the take-up rate for this scheme was very low. Can the Minister for Defence (Senator Robert Ray) provide a breakdown on the establishment costs of the fixed overheads as they were described by Mr Hickey in the Hansard for Estimates Committee B on page 79 and the running costs of the program?
—We do not have the details here, but we will provide them.
—In addition, when the Minister is asking for that could we have a breakdown on the cost per student as well?
—Yes, that is possible.
—Can the Minister explain how additional money is needed for this program when the program's take-up rate was below one-third of what was budgeted?
—These figures are reflected in the take-up costs. If we run under to the extent that Senator Tierney is indicating, there will be further money available next year.

—In the additional estimates hearing we were given a similar explanation that it was overhead costs and that sort of thing, but we are talking about a take-up rate—these figures are rough—of something like 27,000 out of an expected 70,000 in one case, and in another case a take-up rate of about 3,000 out of something like 24,000.

PARA.TAB: As the Minister can see, overhead costs will not explain all of that, because with this sort of program we have a situation where a lot of the costs is incurred in working with the students, answering students' queries and processing forms. Therefore, if there is such a massive underrun, if I could put it that way, it is very strange that the expenditure has overrun what was estimated for the full take-up. The mind boggles at what would have happened if the 70,000 students had turned up and, in the other case, if the people had just opted for the loan and not Austudy. We would be looking at what would be an absolutely massive blow-out if a third take-up rate produced an overrun on costs on the original estimate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALKER.NAME: Senator ROBERT RAY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Defence)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am informed that the expenses are not only based on take-up rate but also on inquiries, as we may still have to provide the same amount of staff and resources to deal with their inquiries rather than the take-up rate. But, if the take-up rate is lower, obviously there will be an adjustment in the next estimates to take that into account.

PARA.TAB: Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.PARA: REPORT OF ESTIMATES COMMITTEE C

PARA.TAB: Motion (by Senator Robert Ray) proposed:
That the report of Estimates Committee C be adopted.

TALK.START.PARA: —The first department to be considered is the Department of Health, Housing, Local Government and Community Services. Again, we will go by the running sheet. (Quorum formed)
—I table additional information received by Estimates Committee C.

—We are considering Estimates Committee C. I would like to point out to honourable senators who have not been in here for estimates earlier today that we are going according to the running sheet. There is something new on this particular running sheet. Items which have an asterisk beside them were not subject to additional estimates, so they should not be pursued in the Committee of the Whole. Are there any matters relating to all questions taken on notice before and during the committee's hearings and for which answers were not received prior to 18 May 1993?

—I asked some questions about cases of TB in overseas born people. I asked for more information relating to those people who have TB and who have come from overseas. I would like to raise with the Minister the fact that the answer that I was given contained information that 66 per cent of the people with TB were born overseas. I ask the Minister: is that not out-of-date information? Is it not true that figures on the incidence of TB in Australia indicate that at least 70 per cent were born overseas and that in Victoria, for example, the level is at something like 80 per cent?

TALKER.NAME: Senator RICHARDSON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Health)

TALK.START.PARA: —The latest figures that we have are for 1991. There were 903 new cases of TB notified to State health departments. Of those, we have data for the country of birth of 884; 577 of the 844—or 66 per cent—were born overseas. I can give a break-up of the 577. They are the only figures that we have.

—It would appear—maybe for some reason unknown to me—that the department is not up to date. The break-up that is given does not indicate any presence of people from Cambodia, from what is now Bosnia, or from the CIS—formerly the USSR. As I understand it, there is a very high incidence of TB in the countries from which those people are coming. In fact, we have had reported cases of people born in those countries who are contracting TB in Australia. I just do not feel that these figures are an accurate reflection of what is really happening.

TALKER.NAME: Senator RICHARDSON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Health)

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not have any other information. My advisers say that they have no information on this. I agree with Senator Newman: it does seem strange that there are no figures of people who come from Cambodia where there is certainly a high incidence of TB. I will check that for her and get back to her as soon as I can.

—The Minister will recognise that the answer I was given says that 156 people came from Vietnam, which is also a country with a high incidence of TB. Its neighbour, Cambodia, is very much in the same boat and therefore of concern when we are receiving a number of people from that country. I do not believe that this accurately reflects the proportion of those with TB who have come from overseas countries.

PARA.TAB: I would also like to draw the attention of the Minister to another part of the answer I was given. I think that the answers I was given in the estimates committee hearing the other night were most unsatisfactory, as is this response that has been given by way of additional information. We will have to try to get to the bottom of why it is so inadequate. First of all, the answer I was given says that people who provide a tuberculosis undertaking are required to report to their nearest tuberculosis clinic within a specified period after arrival so that their health can be monitored. Is that not an extremely misleading answer; in fact, is it not untrue?

TALK.START.PARA: —I am advised that it is true. If it is untrue, Senator Newman might enlighten me and I will see what I can do about it.

—If the Minister does not know and is not being told, perhaps I had better be the one to tell him. First of all, those tuberculosis undertakings do not require anybody to report. There is no way that people can be made to report. They are worthless as a piece of paper. Certainly they are not being followed up and therefore their health is not being monitored.

TALKER.NAME: Senator RICHARDSON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Health)

TALK.START.PARA: —I will have that checked immediately. My advice is that this information on tuberculosis undertakings came from the Commonwealth medical officers in Sydney. We will check with them immediately as to whether or not this is wrong.

—I do not expect the Minister to have senior officials here who do not know the answers. This is not something new; this has been going on for a very long time. The Minister's department has advised that these undertakings are not worth the paper they are written on. His department is also very well aware of the fact that people may be asked to give information about where they are going to live. They do not go and live there half the time, they go and live somewhere else or move on. His department and the State health authorities have got no idea where they are. In practical terms these are worthless.

PARA.TAB: Progress reported.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs. Is the Minister aware of allegations of institutional bias within his department towards refugees? Is he also aware that the secretary to the department has called in the Australian Federal Police to investigate certain alleged actions by a senior officer of the department, and that a meeting of officers of his department has moved a vote of no confidence in the secretary?

PARA.TAB: In the light of these and other concerns that have been expressed recently, and the important need for the community to have confidence in the administration of Australia's migration program, will the Government establish a thorough public inquiry into the department to investigate the operations and implementation of the migration program and the department's capacity to handle, in the future, the tasks for which it is responsible?

TALK.START.PARA: —We do not need Senator Walters's help. Thankfully, in a few days time we will not be getting it. Senator Short raises an issue which I expected him to ask on day one, some 3 1/2 weeks ago. The issues he raises are not new now. They have been in—
—If people on your side were more compassionate and had more commitment we would be much better off.
—We also could do better without Senator Patterson's nasty little comments across the chamber.

PARA.TAB: It is a question that I expected might have been raised about 3 1/2 weeks ago; it has been in the public domain for at least that length of time, if not longer. The question of institutional bias has been raised in a very important court case in Victoria, the duration of which has ensured that at least 200, if not more, files of the department have been made available, through the discovery process, to people applying for refugee status. It is a core issue before the courts, and one that I think is best handled by the courts.

In respect of the assertions about the AFP, I think the secretary to the department put out a press statement on the Friday afternoon that they were called in to investigate the allegations. As I said in the estimates committee process, in my first few weeks in the job I have canvassed attitudes and views from a whole raft of people interested in immigration and ethnic affairs, from the business side to the community side.

I think I met with about 2,000 representatives of community organisations, and had discussions with about 200 organisations, who were making representations to me in respect of our refugee program, humanitarian program or whatever. Overwhelmingly, there is a view in the community that the department does its job very well. I think that came through in the consultations, and I am sure that is the attitude that Senator Short will get as well.

There are two areas of criticism. One is the day by day cases thrown up, whether by a review tribunal or by media commentators. Those cases have always been around, and as long as we have an immigration process these sorts of cases will always come up. The incident which I think Senator Short goes to to develop his case for an inquiry is, of course, the situation of the boat people.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is wider than that.

—Hold it; that is the case which Senator Short has put up so far in respect of the boat people. I have made it clear that we in this Parliament have laid down the law as to how those boat people should be handled and that we in this Parliament made the decision as to detention. We made that decision towards the end of last year when we knew that the people involved had been in detention for some two years and would be in detention for an extra period, at least a year, given the fact that we in this Parliament—
—You made the decision.

—Without Senator Harradine's assistance—gave those boat people further rights of appeal after they arrived in this country. My advice is that in respect of all the people who are currently before the courts—and there are about 321 out of a total intake of about 680 who came in by boat—those cases were all processed domestically by the department within a nine-month period. The clock stops at 273 days. We now have a situation where they are exercising rights by the law of this Parliament. In terms of their release from detention, we determine that the clock stops when they exercise rights outside the internal immigration department process. So I do not think there is a need for an inquiry.
—Order! The clock has stopped. The Minister's time has expired.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Despite the Minister's comments, I think he is aware that my question goes much wider than the boat people detainees, important though they are. In view of the Minister's intransigence on my call for an inquiry, and his seemingly complacent approach to the administration of his department and the community attitudes towards it—potentially a very disabling condition that I hope he has not caught from his colleague Senator Collins—what steps does he propose to take to restore public confidence in the administration of his department?

—It seems as though Senator Short was not prepared to listen to my answer just a few seconds ago, nor was he prepared to listen to it some one or two weeks ago in the estimates committee hearing. In general in the community there is overwhelming confidence in this department. I have been very keen and I have responded promptly, together with the secretary to the department, Mr Conybeare, in instances where allegations have been put to us. Mr Conybeare has been very quick to respond to instances of conduct which would undermine the reputation of his department, such as in respect to the AFP. We will respond in instances where it is necessary.

PARA.TAB: However, I will not be a party to a situation where the Senate undertakes an inquiry into the department on an issue that is currently before the courts in matters which are fundamental to our national security, as this Parliament has determined. We in this Parliament have determined that the system of detention was in our national security. That system needs to be protected.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The Minister's time has expired.

—My question is directed to the Minister for the Arts and Administrative Services. Is the Minister aware of the work of the National Institute of Dramatic Art? By the way, Tasmanians do very well in the very competitive preselection process for places offered at NIDA. Is the Minister also aware of the work of the Australian Film, Television and Radio School and the Australian Ballet School? Will the Minister ensure sufficient support to those wonderful training institutions so as to enhance overseas awareness of Australia's cultural vitality and identity?

—Those three particular institutions—all of which I have had the pleasant opportunity to visit recently—have made outstanding contributions. Particularly of note is the fact that today a graduate of the Australian Film, Television and Radio School won the prestigious Palme d'Or at Cannes. I think every Australian is very proud of that. It is an outstanding achievement by an outstanding resident of this country who has gone through that school. Last year at Cannes we had an outstanding victory in the Prix de la Jeunesse to a graduate of NIDA—
—Your French pronunciation is not very good.

—It is better than Senator Kemp's; it is better than his English as well—in Baz Luhrmann, who directed the outstanding film Strictly Ballroom, which had its origins in the developmental work done at NIDA and which has gone from strength to strength, both culturally and economically, since that time. They are just two examples of some of the outstanding individuals who have gone through those institutions.

PARA.TAB: Today, in the foyer, I had the pleasure of announcing that an Australian musical production, Hot Shoe Shuffle, will open next year on London's West End with its full Australian company of dancers and singers, at least one of whom—as I found in the discussion I had with them—is a graduate of the ballet school. Across the nation there are great cultural successes nationally and internationally. More and more of them are flowing from the support which the Government gives to NIDA, the film and television school and the Australian ballet school and people who—

TALK.START.PARA: —Dawkins might cut their budget; is that right?

—I know those opposite are aghast. If we had given $1 million to one of them and it failed, those opposite would be here wanting to talk about it, but because we gave $100,000 to one and it succeeded, they do not want to know about it. This Parliament spends hours of its time pursuing small amounts of money in areas where people think something might have gone wrong. Here we have investment of the taxpayers' money that is giving a tremendous return to Australian individuals and to Australia as a nation and we should all be proud of it. I think most Australians are proud of these three institutions; everybody on this side of the chamber is proud of them.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I was interested to hear the Minister's comments about Strictly Ballroom and the Hot Shoe Shuffle. Is he aware that Tara Morice, the female lead in Strictly Ballroom, is a Tasmanian? Is he aware that Graeme Murphy, perhaps Australia's most world renowned choreographer and now opera director, is also a Tasmanian?

—My first response to that is to say that I am now. But it is not surprising. I do not know whether Senator Tate could find a way of claiming that somehow we got Errol Flynn through NIDA; nevertheless, Tasmanians have made a substantial contribution to our cultural life. The weekend before last, I had a fascinating opportunity—with those wonderful new members for Bass and Lyons whom we are all so pleased to see in the Parliament—to visit many of the young and talented people developing their skills in the north and north-west of Tasmania. Many of them will go on to these various institutions, as will a large number of people from all around Australia. These are successful national institutions and we are all very proud of the people, from wherever they come, who achieve these sorts of successes.
—My question is directed to the Minister for Transport and Communications—
—Make it sensible.

—As usual, it will be. I refer to a minute to the Minister from his department headed `Pay TV—Next Steps', dated 14 September 1992, although not acknowledged by the Minister until 12 October, which I seek leave to table.
—Is leave granted?
—It was tabled yesterday.

—It was provided to my office this morning; it has not yet been tabled. Is it not a fact that this minute advises the Minister that, in a price based allocation tender process for the satellite pay television licences of the type eventually chosen by the Minister, `a limited examination of the . . . financial capabilities of the tenderers would be possible'? Does this not mean that the Minister was advised by the Department of the desirability of some sort of limited financial hurdle, such as a deposit, being included in the tender process? Accordingly, why did he not seek a full brief providing all the options for assessing the financial capability of bidders before he signed the determination of 19 January?

—I have constantly asserted in this Parliament for three weeks—in the face of this non-stop tirade of humbug from the Opposition about what I read and what I do not read—that Senator Alston has consistently not read documents that I have provided. He has just confirmed it again. I need to correct this from the beginning. Senator Alston said that these documents were not tabled in Parliament yesterday. They were tabled in Parliament yesterday. In fact, since this process began, this set—which I now place on the desk—was the first bundle of documents from the Federal Court tabled in Parliament; this was the next set tabled in Parliament; this was the next set tabled in Parliament; and the last set, containing the document Senator Alston has just referred to, was tabled in Parliament yesterday. I really do not think we can be—

—I rise on a point of order, Mr President. The question did not relate to theatrics; the question asked why this Minister did nothing for several months and why he did not seek a brief outlining the options. I ask you to bring him to order.
—Order! There is no point of order. The Minister was asked about a document that was tabled.

—As the Hansard will show, Senator Alston's question opened with the assertion that this document was not tabled yesterday; I have just demonstrated that it was. All of these matters are contained, as Senator Alston knows, in the Pearce report. I have referred to that highly critical paragraph in the Pearce report—paragraph 27—which provides some trenchant criticism, with which I agree, about what subsequently happened. It is all there.

PARA.TAB: I just want to conclude on this point because it is worth making again. The bottom line is that all of us in this Parliament agreed that the problem with the satellite process, in terms of the very issues that Senator Alston is now referring to, having abandoned the prospect of these hurdles which were raised in that paper—if Senator Alston wants to read the paper, which clearly he has not bothered to do, he will see that a number of simple suggestions were being made in that paper about the possibility of either a one stage or a two stage process being raised; it is all canvassed by the Pearce report—was, in my view the most substantial error, which I identified yesterday, the failure to ask for a deposit.

The Government acted immediately to introduce legislation into this Parliament which corrected the error identified by Senator Alston himself. That became law a week ago. In other words, it resolved the problem for industry. It clearly protected the rights of the existing tenderers, and no-one in the Opposition argued with that. But the only reason it became law and the only reason that the industry now has some stability—now that the mistake has been identified—was thanks to the support of the Australian Democrats in moving that amendment.

The fact is that, despite all this whining, whingeing, moaning and wall-to-wall humbug with which this Parliament has been carpeted for the last three weeks, the Opposition refused to support the corrective action which it identified as being necessary. The pretext was that it had to wait 30 days. What did that actually mean? Not that it had to wait 30 days but that it had to wait until this Parliament rose, and then it could not be addressed until the end of August. In terms of credibility, the Opposition has none on this matter.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Why did the Minister choose to talk about everything other than the question at hand? Does the question at hand not amount to this: that four months before he signed that determination he was put on notice by his department that one of the options available to him was to insist on a limited form of financial capability which would include a deposit? The facts are that the Minister did absolutely nothing, could not be bothered, showed no interest, left it to the department; and now he says that it mucked it up. Why does he not come clean and admit his responsibilities?

—The document that I have just referred to—to get the record absolutely accurate—is contained in one of these box files, not in the green file, which were all tabled as one package yesterday. A number of honourable senators have been complaining about tedious repetition in this chamber. As I said yesterday, one of the problems with this debate is the tedious repetition of the questions. Senator Alston will find that the Attorney-General's advice, which was the advice that was crucial to the decision that was taken, was in fact canvassed in the very first question that Senator Alston asked me on the very first day of these sittings three weeks ago. As reference to the Hansard record will show, it has been asked and answered a dozen times since. I am not quite sure, in his desperate attempt to extract a bit more out of this, how many more times around the track Senator Alston is going to go.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Family Services. The Minister would be aware that many women, especially women from non-English speaking backgrounds, do not have regular Pap smears. What is being done to provide information about cervical cancer and the need for regular checks to women from non-English speaking backgrounds?

—I thank Senator West for her question. Every year some 350 women die of cervical cancer. Nearly all those deaths—about 90 per cent—could be prevented by regular Pap smears. We are very concerned that this message be spread to all Australian women, not just to those of English speaking backgrounds. A key part of a $2 million information campaign funded by the Federal Government is this week's SBS program on cervical cancer. Honourable senators might care to tune in.

PARA.TAB: The English at Work program is informing women from non-English speaking backgrounds about Pap smears. It will be repeated in different languages all this week. Tonight the information will be in Greek, tomorrow in Vietnamese, Thursday in Arabic, and Friday in Spanish. The dramatised documentary deals with some of the problems women face when they are told they have to have a Pap smear. Many women believe this means cancer while others are embarrassed. Many women believe that a Pap smear is a cancer test. I know women think this from my experience of working in the health area.

A Pap smear is a way of detecting cell changes so that problems can be treated before cancer develops. It is estimated that about 750 cases per year of cervical cancer are prevented from developing through the early detection of abnormal cells. A Pap smear is recommended every two years for women aged between 18 and 70.

Next week, in what will make a fortnight of women's health programs on the SBS, the English at Work program will be looking at breast cancer and urging women over 50 to have a mammogram every two years. Like the English at Work program on cervical cancer, the program on breast cancer will be screened in different languages all the next week. The message to all Australian women is that they can take care of their own health by asking their doctor for a regular Pap smear or mammogram.

As Geraldine Doogue said in the program, women should take this action for the people who love and need them, but most of all for themselves. This message seems to be getting through. In Victoria, following a month-long screening of the advertisement by Geraldine Doogue, there was a 30 per cent increase in the number of Pap smears carried out by the Victorian Cytology Service. Women are responding very well to the ads; about 84 per cent remember them.

This week's television program and our ongoing advertising campaign is only one aspect of the Government's fight against cervical cancer. We have dramatically increased the number of women having Pap smears.
Opposition senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not understand. Perhaps Opposition senators are not interested in a program such as the one dealing with Pap smears for cervical cancer. I would have thought that they would be very concerned about a simple test that can so easily reduce the number of deaths from a preventable cancer in women. It has not been taken seriously by those opposite and has fallen off their health care program. This Government's commitment, having listened to women and followed up what they want introduced, has been to develop this program for cervical cancer detection and prevention and the Pap smear campaign. I would have thought Opposition senators would be interested in listening.

PARA.TAB: In particular, it is important that women know the test can be done sensitively and properly. They will then be able to know that they can return every two years and be sure to keep their cervical health under control. It is very important that women understand this service is out there, that they know how to make use of it and that we do not restrict these services only to women who speak English. I commend the SBS program.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Leader of the Government in the Senate and Minister for Foreign Affairs to the current surge of textile imports to the extent that a recent visit to eight Adelaide stores produced eight jumpers made in China and none made in Australia. Will the Government accept the Garnaut proposal for liberalising trade with China? Secondly, without denigrating the prospect of higher wool sales, what will the Government do about the accelerated destruction of the Australian textile industry and the 50,000 or so textile workers who will lose their jobs? More specifically, what is the Government doing to promote Australian-made goods in preference to imports?

—So far as the Chinese wool trade is concerned, I should say at the outset that for some time we have been actively seeking Chinese liberalisation of its current import policies in the wool sector. We have been pressing China in particular to abolish import quotas and licensing requirements and to reduce tariffs rates on imported wool in a series of joint ministerial and officials meetings.

PARA.TAB: I have seen the reported comments on this issue; the suggestions of Ross Garnaut as reported in this morning's Australian. They are very interesting suggestions but I think, given the fact that Professor Garnaut is presently chairing a committee of inquiry with broad-ranging terms of reference on this whole issue, it would be quite premature to speculate on the particular recommendations that are likely to arise from that review, whether they relate to trade with China or anywhere else.

As to textile and clothing concerns more generally, the objectives of the textile, clothing and footwear plan are to promote the restructuring and revitalisation of the TCF industries, to improve efficiency in international competitiveness, to reduce dependence on Commonwealth assistance and to encourage the adoption of best business practices including progressive human resource policies. In particular, the TCF Development Authority has been established to implement that whole strategy with funding available to it and policy mechanisms now in train to actively promote the restructuring and revitalisation of the TCF industries.

Increased value added to wool is being encouraged by assisting a small number of major investments and projects which are export oriented, financially sound and directed towards developing markets for branded and differentiated Australian products. The local apparel industry needs to restructure and reinvest in order to focus its operations upon exports in a smaller, more market oriented domestic apparel sector. Authority assistance in this context to the textile sector is directed towards projects that involve restructuring, rationalisation, reinvestment, export orientation and the further processing of Australian raw materials.

For clothing firms—this is true of footwear firms as well—priority is being given to those which, again, are market rather than production oriented, have close relationships with retailers, are developing branded quality merchandise and are using quick response manufacturing techniques including electronic data interchange systems.

That is the strategy which is under way. The success of that in practice has been demonstrated, I think, by the fact that value added in 1991-92 was $2.2 billion. That is only about $200 million less than in 1986-87 despite a fall in employment over that period of about 15,000 people. Average value added per person employed has increased by about 10 per cent. Exports have risen strongly each year with total TCF exports in 1991-92 of $418 million, which was 38 per cent greater than the figure for 1986-87.

There is a strategy in place and it is working. It has won, I think generally, the acceptance of the industry. The inevitability of changes of this kind is acknowledged and most participants, rather than continuing to try to impose or hold the line on quantitative restrictions, are planning how they will handle the change to lower tariffs. Overall, the industry is supportive of the plan and can be expected, I believe, to continue to work towards the overall restructuring of the industry in such a way as to guarantee its future as an important part of the manufacturing scene in this country.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I wonder, in view of his answer, whether the Minister can tell us, firstly, how the Australian textile industry could cope with a Chinese textile factory paying $20 for a 48-hour week. Secondly, is the Minister prepared to table all products purchased by government which are not manufactured in Australia using Australian-made components?

—Am I prepared to table all products? A pretty large table would be necessary. If Senator Spindler can make that question intelligible I will be happy to try to respond. I think he will have to be a little more subject specific than that. As to the first part of his question, I have nothing to add to what I said. I gave the answer on how we are going to cope.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs. In view of the fact that the United Nations is convening, for the first time in 25 years, a world conference on human rights in Vienna from 14 to 25 June, I ask the Minister whether Australia will be participating in that meeting and, if so, what the main objectives will be. I also ask whether women's issues will be on the agenda and whether Australia will support an Amnesty International proposal for a special commissioner on human rights.

—I am indebted to Senator Giles for that question which reflects her very longstanding interest in human rights and, in particular, women's rights issues. Senator Giles has in fact shown this interest—unlike Senator Bishop, who is squawking again—for the entire duration of her term in this Parliament and I think we will all miss her in that respect.

PARA.TAB: Australia will indeed be participating in the world conference. In fact, I will be leading the delegation. I think our attendance is another affirmation of the importance that the Government does attach to the protection of human rights. That commitment was most recently reinforced by Australia's re-election to the United Nations Commission on Human Rights on 29 April.

The world conference in Vienna next month does provide a unique opportunity to review the progress that has been made in the protection and promotion of human rights over the last 25 years and to identify the measures that need to be taken in the future to build on those achievements. The conference will involve some quite difficult and lengthy negotiations over its final outcome, as the preparatory process has so far been unable to resolve many of the more contentious human rights issues, including the differences that are argued for as between the different regional geographical groupings.

Australia's specific objectives at this conference are as follows: first, to press for a reallocation of funding within the UN to correct the serious disparity between the organisation's proclaimed priority of promoting and protecting human rights and its actual allocation of resources; second, to develop a program designed to achieve universal acceptance of the core human rights instruments and to reform the operation of existing treaty bodies and human rights political organs to ensure their effective operation; third, to develop a particular Australian initiative on the establishment of independent national human rights machinery to promote and protect human rights; fourth, to promote another initiative on national action plans which invites each state to draw up a written plan of action identifying steps whereby it could improve its observance of human rights; and, finally, to ensure that further impetus is given to the handling of women's issues and indigenous issues by the world conference.

As to women's issues—the second part of Senator Giles's question—we did fight hard during the preparatory process to have a specific reference to women included on the agenda. In close consultation with other delegations, in particular Canada, we have recently succeeded in strengthening the text of the draft final outcome relating to women, which is now to go forward to Vienna.

As to the last part of the question, Amnesty International has proposed that one of the outcomes of this Vienna conference should be the announcement of a special commissioner for human rights based in New York. We see considerable merit in that proposal. In particular, it would raise the profile of human rights in the whole UN system and ensure that these concerns were injected into the mainstream of the UN political process. It might also succeed in attracting some additional resources, which are very badly needed in this area. We would want to avoid duplication of or conflict with the Centre for Human Rights in Geneva. We would be concerned if the price of establishing such a position were some purported rationalisation of existing UN human rights machinery which might actually end up weakening that machinery by folding existing procedures and institutions into the office of a special commissioner.

Overall, this proposal is an important stimulus for discussion on reform matters. We are concerned that it may founder on opposition from other regional groups. In those circumstances, we acknowledge that, while supporting it, we may need to look simultaneously at other options to ensure that the outcome of the world conference will lead to an increase in resources and better coordination in the area of human rights. I thank Senator Giles once again for her question.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Family Services and follows the advice she gave a moment ago to all Australian women over the age of 50 to seek a mammogram every two years. I ask the Minister whether under her Government's policy and practice all such women will receive a Medicare rebate.

—My principal responsibility in the area of breast cancer is to see the implementation of the national breast cancer screening program, which will be providing mammogram screening to women every two years. The reason for the delay in the implementation of this program has been the challenge of coming to agreement with the States about how best to establish and implement the program.
—Mr President, I raise a point of order. I asked whether women who take Senator Crowley's advice will receive a Medicare rebate. I wonder whether we could have an answer to that question.
—Order! There is no point of order.

—No, there is not. If Senator Hill will just wait, he will understand the reason why I am answering the question in this way. This program will provide a screening every two years to women over the age of 50. That program is already established to the point where some 200,000 women have already been screened, and the number of women enjoying that screening process is increasing dramatically.

—Mr President, I raise a point of order on the ground of relevance. I ask that you bring the Minister back to at least attempting to answer the very simple question that was asked, and that is: will all Australian women who take her important advice, the advice that she has given today, receive under this Government's policy in practice a Medicare rebate?

—Order! Senator Crowley, you were asked a question about the Medicare rebate and, I think in terms of relevance, you should answer it. However, could I remind the Leader of the Opposition that the question probably was not directed at the appropriate Minister.

—Mr President, you have just pre-empted my king hit. Obviously, the Opposition does not understand what a screening process is about; that is, to provide this service without the complication of having to provide a Medicare rebate. If the question is seriously about Medicare rebates, it properly belongs with Senator Richardson who is the Minister for Health. Senator Hill's problem is that he does not understand what a screening program is. This program is designed to facilitate—to actually make it easy—for the women of Australia to have a mammogram. The process is quite clearly understood in terms of the funding for screening.

—Mr President, I raise a point of order. Three times you have sought to have Senator Crowley answer the question. Thus far she has failed to do so. It is a simple yes or no answer. She seems incapable of doing so because it is not in her brief. I ask you to refer her to the question.
—Order! Senator Crowley did, in fact, refer to the Medicare rebate in the last part of her answer. I ask her to continue.

—It is quite clear that the Opposition does not understand what this screening program is about; I hope I have now made it clear. If it is a question about Medicare rebates, it properly belongs to Minister Richardson. If it is a question about a screening program, then I have responsibility for that. I hope I am making it clear what the mammogram screening program is about. Indeed, 200,000 women have already been screened, and the numbers who actually are attending for screening have risen from 6,500 per month to over 11,000 per month.

—Mr President, I raise a point of order. I am sure that everybody in the Senate, bar Senator Crowley, understands that she is not answering the question. I ask you to draw her attention to it. Pleading for sympathy by asking that the question be directed to Senator Richardson is not the answer.
—I can only say once again, as I have already said, that the screening program, the mammogram program, allows for women—
—Order! Senator Crowley, are you speaking to the point of order or not?
—No, Mr President.
—Then I ask you to be relevant.

—I am sorry. I have already explained that a screening program means that the women who apply for the screening program, who join it of their own choice or by their doctors recommending they go, attend that program at no cost to themselves. There are women who can attend a screening program by referral from their doctor in which case they will be eligible, under certain criteria, for a Medicare rebate number. But I am now being asked to answer what properly belongs in the area of responsibility of the Minister for Health. There is no cost if one is on a screening program.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I will give the Minister a hint. Of course, the relevance to her portfolio is that Senator Crowley stood up here and gave advice to all Australian women over the age of 50 to have mammograms. The question is whether her Government's policy reflects that advice. Is it not the case that only women who have been referred to a doctor as a result of evidence of some abnormality or, alternatively, women who have a history of breast cancer in the family can, in fact, under her Government's policy, receive a Medicare rebate? If that is the case, why does not the Government implement policies that, in effect, reflect and support the advice that she gives?

—Mr President, quite clearly Senator Hill was not listening to what I said. I have just said that a screening program provides this service at no cost to the women. If they want to undergo a screening process and their doctor requests it, and they are eligible under the criteria, as I have already said and as Senator Hill has then trawled over again, they will be eligible for a Medicare rebate. The whole process is to address the question of screening. Senator Hill has just misunderstood what it is about.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Science and Small Business. I understand that Senator Ray will be answering the question. What income has the CSIRO received by way of consultancy fees for acid sulphate soil assessments prepared by the division of soils for the Camden Shores residential canal development and the Micalo Island tourist development on the north coast of New South Wales? Has the CSIRO refused to release the results of these studies on the grounds of commercial-in-confidence? Has the CSIRO also refused to release these reports as required by the New South Wales Environment and Planning Assessment Act? This is the important point: if the answer to parts 2 and 3 of my question is yes, does not the combination of substantial fees and refusal to publicly release the reports give justified cause for concern over possible compromise of scientific objectivity and integrity? Finally, short of releasing these reports, can the Minister suggest any alternative mechanism for ensuring public trust in the scientific independence of the CSIRO?

—In answer to part 1 of Senator Coulter's five-part question, current estimates indicate that the CSIRO was paid approximately $25,000 over the last three financial years. The short answer to the second part of his question is no. A condition of these studies was that the results would be available to both the client and to the Hastings Municipal Council and the Maclean Shire Council respectively. The results were released as part of the environmental impact statements tabled at the New South Wales commissions of inquiry into both proposed developments.

PARA.TAB: The Dunbogan-Camden Shores report was submitted to the Hastings Municipal Council in March 1992 by the Planning Workshop, who were consultants. It was also made available to all parties at the inquiry. The Micalo Island report was tabled as an appendix to the EIS submitted to the Maclean Shire Council and to the New South Wales Department of Planning.

In respect of the third part of the honourable senator's question, the results were presented by the CSIRO to the consultants who had engaged CSIRO, and then released by the consultants through the official channels indicated above. The answer to part 4 of the question is no. The results were tabled at the inquiry and the CSIRO officer involved was present. He presented results, provided detailed explanation and responded to questions from interested parties. As honourable senators will follow from that, part 5 of the question is made irrelevant by the answers to the first four parts of the question.

TALK.START.PARA: —Does the Minister for Transport and Communications believe that air safety standards have been reduced? Does the Terrell report into air safety justify a concern that standards have fallen? Why did the Civil Aviation Authority chairman, Alan Butcher, only provide the CAA board with a sanitised version of the Terrell report?
—It is Ted, actually.
—And why can the full report not be made public as suggested by the author? Yes, it is Ted.

—The first thing that needs to be made clear is that the report was prepared by a study group which was led by Mr Terrell. In fact, the report does not contain the conclusions that it is alleged it does contain: that there has been a reduction in safety standards. That assertion is made in a letter which Mr Terrell in his own capacity sent directly to the chairman of the CAA.
—He ought to know.

—It is important to make that distinction because Mr Terrell was not the only person involved in the preparation of the report and it does not contain that conclusion. The report does raise issues that are being very seriously considered by the board of the Civil Aviation Authority and me. The CAA set up to investigate the problems raised by the report.

PARA.TAB: Another point that needs to be made is that the report came about as a result of it being commissioned by the CAA board. It was a board initiative which caused this evaluation to occur in the first place, which, of course, has been totally overlooked.

The CAA board established a number of working groups to investigate the concerns raised in the report. Those working group reports are now close to completion, and the CAA board is to receive the preliminary findings of those working groups today. The final draft of the report is scheduled to be completed by the 31st of this month. Consultation with industry by the CAA, including the ALAEA, unions and staff, will occur in the first two weeks of June prior to consideration by the board at its 30 June meeting.

For Senator Bishop's advice, the working groups include 12 Australian Aviation Industry Association and union representatives who are fully participating in this process and have access to all material available to management, including the annexes to the Terrell report. I have also asked the CAA personally to seek advice from an outside consultant on the effectiveness of the proposed action plans finalised by the working groups, and this has been done. I am proposing to hold a meeting of the major interested parties, which I will chair myself, to discuss the future direction for aviation safety regulation as soon as possible upon completion of the action plans, the consideration by the CAA staff, industry and all other interested parties, including the ALAEA.

The reason I have laid all that out for Senator Bishop—and this is important—is that all of that information was contained in a letter which I sent to the ALAEA on 18 May. I have had a number of personal meetings with representatives of the LAMEs. I have met with the LAME representatives and with Mr Terrell himself. Following that meeting, I wrote to the licensed aircraft maintenance engineers in the manner that I have just laid out. I proposed in that letter that I would personally chair a meeting of all interested parties, including industry representatives, so that the matter can be brought to a resolution which is satisfactory to everyone.

I have reiterated all those offers in a letter which I sent to the licensed aircraft engineers yesterday. I am pleased that they elected to remove their industrial action last night. I have been advised that they are now considering my further offer yesterday to chair this meeting. I also provided them with a precise timetable as to when the CAA will complete its investigation of the Terrell report. I think that that is without question a satisfactory manner in which to address these very important issues that are currently being considered by the board of the CAA and by the Government.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. The Minister has tap-danced his way very nicely around the pay television issues. In the interests of safety, I seek leave of the Senate to table, for its information and that of the general public, the letters from Alan Terrell to the chairman of the CAA, including his statement that in his view safety has been damaged or weakened, a copy of the letters from Qantas and Ansett to Mr Butcher expressing concern about the lessening of safety standards, CAA's response, minutes of meetings between the CAA, Ansett, Qantas and others, various letters from the licensed engineers union and a report of the study group in toto with all appendices attached. I seek leave to table that document in the public interest.
—There is no supplementary question. Is leave granted?
—No, Mr President. The normal courtesies of showing it to us in advance have not been observed.

—I raise a point of order, Mr President. I could seek leave and could stand here and read this document into the record. I will seek to take note of the answer at the end of Question Time, because it is in the public interest that the documents be on the public record.

—My question is also directed to the Minister for Transport and Communications. I refer to the Warehouse to wharf report from the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Transport, Communications and Infrastructure into the efficiency of the interface between seaports and land transport. The report emphasised the importance of electronic data interchange technology in improving the efficiency of waterfront services. Can the Minister advise of any recent developments in the expansion of electronic data interchange technology in the transport sector?

—The development of electronic data interchange, or EDI, in the waterfront industry is a vital element in improving the overall coordination and interaction of all of the participants in the transport chain. This was highlighted in the Warehouse to wharf report, which recommended the establishment of a national consultative group on EDI to accelerate and coordinate the spread of EDI in the transport sector. It is very impressive to actually have a look at what has been done in the Australian industry just over the past few years with things such as brokerage insurance and so on. In previous years this took a mass of paperwork. The entire transaction can now be completed just by tapping it all out on a keyboard. So there has already been tremendous progress made by industry particularly in providing these EDI services.

PARA.TAB: The group that I have just referred to was established late last year. It comprises high level representatives from the relevant Commonwealth and private sector organisations. It has already undertaken a preliminary study of the current state of EDI in the transport sector, identifying any impediments to its implementation and examining possible solutions. Progress is also being made in the alignment of EDI systems between Commonwealth agencies, and of course the major agency that already accesses this EDI system is Customs.

The Australian Quarantine and Inspection Service is ensuring that its electronic transfer of export documentation is developed in line with the Australian Customs Service system that I have just mentioned. Similarly, for imported cargo, both AQIS and ACS are committed to an integrated clearance process whereby both agencies present a common point of entry and exit for importers. Already over 95 per cent of import entries are now lodged and paid for electronically.

A further initiative will allow cargo manifests to be sent electronically to Customs, which will then direct copies electronically to port authorities and to the quarantine service, and subsequently issue a joint ACS-AQIS clearance through a single electronic message. This system is very good. Might I just say that under the old system that existed only a few years ago it could take up to 100 separate paper transactions to get a container into and out of an Australian port. So a tremendous amount of progress has already been made to obviate all of that.

The system that I have just referred to, which is called sea cargo automation, is currently undergoing trials in the port of Brisbane. The ultimate aim is to have a completely paperless trading system. This will produce considerable direct cost savings and greatly improved service levels to waterfront users. In fact, I would like to be able to table documents in this Parliament on a floppy disk—if I could put in a quick bid for that—instead of having to lug them into the chamber.

The Warehouse to wharf inquiry estimated that 40 million documents related to import and export of cargo were generated annually in Australia. As I have said, a single import process was found to involve up to 100 separate pieces of paper. Any reduction in this paper mountain would be a welcome improvement for the trading community in Australia. However, the inquiry also highlighted the vital role of the private sector in addressing inefficiencies at the port-land interface. The adoption of EDI technology places the primary onus on users of waterfront related services to adopt this new technology and make the necessary investment in computer equipment and software to access the system, thereby realising the full benefits to all users of the system.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Family Services and the Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women. How many drugs have been approved by the Therapeutic Goods Administration for use in Australia by both men and women, and yet have been approved for public subsidy under the pharmaceutical benefits scheme for men only? Is this action by the Minister consistent with the policy of the Government in relation to sexual discrimination? When the same drug is used for both men and women, how can the Minister justify a situation where a man need pay only $15 for a subsidised drug which can cost a woman in excess of $400?
—Mr President, this seems to be a matter of considerable gravity and importance. I will take that on notice and get a serious answer to the honourable senator as soon as I can.

—My question is directed to the Minister for the Arts and Administrative Services. This year, 1993, has been designated the International Year of the World's Indigenous People. What is DAAS doing to help Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people?

—A number of programs that officially come under the broader head of the Department of the Arts and Administrative Services are of particular relevance to Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people. I want to talk about one in particular in response to Senator Child's question. Most senators here would be aware of things like the Electoral Commission's electoral information service, which is very important in a democracy.
—Particularly for the Labor Party.
—I know that the honourable senator hates the fact that Aboriginal people vote, and I know that some of his colleagues here have spent a lot of their time trying to conspire to stop them.
—I have a point of order, Mr President. I think it goes without saying that that was a reflection on the integrity and the views of Senator Macdonald. I ask that that be withdrawn.
—Order! Unparliamentary language is constantly being used in interjections across the chamber. I chose to ignore it so that Question Time will run properly.
—On a point of order, Mr Deputy President, I do not choose to ignore that remark; I am quite offended by it. I think that your action in choosing to ignore it is equally—
—Order! I ask Senator McMullan to withdraw the remark.

—If honourable senators opposite are offended by what I have said, I withdraw it. If they had heard what I was about to say, they would have been much more offended. The point that arises from Senator Macdonald's interjection is that if what I said is not true—and I have withdrawn that statement—it is true that it is a significant cause of concern, obviously, to some people in the Opposition that the democratic process is discharged properly, and that is that all Australian citizens, irrespective of their standard of education or where they live—
—Have a look at some of the rorts perpetuated by the Labor Party up there.
—Order! Senator Macdonald will cease interjecting. If he interjects again, I will name him.

—are equally entitled to exercise their franchise. Even if they decide at the end of the day that they do not want to vote for Senator Macdonald, it does not take away their democratic right to vote. It probably indicates the quality of the judgment they are making.

PARA.TAB: But I do not want particularly to talk about the electoral commission.
