I assume that everybody here would know about that, as they would know about the important things that are done for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people in the arts part of the portfolio through things like Bran Nue Dae and the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander arts committee, which is about to become a board.

I particularly want to talk about those things which Purchase Australia is doing. That body develops Commonwealth purchasing policy and provides advice to government buyers and suppliers. As a response to the report of the Royal Commission into Aboriginal Deaths in Custody, which made recommendations about improving employment opportunities for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people through Commonwealth purchasing, initiatives have been taken to increase opportunities for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people to participate in the award of Commonwealth contracts for construction and associated works in their communities. Throughout 1993 policies will be publicised designed to ensure that Commonwealth buyers and suppliers to communities are aware of policies and contribute to their implementation, when appropriate. There are a number of other areas, but it is important that that area is emphasised.

I thought that the other area of the department to which I started to refer earlier, in relation to the electoral commission, would have had the unanimous support of this Parliament, as its functions undoubtedly assist in the proper discharge of the democratic responsibility of any government. I am disappointed to find that it does not; nevertheless, I enthusiastically support it.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister representing the Treasurer to a question that I put to the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration last Friday dealing with the issue of the bringing forward of tax return lodgment deadlines for registered tax agents. Given that this new deadline is expected to raise an extra $25 million, can the Minister give an assurance that the precipitous reduction in the time available to tax agents to process returns is not the result of the Government pressurising the ATO, either explicitly or implicitly, to increase revenue collections for this financial year because of the problems with the Budget deficit? Given this new time frame, will the Government also give an assurance that the Tax Office will, as in previous years, provide extra time to pay 85 per cent of tax payable due 28 days after the end of the year of income?

—I acknowledge that Senator Watson has a question on notice with regard to this matter, the answer to which will be tabled shortly. Notwithstanding that and whatever the consequences may be for Standing Orders, it is an issue of concern. It was publicised in this morning's Financial Review. It may have caused some misunderstanding or misapprehension, so I am happy to respond to the matter here and now.

PARA.TAB: In respect of the first important question, which Senator Watson invites me explicitly to respond to, the Government has not sought to influence the Taxation Office in the discharge of its responsibilities in this way. As Senator Watson and most senators would be aware, the Commissioner has a clear discretion in these administrative matters. I am advised that this action is not the response of any attempt by the Treasurer or other Ministers to influence the Taxation Office in this way. My advice is that the Tax Office proposal stems from its responsibility to collect revenue as soon as practicable on or after the due date set by the law. The timely lodgment of tax returns is a critical part of this cash flow management responsibility, one in which tax agents have a major role to play.

Accepting that return preparation and processing volumes need to be managed, the Tax Office has for many years had lodgment programs in place for tax agents, as Senator Watson would know. This year the Tax Office has noted that the flow of returns from agents was unevenly compressed into the last stages of the program, regardless of agreements with the profession that returns would be lodged progressively. Delayed lodgment of returns can cause significant slippage of collections. Bringing forward the final dates for agent lodgment is a way of addressing this slippage. It is an initiative which the Tax Office has taken in response to these concerns which have come to its attention and which appear to be contrary to agreements with the profession.

The article in this morning's Financial Review that related to this matter missed the important point that the Tax Office letter referred to was canvassing alternatives to the `bring forward' proposal from members of the Tax Office's peak professional consultative body, the national tax liaison group. The letter proposed meetings with the profession during the next few weeks to discuss any alternatives. By definition, these meetings have yet to occur. So final decisions on the 1993-94 agent lodgment program have not yet been taken. They will be taken after that consultation of which the letter is the catalyst.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I know the Minister is aware of the difficulties that tax agents will have in meeting this new deadline. This bringing forward of the deadline, in effect, represents the compaction to one month of the time now required by registered tax agents to lodge returns within the space of a two-year period. Is he aware of that difficulty? What can he do to ameliorate the problem?

—Obviously, any change in the lodgment process at short notice would cause difficulty to agents who had previously arranged a work program, although, if the work program was leading to the sorts of outcomes that I am advised the Tax Office was concerned about, they should not be surprised if there is some response. The most important response to Senator Watson's point is that, if there are substantial concerns—and it is quite possible that there would be—the meetings and consultation which the Tax Office proposes to have with the profession during the next few weeks should enable a 1993-94 program to be developed which obviates the worst of those problems, although it is a matter for discussion between the Commissioner and his representatives and the profession.
—Mr President, I ask that further questions be placed on the Notice Paper.

—On 19 May I was asked a question by Senator Chapman regarding CAA board approval of a new airspace system. I have a detailed response for Senator Chapman, and I seek leave to incorporate it in Hansard.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.
The answer read as follows—
The CAA Board approved the implementation of an ICAO based airspace model at its meeting on 31 March 1993.

This approval follows the most extensive period of industry consultation ever undertaken by the Authority. As a consequence of this consultation, the model as now refined, is supported by the full range of industry users.

Australia has for over 20 years, been operating jet aircraft flights into uncontrolled aerodromes without separation, in other words, with no Air Traffic Control. Since December 1991, such operations have also been conducted without a directed traffic information service about Visual Flight Rules (VFR) flights, such as those often involving general aviation aircraft.

Under the airspace model, all aircraft operating at Mandatory Traffic Advisory Frequency (MTAF) locations, such as Yulara, will be required to make mandatory radio broadcasts. This will provide jet airline aircraft operating at these locations with traffic advice about all aircraft operations. By comparison, overseas practice usually limits traffic advisories to Instrument Flight Rules (IFR) flights, rather than IFR and VFR.

The use of MTAF procedures is subject to additional consultation with the industry through the Authority's Aviation Regulatory Proposal system. The CAA is satisfied that the airspace classifications that will be introduced in November 1993 will achieve the necessary balance to preserve air safety whilst containing costs to the flying public.

TALKER.NAME: Senator GARETH EVANS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Foreign Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —In accordance with my statement to this chamber last Wednesday, 19 May, I now table the `Register of Senators' Interests' forms of all government senators. It should be noted that Senate Ministers' returns are submitted on the form that has been used in the House of Representatives for some years now, in accordance with the practice established there by the Government for all Ministers. As I indicated at the time of my statement, the Senate will be debating this whole subject in the first week of the Budget sittings. In the meantime, I invite honourable senators from other parts of the chamber to follow the government senators' example.
—Does not the Minister need leave to table those documents? They did not arise out of a question or a statement by the Minister.
—As I understand it, I do not need leave.
—From what I understand, the Minister did not require leave. He could have tabled the documents at any time during the procedures.

TALKER.NAME: Senator HILL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—The Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Gareth Evans) has engaged in a political gimmick. If it were the wish of this Government, the Senate could have debated the motion that the Government put on the Notice Paper to set in place a process for the tabling of such declarations. The Government chose not to do that; it chose to spend the first fortnight of this sitting session on other procedural matters. It was therefore not a matter of high priority according to the Government.

PARA.TAB: Senator Evans, presumably having received a word or two from the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) at the start of this week, came in and said, `This must be done all of a sudden, and I will adopt this particular gimmick of inviting you to fill in the form that I send to you'. It would be equally ridiculous of us to expect him to fill in a form that we might send to him setting out a form of disclosure. But, of course, we would not engage in such ridiculous behaviour.

The Minister has said that at the start of the next session he will ensure that this matter is debated by the Senate and brought to a conclusion. Why could it not have been handled in that way in order that the Senate could determine what form of disclosure it requires and we could therefore all act according to an order of the Senate? Our problem in relation to the Minister's form is well known: it simply does not work. It did not work in relation to the Prime Minister. We leant nothing about the Prime Minister's real business interests in relation to—what was it?—a half million dollar investment in a pig farm in the form of disclosure that the Minister brings to us and asks us to voluntarily enter into.

The Opposition is not prepared to be a party to the Minister's gimmick. We are prepared to be a party and look forward to the proper debate of this matter, if the Government regards it of sufficient importance to bring to the Senate, in the Budget session. Presumably, it will then be carried through to a proper resolution. But we will not be part of this silly little bit of political gimmickry that the Minister brings to us today.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bishop Sen B.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister for Transport and Communications (Senator Collins), in response to a question without notice asked by Senator Bishop this day, relating to a report into air safety standards commissioned by the Civil Aviation Authority.

SPEECH.PARA: The answer that Senator Collins gave to my question earlier today would have left people who were listening to that question with the opinion that safety with regard to air traffic and aviation in a general sense had not been diminished. I attempted to table the documentation. The Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Gareth Evans) declined to allow me to do so, saying that the courtesy of letting the Government see the documentation had not been observed. I would point out that that was quite needless as the Minister has all the documentation. He has the letter, for instance, from Captain Alan Terrell which says:
Thank you for your letter . . . of 6 April enclosing the unconfirmed minute of the Board discussion regarding the report on SR&S which I Chaired.
If I may be permitted to comment now, as I could not comment on the report to the Board when presented: there are three specific points I would like to make.
In an addendum to this letter, Captain Terrell says:
The main report did not specifically address the question of safety as it was not included in the terms of reference.
Convenient. He continues:
I did make some mention of it, however, in the draft Board paper but again, made that comment as innocuously as possible.

It is in my opinion, however, a fact that safety standards/levels have been reduced so that they are closer to the regulated margins. It would be most surprising if this were not so, as in essence what has occurred is that the industry has been deregulated, the Authority has been commercialised, policy has insisted on devolution wherever possible and delegation where this can be controlled, and the country is experiencing a major economic downturn, all at the same time.
Summing all that up, standards are certainly lower, the essence of the argument would be: are they too low?
The entire document deals with the question of whether or not those standards are too low. I refer again to the letter that was sent to the Minister in April:

. . . , roman numeral ii) of the Board's resolution points out that there was no conclusion with regard to air safety in the report. This is true, however I referred specifically to this aspect in my letter to you of 30 March . . .
That was an extract of the letter I was reading from. It continues:

. . . , as I assume from the minute that the Board did not see this letter. These extracts clearly show that I believe safety has been `damaged' or `weakened' . . . but that felt it was better not said in the main report.

I have heard suggestions that I am `crying wolf' in regard to safety. May I assure you my comments are based on a selective analysis of comments we all received and as a consequence, the Board resolution does not reflect the totality of my comments to it.
Thirdly, the composition of the working groups has been delegated to Management, however I personally believe the exclusion of the ALAEA—
that is, the body of licensed engineers who called yesterday's strike—
on the basis that they are not "a union having industrial coverage of the Division" could be unfortunate if this is the intention. They are certainly part of the industry.

In other words, this entire document, which I believe the public is entitled to see, is a catalogue of complaints about the Civil Aviation Authority. It is a statement by and large which says that in the bid to commercialise safety—that is, to put a price on safety—people's lives are being put in jeopardy.

PARA.TAB: Also contained in this documentation is a report, to which my colleague Senator Boswell referred yesterday, concerning the incident that occurred in Brisbane, where an engine caught fire. It was a fiasco of ineptitude, largely because there was no planning to coordinate all the services that were needed for such an incident.
Again today we have a report out of Sydney that a KLM flight had to abort its landing because a truck was left on the runway.

TALK.START.PARA: —Ha, ha!
—It is not funny, Minister.
—It wasn't a truck.

—It was on the runway, Minister. The report states that the Bureau of Air Safety Investigation may know later today why a truck was left parked on the Sydney airport runway as a passenger jet came in to land last night. The KLM Boeing 747 jet aborted its landing and circled the airport while the vehicle was removed. Again and again we are seeing incidents where the loss of life is getting closer. I again seek leave to table this document.(Time expired)

—Mr Acting Deputy President, on the question of leave: I remind Senator Bishop that the practice which has always applied in this place is that if honourable senators want to table something or incorporate something by leave it should be shown to the Minister on the front bench. TALK.START.PARA: —The evidence in relation to the safety of the Australian aviation system that has been placed before the Senate this afternoon is of the utmost gravity. For some years now I have been warning, in a responsible way, about a diminution of standards in the Australian aviation industry. I have been very heavily ridiculed by Senator Collins and Senator Schacht. I do not mind that because my shoulders are broad enough to put up with any irresponsible comments from those sorts of people. Nevertheless, the issue is an enormously serious one.

PARA.TAB: The evidence of a diminution of standards with respect to safety has been in the public arena since the airline pilots dispute in 1989-90. I will be very clear on this point: I am not saying that the pilots strike was in any way at all the cause of the diminution; it just illustrated the shortcomings that were becoming apparent. It is very important to ask why safety in Australia has collapsed or is running down. There are many reasons for this but basically it stems from the Civil Aviation Authority, the successor to the Department of Civil Aviation, taking the wrong approach at the instigation of the Government.

We have had the doctrine of affordable safety under which somehow we measure safety not in terms of lives lost but in terms of statistics—that is, if not as many people are killed in aeroplanes as are killed in buses, we are wasting money by setting excessive safety standards for aircraft. We have had a perverted view of the user pays doctrine which tries to argue that there is no public interest in transport at all, particularly in aviation, and because the community gets no benefit at all, everyone who flies must pay the whole cost. That has perverted the safety standards.

Safety is a cultural thing. It is not just a simple set of rules; it is a state of mind. Safety is something that perfuses the whole of the industry. It takes years—generations—to build up. That is why when things start to go wrong they do not necessarily go wrong overnight. It is why we do not necessarily have a great disaster once things start to go bad. But it is terribly important at this stage that we review what is happening.

This matter was triggered off by a report made by Captain Terrell, a former board member of the Civil Aviation Authority. He was without doubt the most experienced airman on the CAA board—a board that has been quite noticeable for its lack of knowledge and personal experience of the area in which it is dealing; namely, the aviation industry.

Captain Terrell has reported as a member of a committee and in a private capacity to the Minister, voicing his alarms. Coming from a person like that, the Senate must take note of those concerns. Just to illustrate the point, the general aviation accident record in Australia shows a pattern of continuing deterioration. It is I think, off the top of my head, twice as bad as it is in the United States, despite the fact that we have a far better climate and far less traffic density. What we are dealing with here is the application of wrong and incorrect policies.

We have had from the Minister a very arrogant defence of his department and an absolute refusal to recognise that something might be wrong. We have seen the Civil Aviation Authority introduce massive changes with respect to air space. There has been advertisement of those changes but there has been no education campaign mounted. There is no way pilots in the recreational or the general aviation sector, apart from those flying for hire and reward, can know what the rules are now because the publications are not there. The face-to-face briefing has been abandoned.

The Macphee report on the inquiry into the TAATS aviation contract which was tabled in December last year showed that the board was collectively incompetent on a grand scale, and the Government still keeps the board in office. It now looks as if the chairman of the board, Mr Butcher, is going to slip gracefully away instead of being fired. I think that is outrageous. This is the man who approved six-figure payments for people like Baldwin and Edwards, who were found in this report to be culpable of gross incompetence in the management of their affairs. They depart, courtesy of Mr Butcher, with huge separation payments when they had to go because of their incompetence.
But the matter that is before us is the need for the Minister to put aside his preferences. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —I support the comments of my colleague Senator MacGibbon. Most of us in this place are involved in extensive flying. I was a passenger in an aircraft which attempted on four occasions to land at Launceston airport but, because of fog, the first three attempts were unsuccessful. Obviously, the sort of information that ought be available to the pilot as to the height of the fog ceiling and its density, et cetera, is not available any longer.

PARA.TAB: I think that all of us have had these sorts of personal experiences and that adds to the concerns about the standard of safety and the lack of personnel available to give information about such things as height of fog ceiling, its density and so on. I can tell honourable senators that it is not very comforting to be a passenger in such a situation; one has a feeling of concern when it takes four attempts to land an aircraft.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Transport and Communications)

TALK.START.PARA: —There is one really essential point that needs to be made here. I was the Minister who appointed Captain Alan Terrell. It was deliberately done by me, and I think Senator MacGibbon knows that. I deeply regret—and I am very sincere about this, as my office will attest—that Alan Terrell is no longer a member of that board. I am very sorry indeed that, for reasons entirely unconnected with his board activities, he is no longer a member of the board.

PARA.TAB: I appointed Captain Alan Terrell personally to the board of the CAA. At the time that I appointed Captain Terrell—and I might add that I received the full cooperation and support of the senior management in CAA and the chairman of the board; not that it was required, but I did—I spoke to the board of the CAA. I indicated to it that the most effective way of utilising Captain Terrell's experience—which I freely acknowledge Senator MacGibbon has correctly stated—his high reputation in the industry and his long-time experience as a senior captain with one of the major airlines in Australia was in fact to put him in charge of a safety subcommittee of the board, and that was done.

I simply say to senators, because I think it is important, that I am looking high and low at the moment—and I tell senators that it is hard—to find a board replacement for Captain Terrell, who I am still actively involved in discussion with on this issue, who has the same level of expertise as Captain Terrell. I particularly appointed him for that purpose and to set up a safety subcommittee of the board, which he chaired very well. The reason that I make that point is that it is a direct result of that appointment by me of Captain Terrell, and his role in chairing that safety subcommittee that was established, that the board of the CAA initiated this report. It is not a report which has been forced down the throats of the CAA board by Captain Terrell, as he himself will acknowledge; it was an initiative of the board that the review be undertaken and I am glad it was.

In conclusion, the CAA board is moving, and properly moving, expeditiously to properly consider—in full consultation with the industry, the unions and with its management—the Terrell report. I gave that advice earlier today in Question Time. The working group's draft reports are being considered by the board today and the final reports will be completed at the end of this month. All of that information has been provided by me to the licensed aircraft maintenance engineers. In addition to that, as a direct response to the representations they made personally to me at meetings that I had with them, I have in writing proposed to personally chair a round table meeting of all the participants, after the CAA's consideration of this issue, to bring this matter to a successful resolution.

I conclude by saying that I will complete expeditiously my examination of the documents that Senator Bishop wishes to table, but I have already picked up, just in glancing through them, a number of comments made in terms of the anecdotal evidence that has been provided that would concern me in that they appear to be potentially defamatory. I am simply saying that I have picked that up already and I will have a closer examination of the documents when I leave the chamber. But I do not want parliamentary privilege to be abused in the sense that anecdotal evidence, which I have picked up on two or three pages already, may be damaging of people's reputations and therefore be protected.

I make the final point that the board is taking Captain Terrell's report seriously, but Captain Terrell went at large into an organisation which has just gone through a great deal of change. I say without hesitation that I support people like Senator MacGibbon who over the years have publicly demanded that change, long overdue.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thought this was to be a brief statement.
—I will conclude on this point. That change is long overdue, but when change is introduced into any organisation there are always people who will resist that change.
—Mr Acting Deputy President, I raise a point of order. Under standing order 190, I seek leave to make a personal explanation on the grounds that I have been misrepresented.
—You can seek leave after the question has been put, Senator MacGibbon.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tambling Sen G.E.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —This matter is of major importance. In perusing some of the issues that the Minister for Transport and Communications (Senator Collins) has under consideration, and in looking at the evidence, he refers to what he considers to be anecdotal evidence in some of the correspondence. But equally I would draw the Minister's attention to some of the very important stuff that is contained in this file that is very important for the public record.

PARA.TAB: In particular, I would draw to the Minister's attention a letter, a copy of which he received—by CC, I note—dated 6 April 1993. Importantly, this letter is from Qantas. It is from Captain R. Heinecke, the Acting Deputy Chief Executive, Operations. Following a briefing, Captain Heinecke writes to Mr Butcher stating:

SPEECH.PARA: It is of particular concern to us—
I would point out that that is senior officers of the Qantas group—

that differences exist between the proposed course of action suggested by the study group and the action proposed by your Acting Chief Executive. In respect of task force composition, for example, the study group recommends that each task force would contain appropriate experts from industry et cetera. However, the Acting Chief Executive has seemingly decided that the industry will not be involved and outside consultations will be used as nominated by the working group chairman.
Further on in the letter, and I draw this to Senator Collins's attention, Captain Heinecke says:

The very creditability of, and industry confidence in, the safety regulation and standards division is in serious jeopardy. Unless this is properly and effectively addressed there could be serious industrial implications and an erosion of public confidence when the facts of the report are made public.

It is very concerning that the Minister is now hedging and delaying, and is not prepared to face the decent action that he ought to take. I am absolutely astounded that in the last division the Australian Democrats were equally prepared to walk away from their responsibility in this matter. They did not even seek to acquaint themselves, very obviously, with the important issues that are to hand and need now to be very carefully addressed.

PARA.TAB: Question resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to speak under standing order 190. The Minister claimed that I did not understand that he appointed Captain Terrell. I understand that very well and I also understand that he called for that safety report. What concerns me is that all of us on this side of the chamber believe that Captain Terrell's committee's report went to the board and the chairman then edited that report and sanitised it—took 16 or more pages out of it—before it got wider distribution. That is our concern, because we do not want a chairman with Mr Butcher's track record interfering with an independent report.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walters Sen M.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister for Family Services (Senator Crowley), in response to a question without notice asked by the Leader of the Opposition in the Senate (Senator Hill) this day, relating to Medicare rebates on mammograms.

SPEECH.PARA: Earlier today in Question Time Senator Crowley said that the Government was encouraging all women over 50 to have a mammogram every two years. She was questioned about that by Senator Hill who pointed out that, as a general rule, mammograms performed on women of any age do not get a Medicare rebate. A specific reason for having a mammogram done is required before a woman is entitled to a Medicare rebate.

PARA.TAB: Senator Crowley went on to speak about the screening programs. Those screening programs are very few and far between. I am not complaining about that at all because I believe that these screening programs must be set up very carefully. The people who read the mammograms must be experienced people. So far as I am aware, the screening programs are set up only in capital cities. For instance, we have only one in Tasmania, although others are coming. I am not suggesting for one moment that the setting up of these screening programs ought to be rushed, because we need well experienced people to read the screens. I believe if we do not have those experienced people it could be even more dangerous than not having the screenings done at all.

It is totally irresponsible of Senator Crowley to stand up here and say that all women over 50 should have mammograms done every two years, while at the same time her Government prohibits a Medicare rebate for those women. It is about time that Senator Crowley became aware of the restrictions that her Government is putting on women over 50. She is correct to pursue the pap smears issue because women are entitled to Medicare rebates for pap smears. However, at present women are not entitled to Medicare rebates for mammograms and, of course, they should be.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—The Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs has two references, which were referred to it during previous parliaments, which it wishes to continue with during this Parliament. On 10 May 1989 the Senate gave the committee terms of reference requiring that the committee inquire into the cost of legal services and litigation. The committee has already produced one report in connection with this inquiry and a further six reports are in preparation. The committee has decided that it will continue with this most important and wide-ranging inquiry. Honourable senators will be pleased to know that the detailed results of the committee's inquiries will become progressively available over the remainder of this year.

PARA.TAB: The committee has also decided that it will continue with its inquiry into the operations and effectiveness of the Financial Transaction Reports Act 1988, formerly the Cash Transaction Reports Act. This matter was referred to the committee on 12 May 1992. The committee will report on this inquiry by 30 September 1993.
People may be concerned to know why I have said those words. They have been written out for me, and they act magically to reactivate those reports. It was a worthwhile little effort.

TALKER.NAME: Senator HILL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I want to make a statement in relation to the Minister for Transport and Communications (Senator Collins) seeking further advice from his department on the document relating to aviation safety that Senator Bishop sought to table. We intend to pursue that matter. Senator Collins said that he would require half an hour to decide whether leave could be granted. Nearly an hour has now passed. He has refused leave but he did so on the basis that he is unable to decide whether he will grant leave.

PARA.TAB: I do not think it should take any longer than this for him to get the advice of his department as to whether such leave should be granted. It is an important matter; it is a matter in the public interest. If Senator Collins wants to come in here and argue that it is not in the public interest that this document be tabled, we look forward to the argument that he might put in support of such a proposition. But if he is not prepared to do that, he should grant leave.

We will wait perhaps another half an hour or so and then seek to bring up this matter again. If necessary, we shall seek to suspend the Standing Orders in order to avoid the need for leave. The Australian Democrats have a copy of the documents that we are seeking to table, so they will have time to decide whether, on the merits, they should support the tabling of these documents, which we assert in the strongest terms is in the public interest.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bourne Sen V.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the document.

SPEECH.PARA: I will make only a very short statement on this report at this stage because I look forward to making a longer statement when the time becomes available to me. This delegation, the second Australian human rights delegation to China, had substantially the same membership as the first delegation; there were only a couple of changes.

PARA.TAB: I believe that a very good way to run a delegation, particularly to somewhere such as China, is to have a comprehensive mix of parliamentarians with an interest in human rights and foreign affairs and experts in different aspects of the country visited. Professor Tay is a particular expert in the field of Chinese law and knows a lot more about Chinese law than many of the officials that we met. Mr Chris Sidoti is an expert in human rights and human rights documents, such as the UN human rights document. He is currently with the Australian Law Reform Commission but he was previously secretary of the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission.

Many good people from the Department of Foreign Affairs were involved in the delegation. The calibre of the people who went on this visit says volumes about how good our Department of Foreign Affairs is. We were told frequently that Dr Richard Rigby's Mandarin is better than that of most Chinese. We had Mr Ian Russell from the human rights section; Mr Kevin Garratt, who was seconded to Foreign Affairs, speaks Tibetan and is an expert in Tibetan culture; Ms Dilber Thwaites, who speaks Uigur—she is Uigurian—and is an expert in Uigur culture; and Mr Stephen Huang, our first secretary, political, from the Australian Embassy in Beijing.

We were not in China for a very long time; we were there for 12 days this time. But we did get out to Xinjiang in the far west of the country. It was very different from anything we had seen before. We have frequently been asked about whether Xinjiang is similar to Tibet in that it is full of minority populations and there are more and more Han going in there every day. That is true, but I found the atmosphere in Xinjiang very different to that of Tibet.

In Tibet I found the atmosphere very difficult, very repressed. There were many members of the Chinese military holding guns and prepared to use them whereas Xinjiang, although there is some institutionalised repression which is detailed in the report, is a much more open place and is well and truly the centre of central Asia. The Kashgar market is very large. It is not just people from China who go there but people from all over central Asia.

It was a very interesting trip. We met some fascinating people. I would like to thank all of the Chinese officials, who were very helpful to us. I would like to thank the people from the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade, in particular our embassy staff in Beijing and Hong Kong, who were excellent. I will make a much fuller statement on this when it is debated under ministerial statements in August.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —This report of the second Australian human rights delegation to China is markedly different from the first report. Any objective study comparing the two reports would have to conclude that something had happened between the departure of the first delegation and the departure of the second delegation. This report is far more detailed and is based on much more actual information and evidence than was the previous report.

PARA.TAB: I am disappointed that the Senate does not have the opportunity today to deal at length with the report and with the ministerial response thereto. Our relationship with the People's Republic of China is a very important and grave question of public policy. It is important that we are conscious of the gross violations of human rights in China when consideration is given to the pursuit of most favoured nation trading conditions with the PRC.

I have time to deal with just two matters. The committee deals in rather philosophical terms with the issues of human rights and the different interpretations that are placed on human rights in China by the PRC as compared with those placed on human rights in Australia by the Australian Government.

It is evident from the white paper on human rights produced by the PRC that its view of basic and fundamental human rights for individuals means that those rights could be subordinated to the perceived rights of the state, which are termed economic, social and cultural rights. Of course, those rights are determined by the PRC. We all know that human rights are universal and indivisible. This type of nice philosophical dialogue means very little to some of the political prisoners currently rotting away in Chinese gaols.

I did ask quite strongly that the human rights delegation investigate what has happened to those refugees whose applications were rejected by the Australian Government and who were forcibly repatriated to China. The response from the then Minister for Justice, Senator Tate, was:

With respect to Senator Harradine's very good suggestion about the present parliamentary delegation travelling in China, it is a good suggestion and therefore has occurred to others. Indeed, that delegation has been briefed on precisely this matter. It is amongst its working papers and documents, as I understand. I am quite sure that there would be persons within the delegation who would have an opportunity—and, as a delegation, there would be an opportunity—to utilise that brief in order to follow up the matter.

SPEECH.PARA: In this delegation report I cannot see any reference to that matter. The philosophical discussions in here are all very well, but I believe they mean nothing to those people who have been forcibly repatriated. (Extension of time granted) There is nothing in this document to say what has happened to those people. We know that the Chinese have said that people who are forcibly repatriated will not be punished for illegally departing China. That is not the point. The point is whether they are being punished—and all evidence seems to suggest that many of them are—on their forcible return to China as a result of their previous activities, including pro-democracy activities.

PARA.TAB: At last the delegation, contrary to what it did in the previous year, has acknowledged that there are gross and continuing violations of human rights in the Chinese population control program. I believe that some of the material in this report is not fully consistent with the evidence that is available on these matters. I will be dealing with that matter in greater detail when it comes before the Senate in August.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise as one coalition senator to briefly note the importance of this report and the importance of the accompanying statement of the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Senator Gareth Evans). I acknowledge with thanks the arrangements that have been made with all parties by the Government Whip for this matter to be listed for consideration in the August sittings so that we may at proper length evaluate and pass comment on both the report and the statement. Therefore, I will not continue my remarks at this stage but defer them until August. Accordingly, I seek leave to continue my remarks.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted; debate adjourned.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the document.

SPEECH.PARA: I am not quite certain what I am more put out about—the contents of this report of the Copyright Agency Ltd or the manner of its presentation to the Senate. I would ask you, Mr Deputy President, to raise with the President the manner in which the Senate has been conned by the Government—I presume it is by the Government—in the Order of Business paper for today. It states that this report—which was signed on 14 October 1992—was presented to the former Attorney-General on 14 December 1992. However, the Notice Paper states that it was in fact submitted to the present Attorney-General (Mr Lavarch) on 20 May 1993, left his office on 24 May and is now being eventually tabled on 25 May 1993—that is, a report for the year to 30 June 1992.

PARA.TAB: As you know, Mr Deputy President, it is arrant nonsense for the Government or anyone else to pretend that `the Minister' means anything other than the position of the Minister, not the particular person who may have happened to be the Minister at the time. This report was submitted to the former Minister in time for it to be presented to this chamber while we were sitting last year. That was not done. In other words, the requirements of speedy reporting were not broken by the Copyright Agency Ltd but by the Government itself—although why it took from the date of signature on 14 October 1992 until 14 December 1992 to get to the previous Minister is beyond me.

Mr Deputy President, I would ask you to see whether the President does not consider it grossly misleading that in today's Order of Business the Government is trying to pretend that this was only received by the present Minister on 20 May. It does not matter who the Minister is. The Government sat on this report from 14 December until 24 May. This may have been done because the report itself is inadequate—I do not know—or it may simply be that there has been massive incompetence in the transfer of responsibilities from one Attorney-General to the next.

The problems that I see with this Copyright Agency Ltd report—and I say in passing that I support the principle of this organisation—are in relation to the fact that this organisation is handling a very large amount of money indeed, and yet the audited reports relate not to the enormous amount of money being handled but simply to the corporate accounts, the accounts of the Copyright Agency Ltd, which handle this enormous amount of money.

While it is true that some private sector auditors, chartered accountants called Camphin Boston, have audited the accounts of the Copyright Agency Ltd, which involve some millions of dollars—for example, something like $1.9 million in running costs, which seems to me to be an extraordinarily large amount in view of the sum actually handed out to authors—the real issue is what happens in the trust account, which deals with $17.8 million. It is not audited, there are no comparable figures for the previous year, and it does not meet the requirements of the Companies Act. It is not good enough.

Apart from anything else, there is something like a 21 per cent operating cost to revenue, which clearly seems to me to be far too high. Funds of $9.4 million were received during the year and $6 million went out. However, there is to be a $9 million disbursement to authors this year. If we are to have this kind of reporting, can it please be more effective and more accurate with some comparable figures so that we can see what on earth is really happening. The audited accounts are next to meaningless—apart from being monumentally late, of course.

This is one of the reasons why it seems to me that the Senate estimates process should cover all these sorts of bodies, even when there is no requirement for an appropriation of funds. Otherwise, all we will get by way of supervision of this kind of operation is five minutes allocated speaking time during the presentation of documents, such as we have had today.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Baume, I will pass your initial comments on to the President.

PARA.TAB: Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: National Board of Employment, Education and Training

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Teague Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the document.

This is the seventh in a regular series of reports from the National Board of Employment, Education and Training to the Parliament through the Minister about firstly the operation of the profile process, that is, the profile of educational institutions which need to be negotiated and agreed to under statute by the Commonwealth Government, and secondly the operation of the higher education contribution scheme. There is a third matter raised in this report, that is, the question of institutional autonomy.

These three topics are very briefly considered in the report. The board agreed on this report on 5 March, a few days before the last election. It describes everything as rosy with regard to profiles, institutional autonomy and HECS and I do not doubt the sincerity of the chairman of the board, Mr Peter Laver, or the Chairman of the Higher Education Council, Professor Chubb. I do not challenge the sincerity of their putting forward a report on 5 March saying that all is rosy.

However, I take this opportunity to say that I am not convinced by the board or the council's statements in regard to these three topics. The findings in this report are contrary to the statements made to me over a regular period, including in recent months, about the lack of sufficient autonomy in our universities and other educational institutions and the onerous provisions whereby a centralist government in Canberra requires profiles to be defined in backrooms between university representatives and the Government here in Canberra.

These matters were hotly debated in the month of March during the election campaign and it must be observed that, when a report like this is tabled a couple of months later for the attention of the Parliament, the statement about everything being rosy lacks credibility. It is merely an assertion in the context of an education debate which has raged not only during the month of March, but in all the months before.
Page 2 of the report concerns profiles and states:

SPEECH.PARA: The universities, as autonomous institutions, need these opportunities to understand government policies about funding in a wider context, and about social issues such as equity and participation, in order to arrange their own programs more effectively. It is also apparent that most appreciate the opportunity the profiles process offers for this interaction.
I regard that as a patronising statement by the council and the board. I want to hear directly from institutional representatives rather than just hearing these rosy statements.

PARA.TAB: In the section of the report concerning institutional autonomy, I wish to refer to the reference made in one brief paragraph to the glaring intervention of this Government in regard to the John Curtin School of Medical Research at the Australian National University. I expect Senator Tierney to speak at length about this matter in a moment or two. Of course, the report acknowledges that this was a grave intrusion upon the autonomy of the ANU. In its passage on the John Curtin school it even recommends that the funding responsibility return to the Department of Employment, Education and Training. But it concludes in this way on page 7:

SPEECH.PARA: In general terms, however, the Council's position—
that is the Higher Education Council—
is that institutions have a greater degree of autonomy than in the past.

Which past? I put it to the Senate that that comparison is made only with regard to the last few years, not with regard to 10, 20 or 30 years ago. It is an unbelievable statement. I ask that these matters be considered with greater credibility.

TALK.START.PARA: —The seventh report of the Higher Education Council is in the form of advice to the Minister. It is NBEET's report on two of the most controversial issues in the higher education sector: the profiling process and institutional autonomy. Before I discuss the report, however, I would like to point out that it suffers from the same delays as all other reports from NBEET. It was interesting to note Senator Baume's comments earlier with regard to another department. Let me chronicle in a similar way the delays this report has suffered in coming before the Senate.

PARA.TAB: The Higher Education Council had undertaken to review and report to the national board, and its report is dated 23 February. It then took the national board another six weeks to forward the report to the Minister for Employment, Education and Training (Mr Beazley) with a very brief covering letter. It then took the Minister another six weeks to table the advice to the Parliament. Given that the Parliament has been sitting for the last 3 1/2 weeks, I cannot understand why the Minister should delay the presentation of this and every other NBEET report for so long. We had the disgraceful situation a few weeks ago where 10 reports were tabled on one day, thus avoiding the scrutiny of the Senate.

These delays mean that important issues that are at stake are not fully debated. Two of the issues of higher education that are at stake are profiling and institutional autonomy. This report before us reports briefly on the 1992 educational profile process. The report states that the profile process has again been seen to be helpful and not intrusive. As I have noted before when NBEET has made this sort of statement, I do not really understand who is telling this to NBEET because the comments that I have received from people in higher education institutions are that they regard the profiling process as largely a waste of the time and resources of the university.

This attitude seems to have created problems in data collection that affects the relationship between the institutions and DEET. The valuable time of university staff is taken up on a number of other similar exercises providing similar data to the Australian Bureau of Statistics, the Australian Vice-chancellor's Committee, as well as the department. University academics have a lot better things to do with their time in teaching and in research and should not be wasting an enormous amount of time filling out forms that have very little value.

The document also reports that the council wrote to each vice-chancellor inviting comments on any specific examples of intrusion which their institutions may have experienced with regard to autonomy and seeking examples of potential intrusion which could lead to unease. Twenty-four responses were received outlining various matters. The most frequent example of institutional autonomy abuse, according to the vice-chancellors, was requests by bureaucracies and authorities for data. However, the council believes that few, if any, of the responses from institutions identified examples of intrusion into institutional autonomy.

Senator Teague's comments about the John Curtin School of Medical Research were interesting. One would have thought that that is the most glaring example of an invasion of an institution's autonomy. A particular school of the university was actually removed from the control of the ANU council. It is that sort of example which should cause great concern to all universities, to this Senate and to the Australian people.

Often I think that this has come about because of a different interpretation of the word `autonomy'. In its report here today, the council believes that generally institutions have a greater degree of autonomy than in the past. It points to a number of reasons for this. It says that less cumbersome procedures are required for accreditation of new courses and that there is a greater capacity to establish new faculties or enter new fields of study and encouragement and support to build research profiles. This conveniently overlooks the other ways in which the federal bureaucracy has been intrusive and, as was mentioned before, John Curtin would be the worst example. I suggest that the council should look at what institutions regard as an invasion of autonomy rather than dismiss them because they do not fit in with the council's definition.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the President, I present a letter the President has received from the Chairman of the Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration, Senator Coates, relating to the allocation of annual reports to committees.

—In accordance with the provisions of the Audit Act 1901, on behalf of the President I present the following report of the Auditor-General: Audit Act—Project Audit: The National Bankcard: Who Will Pay The Piper?—A Report on the Financial Obligations of the Federal Government—(Report No. 34).

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the document.

SPEECH.PARA: This report, Project audit: the national Bankcard: who will pay the piper?, by the Australian National Audit Office is a very important report indeed. It is a report on the financial obligations of the Federal Government. The report identifies government obligations in excess of $125 billion. It says that even that figure is underestimated. The report believes that the underestimation is more than $44 billion, made up of guarantees and contingencies of $18 billion, capital and other commitments of $9 1/2 billion and forward obligations of $16.8 billion. In other words, the report identifies government obligations of exactly $169 billion. That is an enormous amount of money.

PARA.TAB: The Auditor-General's report concluded that, whilst Australia is currently able to meet this level of obligations, improvements in existing monitoring and reporting arrangements are needed. The report says that central to these improvements is the development of `whole of government reporting', which is now possible given the Government's adoption of accrual accounting for all agencies. That is a matter on which we had some discussion last week in the Senate. In raising this matter, I welcomed the fact that the Government is moving towards the adoption of accrual accounting.

The Auditor-General makes several recommendations aimed at improving the management of these huge obligations and the information available in relation to them so as to better assess the Government's management of its obligations, including whether in the management of its programs the Government has considered the impact on the level of obligations and the consequences to both existing and future taxpayers. I want to quote at some length from a couple of the key sections of the report because I believe that what the Auditor-General has put in here—by way of comment and explanation and description of the existing situation and the recommendations the report makes to deal with it—is very important indeed.

The bottom line of this report reflects even more strongly than the Opposition has been able to do the Government's gross irresponsibility in its election promises which involve huge increases—$4 billion worth—in government spending. It also reflects the gross irresponsibility that flows from the fact that this Government has completely ignored the size and significance of the Budget deficit. It has not pursued the necessary measures to reduce that deficit and the public sector call on the savings of Australians—savings that are so critical if we are going to get this economy going again. An increase in the Government's Budget deficit—indeed, any Budget deficit—requires drawing on the nation's savings and a consequent reduction thereof. I will come back to that point a little later.
I wish to quote some key points in the report. It states:

Obligations of the Federal Government exceed $125 billion. While the Government is currently able to meet these obligations, improvements in existing monitoring systems to control the level and impact of these obligations are needed.
These obligations include Federal Government borrowings with a market value of $50 billion.

SPEECH.PARA: In other words, government borrowings have a market value of $50 billion, which corresponds to 11.8 per cent of our total annual gross domestic product—our total national production each year. That figure compares favourably with the average over the past 10 years, which has been in excess of 13 per cent. However, the Auditor-General makes a very telling point, with which I totally agree:
The recent deterioration in the budget deficit may, however, put pressure on future debt levels.

PARA.TAB: The Australian Treasury's role in managing the Federal Government's borrowings could be improved by regular performance evaluation of the debt management function.

Funding decisions taken by the Government lack the benefit of the information that would normally be available in any well run company which manages the level and impact of its obligations on future cash flows, costs and investment decisions so as to protect its future viability and maximise its return to its shareholders. In government, funding decisions have a direct impact on the Australian economy and taxpayers. Sound financial management of obligations by the Government should ensure that the impact on future taxation rates, the cost of government programs and investment in infrastructure will be balanced with the need to avoid undue obligations on future taxpayers and adverse affects on the living standards of Australians.

SPEECH.PARA: That is quite the opposite of the end result of the Government's recent decisions and actions in its grossly irresponsible fiscal policy. The report goes on to state:
In this respect, current accountability to the Parliament and the taxpayer is deficient, as:
. available data is not easily accessible and fails to highlight relevant benchmarks
. no federal agency has a responsibility to accumulate, monitor, manage or report on the total obligations of the Federal Government—
that is an extraordinary finding by the Auditor-General—
. budget papers provide only a short term view on the impact of funding decisions—
we all know that—
. practices adopted in the financial reporting of obligations, including superannuation, are significantly below the standards adopted in the private sector.
That is a very damning comment indeed. The report then states:
More accessible and better information is needed if Australia's medium to long term interests are to be protected.

The report acknowledges that the introduction of accrual accounting for departments and agencies by the Government is a significant step forward and that research work has commenced on whole of government reporting on an accrual basis. The Australian National Audit Office (ANAO) considers that whole of government reporting on an accrual basis is critical to disclosure of obligations and recommends that it be introduced by June 1995.

That is one of the two recommendations made by the Auditor-General. There are 15 recommendations, two of which are regarded by the Auditor-General as essential—and that is one of the two. In supplementing the points that I have just described, the report states:
To meet outstanding obligations, the Commonwealth has available liquid assets totalling $57 billion,—
Remember that the total of its outstanding obligations is $170 billion—
leaving $70 billion to be met from future government receipts or realisation of non-liquid assets.

That $70 billion still to be met from future government receipts or realisation of non-liquid assets excludes the $44 billion which the report feels its obligations figure of $125 billion is understated by. The report then says:
The Commonwealth's power to tax should ensure that the Commonwealth remains solvent at all times—
One would hope so. It continues:
The obligations presented above represent the financial obligations of the Government prior to the exercise of its taxation powers and impact on the taxpayer through the possibility of:
. the Federal Government being forced to increase receipts by options such as increasing taxation levels or privatising government assets
. the Federal Government being forced to reduce expenditure in other areas of government, such as infrastructure, thereby lowering the future standards of living of Australians, and

. obligation levels increasing . . . leading to an escalation of servicing costs. This latter option could have wider economic implications such as the possibility of increased dependence by both private and public sectors on foreign debt.

That confirms what the coalition has been saying time and time again over recent years. If one is looking to strengthen the sovereignty and the independence of this nation, the one thing one does not do is to put this nation continually and increasingly into hock, into debt, to the rest of the world. Yet that is a policy which this Government has pursued stringently and assiduously since it took office.

PARA.TAB: Since the Government took office, our national debt to the rest of the world has gone up from approximately $25 billion, a very manageable figure in those days, to a figure in excess of $200 billion. That figure means that we as a nation have almost the highest level of foreign debt on this earth. This is an enormous indictment of this Government's policies and it is the highest risk set of policies that a nation such as ours could pursue, particularly when one looks at the prospects for the Australian economy, given the difficult problems in the overseas world, the international economy, and all the implications for our export earnings—let alone the lack of reform measures that have been taken in Australia to enable us to become more competitive, not just overseas but in our domestic markets as well.

This Government's irresponsibility in failing to tackle the Budget deficit—and, on the contrary, by exacerbating that deficit through a whole series of grossly irresponsible spending promises and bribes during the election campaign—has put this economy, and therefore all Australians, at even more risk of declining living standards and of going into hock in relation to the rest of the world than was the case before.

The Government has created for itself the totally unenviable task of delivering $4 billion of spending promises per year for the next three years of this Parliament. That results from no less than 138 specific additional spending promises and election bribes that were made in and during the lead-up to the last election, $2 billion dollars of revenue promises and $8 billion of personal income tax cuts. On top of that it has given a commitment of a Budget deficit of no more than $5 billion in 1996-97. That figure compares with a Budget deficit outcome for this year of approximately $16 billion on present indications.

The Government has got to try to meet all these commitments, promises and undertakings in an environment of low growth, high unemployment, national dissavings and nil investment. There is not one forecaster in Australia, public or private, who believes that those various undertakings are compatible. Independent forecasters are at one in stating that those undertakings are incompatible. They forecast a Budget deficit of around $13 billion in 1996-97—not the $5 billion that the Government is talking about—if the tax cut and spending promises are kept. That means that the Treasurer (Mr Dawkins), and the Minister for Finance (Mr Willis) have to come up with $8 billion from somewhere. Personally, I think that that is likely to be a gross underestimate as well.

All the reports indicate, and I think Treasurer Dawkins yesterday confirmed, that the Government will have to find $2 billion next financial year alone, that is, 1993-94, just to maintain the level of the deficit at its current level for this year of around $16 billion. It means that the starting point for the upcoming Budget is a deficit of $18 billion, despite the Government's claims that recovery is now under way in the economy. What nonsense that statement is.

To put into perspective the magnitude of what is required, only twice under this Government has expenditure been cut by $2 billion in any one year. The $8 billion that it will have to find in the period up to 1996-97 is four times that figure. The first occasion when $2 billion was cut was in the midst of the banana republic fever, in the 1986 Budget. The second occasion was in the May 1987 statement when a further $2.6 billion was slashed. What sorts of cuts do we get for $2 billion? In 1986 the cuts included slashing defence, introducing student fees, cutting hospital and medical services, deferring pensions, reducing foreign aid, halting capital works, diminishing road funding, hammering States' payments and massive asset sales. In the May 1987 statement, the cuts went further into defence, roads, payments to the States—squeezing the States—local government, primary industry, killing off the first home owners scheme, introducing the controversial pharmaceutical co-payment and large-scale welfare crackdowns. In other words, a cut of $2 billion would hit a lot of people—so what about an $8 billion cut, which the Government will have to make?

To put that into perspective, the $8 billion is almost the entire Commonwealth expenditure on education and defence. It is equal to all the Commonwealth expenditure on housing and community amenities, transport and communications, culture and recreation and labour and employment. It is more money than the Federal Government spends on the unemployed and the sick. It is more than it spends on assistance to all families. It is, indeed, on the revenue side, equivalent to two-thirds of company tax revenue and 85 per cent of all sales taxes. It is more than we collect in petrol excise; and it is over three times the collection from the Medicare levy. In other words, obviously we are in for some major tax rises and expenditure cuts over the next few years if the Keating Government is to honour its promises. A more savage attack on the Budget deficit will be required than that which has ever occurred under this Government.

What the Auditor-General's report is really getting at—this is the bottom line—is, on the one hand, the gross irresponsibility that this Government has let itself be drawn into through either an inability or an unwillingness to undertake a responsible budgetary policy over recent years and, on the other hand, the grossly irresponsible election bribing that went on in the run-up to the 1993 election when the Government made well over 130 spending promises that it knows it has no hope in the world of being able to meet unless it abandons all of its tax cut proposals and the like. The coalition is certainly not going to allow this Government to get away with actions which are going to legitimise in any way the totally illegitimate and unachievable promises and commitments that it has made in the last couple of years.

There is a lot more in this report that I commend to the Senate, but time does not permit me to pursue this today. The Auditor-General's report The National Bankcard—Who will pay the Piper? is one that requires much more careful consideration by this Parliament and, indeed, by the Australian community.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
