TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Joint Committee on Public Works, I present the following reports of the committee: housing development, Palmerston, Northern Territory; housing development at Flinders View near Ipswich, Queensland; and HMAS Waterhen facilities modernisation, Waverton, New South Wales. I seek leave to make a statement.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —The first report which I have tabled deals with the construction of 210 dwellings at Palmerston in Darwin—70 of which will be for service personnel and their families. The balance of 140 houses will be offered for sale to private purchasers. The project will be undertaken in three stages at a net cost of $14.2 million. The committee has recommended that the project proceed as planned.

PARA.TAB: The committee concluded that there is a need for the Defence Housing Authority to provide appropriate housing to cater for the increased Army presence in the north. The site of Palmerston is ideally located for Army personnel working at Waler Barracks. The proposed construction of facilities for the 2nd Cavalry Regiment, comprising Waler Barracks, was the subject of an inquiry and report by the committee during 1992. This proposal is therefore directly related to that development.

Palmerston, which was established in 1980, is located 22 kilometres east of Darwin and currently has a population of 8,000 residents. The houses will be located in the suburb of Driver and will be built on 114 lots. The proposed development has been designed to comply with local planning guidelines. Considerable regard has therefore been given to road patterns and the provision of open space, which are reflected in the civic design concept and the landscape master plan.

The houses themselves will comprise 91 detached dwellings, 58 attached courtyard dwellings and 61 medium density dwellings. Features of the designs include: elevated floors; orientation to capture maximum ventilation and louvre windows for cross-flow ventilation; cyclone proof construction; metal wall and roof cladding; solar hot water; and ceiling fans and airconditioning of the living room and main sleeping area. House sizes and the number of bedrooms in each will be provided to meet service requirements. The designs will provide for a range of floor areas, ranging from 115 square metres to 145 square metres.

As I mentioned earlier, the Defence Housing Authority proposes to provide 70 dwellings for service families with the balance of 140 being offered for sale to private purchasers. At the public hearing the authority advised the committee that it may be desirable to increase this holding to 50 per cent should demand from the private sector be low. The committee was assured by the authority that it does not intend to establish an estate solely for service personnel but wishes to integrate service families into the general community.

The second report, which I have just tabled, involves the development of a 53.8 hectare site at Flinders View near Ipswich to improve the standard of housing for defence personnel at the nearby RAAF base Amberley. Mr Acting Deputy President, as you represent the State of Queensland, I am sure this would interest you.

TALK.START.PARA: —It would interest us all.

—And others, yes. The Defence Housing Authority proposes to construct 180 dwellings, and the balance of 370 dwelling sites will be offered for sale to the public. Service and private sector housing will therefore be integrated within the proposed development. The estimated cost of the proposal is $31 million, of which $18 million will be received from the sale of building lots.

PARA.TAB: The committee has concluded that there is a need to provide suitable dwellings for those service personnel from RAAF base Amberley who are occupying substandard houses and temporary rental accommodation in the Leichhardt and Amberley areas. The site of Flinders View is well located for a housing development for service families due to its proximity to RAAF base Amberley and existing and proposed local school, shopping and recreational facilities.

An urban planning concept was developed for the proposal. This aims to achieve a mixed density neighbourhood based on integrated allotment, housing and road planning design principles. Local housing precincts have been designed to have the focus of a small village reserve or landscape feature.

Whilst the committee is generally satisfied with the planning and design of the proposed development, its report makes a number of recommendations in relation to the provision of specific features in the houses. First, the committee has recommended that the Defence Housing Authority provide all the dwellings with solar hot-water systems. This recommendation is consistent with the stand taken by the committee on previous occasions. Solar hot-water systems are a community norm, and the authority should demonstrate its commitment to energy conservation. Secondly, the committee has recommended that smoke detectors and earth leakage circuit breakers should also be installed in the houses. Again, the committee believes that the provision of these features is consistent with community expectations.

The report also makes a wide-ranging recommendation which involves the authority reviewing its design criteria to ensure that service housing is as energy efficient as possible. However, the committee continues to be impressed by the progress made by the DHA in improving the standard of housing provided to defence personnel.

The third and final report I wish to comment on concerns the proposed facilities modernisation at HMAS Waterhen at Waverton, a harbourside suburb of North Sydney. HMAS Waterhen is the nation's national mine warfare base. The committee has recommended that the facilities modernisation estimated at a cost of $73 million at December 1992 prices should proceed as planned. In arriving at this recommendation the committee gave careful attention to a number of matters such as the need for a modernised mine warfare base, the best location for it and the existing facilities at HMAS Waterhen.

There is no doubt that the Navy needs improved facilities from which to operate its new mine warfare vessels which are planned for introduction in December 1997. The existing facilities at HMAS Waterhen would be inadequate to support the new mine hunter coastal ships. The Department of Defence examined a number of possible alternative locations, and the committee has concluded that the location of new purpose-built facilities in Sydney and at HMAS Waterhen offer cost, support and operational advantages over other options examined.

The number of personnel to be employed in shore facilities and attached vessels is expected to be 766. The proposed capacity of the shore element is to accommodate 377 personnel at peak levels of operation during a working week. The balance of 389 personnel will be employed in attached vessels which will deploy and return to the base on a continuing basis throughout the year. The main elements of the proposed work include a new operations and administration building, a supply and clearance diving building, a technical workshops building, waterfront and external works, a car park building and relocation works.

The committee's report concludes that the scope of the proposed development can be justified on the basis of the functions of HMAS Waterhen and the number of vessels and support infrastructure it will be required to support. Furthermore, the report concludes that generally the proposed design and siting of facilities and other structures would not detract from the maritime character of other facilities and structures in the area.

The report does recommend, however, that the final design of the proposed car park will need to reflect its environmentally sensitive location, and that Defence should ensure that personnel to be employed at the redeveloped base use public transport to the maximum extent possible. The latter recommendation takes account of the views of representatives of local residents who appeared before the committee at the public hearing. I commend the reports to the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tambling Sen G.E.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the statement.

SPEECH.PARA: On Saturday, 17 April this year, the Governor-General, Bill Hayden, opened the new Army facilities at Waler Barracks in the Northern Territory. On that memorable day it was a very important, symbolic and significant event. It was well presented by the Department of Defence and, indeed, the Army's role in integrating so much of its new activity in northern Australia was very well accepted by the Darwin and Palmerston communities.

PARA.TAB: The first of the three reports that have just been tabled by Senator Calvert refers to the associated housing development at Palmerston in the Northern Territory. I welcome this report and this initiative not only because of the importance that it holds for my own electorate, the Northern Territory, but also because the Defence Housing Authority is breaking new ground in the way it operates in Australia.

I commend the work of the Defence Housing Authority. It has taken a number of very important initiatives in the management of housing for defence personnel, and in the providing of many associated facilities. I would particularly commend the activities of the Defence Housing Authority for its good neighbourly and good neighbourhood policies of integrating into the community. This particular housing project is a very important one. The Defence Housing Authority has been developing a special relationship with the town of Palmerston which is, of course, very close to the new Waler Barracks.

I refer to the annual report for 1991-92 of the Defence Housing Authority and in particular the comments in the Managing Director's Review by the Managing Director, Mr Bill Kirkby-Jones. Under a heading of `Defence Environment', Mr Kirkby-Jones says:

SPEECH.PARA: In the past 12 months the Authority has undertaken a major housing construction and acquisition program in Darwin to meet the needs of the 2nd Cavalry Regiment which is scheduled to commence its relocation from Holsworthy in New South Wales.
Further on his comments read:

The relocation of Service units changes the patterns of demands for housing to be provided by the Authority and to meet this changing demand expeditiously there is the need for early advice. This is not always possible since there are many other factors which may drive the timing of relocations and in consequence there is an increased requirement for the Authority to be both responsive and flexible and to consult closely with the Australian Defence Force.

Since its inception, the Defence Housing Authority has had a good record in the Northern Territory, particularly in the areas close to Darwin, and in concentrating on a focus in rectifying the defects of the housing which was handed over to it at Tindal near Katherine. This new and additional work is very important. I commend the Defence Housing Authority on the design of the construction that it has so far instituted. I am sure from the comments that are flowing through from this report and the evidence that has been given to the Public Works Committee that it will continue with that innovative and very special housing design. I also comment on the degree of consultation that the Defence Housing Authority has engaged in with the various planning authorities, the Ministers and the departments of the Northern Territory Government and the Northern Territory Town Planning Authority.

PARA.TAB: To date, the single personnel of Waler Barracks have been accommodated on site at Waler Barracks and the families have been accommodated in the nearby suburbs, particularly Palmerston. It is obvious, as a result of this report and the initiatives that are to be taken, that defence personnel will build up in Palmerston. But it is important to note that the Defence Housing Authority intends to ensure that the service families are integrated into the general community. In particular, the land and housing developments initiated by this project will ensure that that initiative continues.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of Senator Aulich, I seek leave to make a statement relating to the work of the Standing Committee on Employment, Education and Training and to give notice of a motion.

TALK.START.PARA: —During the last Parliament the Senate referred to the Standing Committee on Employment, Education and Training matters related to the operations of sections 45D and 45E of the Trade Practices Act 1974. The committee received a number of submissions from employer and employee organisations and individuals, as well as submissions from conservation groups concerning the impact of these sections on such groups activities.

PARA.TAB: Honourable senators will be aware that the Government has declared its intention to introduce a major package of industrial relations legislation into Parliament during the Budget sittings. On behalf of Senator Aulich, I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, he will move:
That the following matter be referred to the Standing Committee on Employment, Education and Training for inquiry and report by 27 September 1993:

SPEECH.PARA: The effect of the operation of sections 45D and 45E of the Trade Practices Act 1994 with particular reference to:

PARA.TAB: (a)whether sections 45D and 45E are unduly harsh and restrictive when compared with International Labour Organisation conventions on freedom of association and the recently clarified right to free speech apparently implicit in Australia's constitution;

(b)what revisions to either the Trade Practices Act 1974 or the Industrial Relations Act 1988 should be made in order to clarify a worker's right to withdraw labour and under what conditions such withdrawal may or may not be pursued as a breach of contract;

(c)whether sections 45D and 45E provide security in law for the legitimate rights of individuals, and small and large businesses, to have freedom in the movement of goods and services and to trade without interference;
(d)whether sections 45D and 45E are a satisfactory means of preventing and settling industrial disputes; and
(e)the extent to which sections 45D and 45E might unduly restrict civil liberties, particularly by way of impeding the legitimate exercise of protest action by citizens.

TALKER.NAME: Senator RICHARDSON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Health)

TALK.START.PARA: —Just before the sitting was suspended for lunch—which seems so long ago now—Senator Newman asked a number of questions concerning tuberculosis sufferers. In particular, she asked about the undertakings they give when entering Australia. I thought I would give her a further answer to that question.

PARA.TAB: Effective health measures are required to ensure that tuberculosis does not become a health issue within Australia. However, generally speaking, these rest with State governments. The Commonwealth screens intending migrants and, in appropriate circumstances, the migrant medical clearance unit issues a tuberculosis undertaking. The States are responsible for follow-up action and the Commonwealth has no data on that compliance.

While our TB statistics do not indicate a rise in incidence here, a recent World Health Organisation meeting has reported an increase in TB worldwide. Every year three million people die from TB and eight million new people develop the disease. If we are to contain and control the disease in Australia as part of a worldwide effort, we must maintain our vigilance and ensure that our case finding and treatment procedures remain as effective and thorough as possible.

I table data on the birthplaces of all people notified as having TB for 1991. With regard to the countries specifically identified by Senator Newman prior to the lunch break, the numbers are small and are as follows: Cambodia, seven; Yugoslavia, 18; and USSR, five. Given the figures that we were talking about earlier—Vietnam with 156 and China with 44, et cetera—these are very small numbers.

However, I am concerned that there is no Commonwealth follow-up on those State responsibilities. This means that there is no proper accountability for what happens with these tuberculosis undertakings. As a result of this matter being raised, I shall ensure that a regime is put in place very quickly to do exactly that.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Minister. I am glad he recognises that it is a serious matter. I did not think that I got very serious consideration at the estimates committee hearing the other night. I appreciate the fact the Minister is apparently not ready to brush it aside. But I take issue with some of the detail of his answer. The Minister said that the TBUs are handed to the States which then have the responsibility for follow-up action. The States may have some sort of responsibility for follow-up action, but the problem is that there is no legal basis for the document that the Commonwealth requires the migrants to sign. The documents are not enforceable. There is no way that either the Commonwealth or the States know where these people are because, although they have undertaken to report in, at the most only 40 per cent of people actually do report in. They disappear into Australia, possibly incubating TB and spreading the infection.

PARA.TAB: The Minister's department has responsibility for public health policy in this country. Therefore, I hold his department accountable for not having previously put in place a regime whereby these undertakings are in fact enforceable. I ask the Minister: why has that not occurred?

TALKER.NAME: Senator RICHARDSON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Health)

TALK.START.PARA: —Without having received advice as to why it has not occurred in the past, I can only assume that, in being able to give the answer that our TB statistics do not indicate a rise in incidence here, it has probably not been considered necessary. But I have acknowledged to Senator Newman that, no matter what was considered in the past, I consider it necessary. I will make sure that the regime is put in place.

—I thank the Minister. I point out to him that, judging by the figures that were given to us the other night at estimates, there is in fact a trend upwards in the incidence of reported cases of TB in Australia. Added to that, as we receive a high proportion of our migrants from Asia and as we are surrounded by Asian countries which have an extremely high incidence of tuberculosis, I would have thought Australia would be bending over backwards to screen for TB—particularly people from Asian countries and also people from countries like the USSR and Yugoslavia which also have a high incidence—rather than requiring the Opposition to draw the Minister's attention to this problem before action is taken.

PARA.TAB: I ask the Minister to tell me why there has been no action. It is no answer just to say that we do not have big numbers of such cases. The trend is up and we are surrounded by countries which, by world standards, have an extraordinarily high incidence of TB, and we are taking a high proportion of our migrants and refugees from those areas.

TALKER.NAME: Senator RICHARDSON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Health)

TALK.START.PARA: —I did say earlier that I do not have figures for 1992-93, so I cannot say what has happened in most recent times; when those figures come out I will make them available. Senator Newman is not correct when she says the rate of reported cases of tuberculosis is going up. In fact, since 1988 it has trended down. In 1988, there were 925 cases or 5.59 cases per 100,000 head of population per year. That dropped to 902 in 1989. It went up to 979 in 1990, and down to 903 in 1991. So with that recent trend not being up, I can only assume that the answer I gave earlier was correct, and I think those figures bear it out.

PARA.TAB: Nonetheless, I am acknowledging—particularly given that there are now signs of a new strain that is resistant to drugs and therefore potentially can be a big health problem, particularly for those at risk in our society—that it is necessary to put a regime in place. That of course will involve the Commonwealth and the States. It will involve not only involve my department but also immigration. I am giving an undertaking to put a regime in place as soon as possible.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Minister. I draw the Minister's attention—and I will not make a great thing of it now but will leave him to think about it—to the evidence given to the Senate estimates committee in which it was acknowledged that there was a small trend upwards and that the reduction in 1991, which the Minister just told us about, was treated as not particularly significant. That was evidence given by one of the Minister's officers to the Senate estimates committee and I have the passage in front of me. Perhaps the Minister had better double check his advice.

PARA.TAB: I move to another issue. I understand we are screening migrants overseas by way of X-rays. I understand that is about 100 times more expensive than the Mantoux test, which in many ways is a more useful test of exposure to TB. I ask the Minister for Family Services (Senator Crowley) why we are not using the Mantoux test, especially in those countries that I mentioned earlier which have a particularly high incidence of TB.

TALKER.NAME: Senator CROWLEY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Family Services and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am advised that when using the Mantoux test we can get a very high level of false positives, particularly in those countries that Senator Newman mentioned.
—Is that all the answer, Minister?
—Yes: the Mantoux test will provide very high false positives—misleading evidence that might suggest TB when there is no TB there.

—I thank the Minister for the answer. Could she explain to me why the only information I was given the other night related to these TB undertakings, which relate to a very small proportion of the people who are coming in. I understand that they are people who have had TB and have had to demonstrate that they have had treatment for it. They get a chest X-ray to show that they are clear and then sign an undertaking to say that they will report in and be monitored. There is a great number of other people—as the Minister at the table, being a doctor, would know full well—who can be incubating TB but it is not showing up at that stage in their X-ray, yet their exposure to TB will be shown up by a Mantoux test.

PARA.TAB: We have a larger proportion of the vulnerable people coming in with no indication at all that they have been exposed to TB. The figures that I gave the Minister in this committee earlier today show that about 50 per cent of all the notification cases in Australia from overseas born people incubate TB within the first five years that they are here. In fact, as I recall, one-quarter of them develop TB within the first two years that they are here. That was not addressed by the Minister for Health (Senator Richardson) in the precis that he gave me just now in response to all the questions I asked earlier today.

The fact remains that the screening procedure, whichever it is, is obviously inadequate. People are getting through our system and coming into this country—at this stage, admittedly, not in enormous numbers—who, as the Minister knows, are able to spread the disease if they are not detected. We have no way of enforcing any follow-up on them at all and we do not know who they are. We clearly did not know that the majority of people who have been exposed to TB after developing it in Australia had been exposed at all. What are we going to do about that? The Minister, as a doctor, must be concerned.

TALKER.NAME: Senator CROWLEY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Family Services and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women)

TALK.START.PARA: —I believe that Minister Richardson has given an undertaking on the large part of Senator Newman's question. In answer to her earlier question to me after the last answer, I do not believe it would assist at all to use a Mantoux test, which could give false positives and misleading evidence of tuberculosis where exposure had not occurred. The questions Senator Newman raised are very important; I think Minister Richardson has made that clear and I think he has taken note of her comments on the matter.

—I thank the Minister. I will not belabour this issue much longer tonight, although she can be assured that it is something that I shall not allow to rest, even if the department does not seem very concerned about it. I am glad to see that maybe I have alerted the Minister to the need to be concerned.

PARA.TAB: I would like to ask the Minister now, if her officials are concentrating, what the relationship is between the Commonwealth and the States on this issue. Am I correct in the information that has come to me that there is a very great deal of frustration amongst those responsible for public health in the States in that they cannot get cooperation from the Commonwealth on this matter?

TALKER.NAME: Senator CROWLEY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Family Services and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women)

TALK.START.PARA: —I understand that over the years the States have had discussions with the Commonwealth about this matter. It is an issue that has been raised on a number of occasions but I am advised that there is no particular cause for concern coming from the States at this time.
—Is it not true that the Commonwealth has refused to provide further information to the States to enable them to follow up on people who may be potential carriers of tuberculosis?

TALKER.NAME: Senator CROWLEY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Family Services and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women)

TALK.START.PARA: —I believe Senator Newman has raised all these matters with Minister Richardson. I believe that it is covered by his agreement to look into this matter.

—I have not earlier raised anything to do with this issue. This new issue that I am now raising concerns the frustration that the States are finding at the Commonwealth's refusal to provide information on which the States could act. There has been a refusal by the Commonwealth, a matter that I have not raised earlier.

TALKER.NAME: Senator CROWLEY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Family Services and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women)

TALK.START.PARA: —From time to time the States have raised these matters with the Commonwealth, but they very much go to the department of immigration. I understand from Minister Richardson's reply to questions from Senator Newman that when he says he will look into this matter, that will include taking up this issue with the department of immigration.

—Does the Minister regard this as an area where public health requirements must take priority over privacy issues? Or does she think the right of people to go around and infect others with a very infectious disease and to have the privacy to do that takes priority over the interests of other people not to be infected?

TALKER.NAME: Senator CROWLEY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Family Services and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women)

TALK.START.PARA: —All honourable senators would regard the management of diseases of this sort as being very serious. My understanding from advice received is that tuberculosis is a notifiable disease, but notifiable to State organisations. I have raised in this place before the point about the fine balance that has to be found between the requirement to notify diseases and at the same time to protect as much as possible the privacy of citizens. It is a matter of great and serious concern, and properly it is a matter of fine balance.

—I thank the Minister. I conclude by saying that I find it extraordinary that the Commonwealth has not made it mandatory for people to obey its undertaking. In addition, it has people coming into the country who may well know the whereabouts of such people who may have been exposed to TB, but who refuse to give information to State health authorities to prevent the exposure of other people to TB, all in the name of privacy. I find that extraordinary.

PARA.TAB: I cannot believe that this situation can be allowed to go on, especially when we are sitting in the middle of an area that is rife with TB and we are taking a large number of migrants from that area. We must have measures in place to protect Australian people from exposure to TB. In my view, it is no justification for the Commonwealth to refuse to give information to those whose duty it is to treat people with TB and to find out who their contacts have been.

When somebody with a notifiable disease comes from another country into this country and spends over two years, five years or whatever it might be here, somebody who obviously has been in contact with a lot of other people, it is absolutely imperative for the health authorities in this country to be able to trace those contacts and to get the help of the Commonwealth in doing so.

It is a total failure of the Commonwealth's responsibility, in my view, to hide behind the veil of privacy on this issue when public health is at stake. I am very glad, therefore, that the Minister for Health (Senator Richardson) is prepared to follow it up. I am astounded at what I see as a total failure of responsibility by the Commonwealth—by the department of health and the department of immigration, both of which I believe are culpable in this matter.

TALK.START.PARA: —Are there any questions or matters to be raised in relation to questions taken on notice before or during the committee's hearings for which answers had not been received by 18 May?

—I rise only to ask why a couple of questions that were taken on notice have not yet been responded to. Mr Chairman, I would have thought it more appropriate to deal with these matters with the relevant officers as we went through the running sheet, but if it is your direction that I deal with them now, I can do so.

PARA.TAB: The only two questions to which I do not seem to have answers are in relation to some comparative unemployment figures on the local capital works scheme under subprogram 6.4. I am happy to deal with those matters when we get to that subprogram as there are a couple of other matters I want to raise at that time.

The other question related to a valuation of the Lobby Restaurant. I do have answers to some other questions I asked in relation to that. I do not really want to take that matter much further, except to say that one of the answers states that the building valuation currently available was undertaken in 1988 and is not considered representative of the current building asset value. I would not have minded having that if that was all that was available, but the answer goes on to state that the building is currently being valued by the Australian Valuation Office, that an early report had been requested and was expected by Friday 21 May. That was a few days ago, so I am wondering where that valuation is and whether I could have a copy of it. I am happy to come back to these.

TALK.START.PARA: —You mentioned that the first matter was in relation to subprogram 6.4. That could be raised when we are dealing with that subprogram.
—The other matter came under program 6, housing and urban development.
—Very well, if you would prefer to deal with those matters then.
—I think that will probably be the most convenient way of going about it so that the appropriate officers will be here.
—There being no-one wishing to speak to the general matter of non-program specific variations or to program 1, program 2, program 3, program 4 or program 5, we now move to program 6.

—I suppose that initially I should ask the Minister—although, with no disrespect to Senator Crowley, I suspect she will not be able to assist terribly much—whether she can indicate when the information I sought in the form of details about the formal evaluation might be made available.
—Is this the Lobby Restaurant, Senator?

—No, the Lobby Restaurant is a bit further on; this is the working for the future program, about which I raised a reservation. During the estimates committee hearings, Senator Richardson indicated that a formal evaluation would be made—by the Office of Local Government, I assume—of the outcomes of the local capital works program. I would like to know from the Minister whether the formal evaluation program will include an evaluation of the jobs created. Will it give an indication of the jobs created by each project? Will it give an evaluation of the jobs that went to previously unemployed people?

PARA.TAB: When the local capital works program was introduced, there was a suggestion that 13,000 jobs would be created. Subsequently we had indications from various Ministers that they were finding it difficult to show where, for the enormous amount of money being spent, any new jobs would be created. The best we got was when it was indicated in this chamber—I think it was by Senator Bolkus—that no new jobs would be created; we would just save a few jobs that otherwise might have gone. In the estimates committee hearings Senator Richardson indicated that there would be a formal evaluation. I am wondering when that formal evaluation is likely to come and whether it will include the things I have raised.

TALKER.NAME: Senator CROWLEY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Family Services and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am advised that the evaluation will commence by about July and should be completed by the end of the year or early next year. As Senator Macdonald has said, the Minister promised a formal evaluation and I understand that that will start in July.

—At page 59 of the Estimates Committee C transcript I asked for some unemployment figures for the March 1993 quarter for the purposes of comparison. At the time I think the officer Mr Lynch told me that he did not think those figures were yet available and indicated that there would be no difficulty in supplying them when they were. I then suggested the possibility of looking at those figures when they became available. Would the Minister be able to indicate when those March 1993 figures might be available? That seems to be the question which remains unanswered.

TALKER.NAME: Senator CROWLEY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Family Services and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women)

TALK.START.PARA: —The March 1993 unemployment data should be available towards the end of July this year. The data is provided by the Department of Employment, Education and Training from information gathered by the Department of Social Security and the Australian Bureau of Statistics. Given the massive amount of data involved and the complexity of analysing it, it will take some months to become available.

—I really want the Minister to tell me whether that formal evaluation will include the number of jobs created. Will it show the numbers of jobs created in each local authority area and will those figures from each local authority area indicate which of the people employed had been unemployed previously?

TALKER.NAME: Senator CROWLEY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Family Services and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am advised that no final decision has been taken on the matters which Senator Macdonald has raised. It certainly would be a very expensive exercise to try to do that for every local government area. It may be that a sample of local government areas will be chosen as the way to go. But that decision is still not finalised.

—The Minister indicated to me that there would be a full and formal evaluation. Just getting a sample of a few councils could hardly be called `full and formal' because how do we get the representative sample? There is a lot of confusion and unhappiness about how the money was given out. The Minister might recall that there were suggestions that it was given out in marginal electorates. I do not always agree with that, but it is one view.

PARA.TAB: A lot of local authorities are very unhappy that, whilst they have huge numbers of unemployed, they did not reach the required amount in percentage terms and therefore missed out; notwithstanding that neighbouring councils were given quite a lot of money. There is even a suggestion that some of the councils which received money got it on the basis of a number of residents who actually lived in one area but registered in another. But in the past I have been told that is wrong.

If there is to be a full evaluation, one would hope that it would indicate the number of jobs created. The money was handed out to local authorities initially on the basis of a job creation project. I cannot believe that the Government would have gone into a job creation project without being able to measure in some way the number of jobs that it created. A little later on, the name or emphasis of the program was shifted very skilfully. It became a local capital works program which was just supposed to give out money for capital works rather than create jobs.

I do not think anyone has ever denied that it was intended to create jobs in the run-up to the election. One would think it unusual that if it were a project to create jobs, there was no method in place to evaluate how many jobs had been created. Surely when giving the money there would have been some requirement to report back on the number of jobs created. I will be interested to hear the Minister's answer and to find out what stage the decisions as to this evaluation have reached. Senator Richardson mentioned it with some gusto and certainty. I would like to know when it is likely to be decided—if it has not already—as to what that evaluation will involve.

TALKER.NAME: Senator CROWLEY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Family Services and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women)

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Chairman, perhaps it would assist the honourable senator if I tabled the eligibility criteria for the local capital works program which spells out the criteria for the selection of projects. This might deal with his comments that it was a job creation program, because that was perhaps an insufficient description. I have already said that the details of evaluation are still under discussion.

PARA.TAB: It is pre-emptive for Senator Macdonald to suggest that a few local government areas would be part of a sample. I am advised that, if the sampling method is agreed to, it would not be a few but would involve a proper comprehensive sample. It is possible to do that. In fact, we are jumping the gun here because the details of that evaluation process are still under discussion. I will table the document relating to the criteria.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macdonald Sen I.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am aware of that and there is no need for the Minister to table the document if she wants to save cluttering up the record. The document is of no assistance to me. In the Estimates Committee C hearing Senator Richardson said:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . I hope you do not jump to making any conclusion out of the figures. The real test will be how many people were put on or kept in employment as a result of the money that we outlaid, and we will know the answers to that at the conclusion of the program when a proper review has been completed.

For Senator Richardson to say that we will know how many people were put on and kept in employment, I assume that will require an analysis or evaluation of all the councils which received money. That will ascertain how many people were put on or kept in employment, or was Senator Richardson not telling me the truth? I am sure he would not do that.

TALKER.NAME: Senator CROWLEY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Family Services and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased that Senator Macdonald made that closing comment. The advice I have just given the honourable senator stands. The seriousness of this evaluation is understood by government, and I am quite sure that the officers will be paying keen attention to Senator Macdonald's comments and taking them into account in their deliberations.
—Is the Minister confirming what Senator Richardson said and that I will be told of the numbers employed or kept in employment as a result of this program?
—I am advised that is correct.
—We were debating program 6. I see that Senator Macdonald had certain reservations. Therefore, if he wishes to take any of subprograms 6.1, 6.3 and 6.4, that would be satisfactory.

—The cleaning of the statues at the Australian Institute of Sport comes under subprogram 6.1 in a roundabout way. According to subprogram 6.1, the National Capital Planning Authority is actually divesting itself of $35,000 which it theretofore had spent on the cleaning of six statues at the Institute of Sport. Mention is made that this expenditure is no longer in the authority's program. The $35,000 is picked up in the estimates of the Institute of Sport. So on one side it goes out and on the other side it comes in. Regardless of the accounting refinements, it really means that at some stage along the line $35,000 was allocated to clean and maintain six bronze type statues at the Institute of Sport. I have since had a look at those statues. They are about life size. To an inexperienced eye, they are quite well done. They look to be good statues. But I still cannot see how one could spend $6,000 per annum cleaning and maintaining each of those statues.
—Some people do not have that much to spend on their houses.

—As my colleague Senator Patterson says, some people do not spend that much on maintaining their house in a year, let alone on some statues. I suspect that the Minister will not be able to give me an answer now, but could she possibly tell me for how long those statues at the Institute of Sport have been cleaned and maintained by the NCPA; when they were erected; and the total cost of cleaning and maintaining the statues since they were erected? Just for comparison's sake, would it be asking too much to try to get an indication of what the initial cost of those statues was when they were installed?

TALKER.NAME: Senator CROWLEY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Family Services and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women)

TALK.START.PARA: —With Senator Macdonald's concurrence, I think it would be best to take all those questions on notice. The detail is not really available.

—I would appreciate it if I could have that information. The other question I have in relation to subprogram 6.1, and which I mentioned before, is the valuation of the Lobby Restaurant. Is that now available? It was supposedly due on 21 May?

TALKER.NAME: Senator CROWLEY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Family Services and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am advised that the Australian Valuation Office values the building in its current condition at $170,000. The Australian Valuation Office also estimates the cost of replacement at $400,000 to $500,000.

—I should say for the record that some other questions I asked are claimed to be commercial-in-confidence. I have inspected the restaurant and had a talk to the owner, and I am satisfied with the information that has been given. But I was curious as to the value. The value of the property appears to be $400,000 with $170,000 for the building. That is a $570,000 investment in the name of the Commonwealth for which the Commonwealth receives a rental. It is, as you would remember, Mr Temporary Chairman, a building steeped in history. It should, I suspect, be maintained as part of the old parliamentary precincts because of the history and the meetings that were held there back in a more turbulent time of our parliamentary history. But I thank the Minister for that information.

PARA.TAB: I have noted my reservation on the next matter, which relates to subprogram 6.3, and I do have a couple of questions. However, I understand that my colleague Senator Patterson would also like to ask some questions on that subprogram, and to show that chivalry is not dead I will concede to her.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to ask Senator Crowley whether the report in the Canberra Times on 20 May that contracts for matching grants to voluntary agencies' Christmas appeals were signed on 11 December 1992 was correct. I would like the Minister for Family Services to confirm whether or not they were signed on that date, because that is what was reported in the Canberra Times.

TALKER.NAME: Senator CROWLEY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Family Services and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am advised that the report in the Canberra Times was wrong. The contracts were sent out on 21 December and signed, I am advised, as they could be after that date and before Christmas.

—I want to know whether that was the information given to the Canberra Times by Senator Crowley's spokesperson, as was reported in the Canberra Times, or whether the Canberra Times was wrong. I do not know whether the Minister's advisers can tell her but her spokesperson should be able to tell her that. I also ask whether the advertisement that appeared on 12 December provided any indication that the Government would match only funds that were spent over a designated period of time.

TALKER.NAME: Senator CROWLEY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Family Services and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am advised that the Canberra Times made the error and that the advertisement did not specify—I am sorry, what was the question?

—The question I asked the Minister is the very question I asked her in the chamber the other day. I thought that the Minister would have got on top of this in the intervening time. The question I asked was whether the advertisement provided any indication of whether the Government would match only funds that were spent over a designated period of time.
—The answer to that is no.

—Is the Minister telling me that the agencies received their application forms on 21 December? I remind the Minister that, in answer to a question on 20 May, she said that the department started sending out application forms to agencies on 14 December. I ask whether or not that is correct. The Minister has just mentioned the date of 21 December yet she told the Senate on 20 May that the date was 14 December. When were the application forms sent out? Did they all go out on the 21st or did some go out on the 14th? Could the Minister clarify that? When the agencies read the clause in the agreement that the money to be matched was money spent over a specified period rather than all moneys raised by appeal, was that the first time they would have been aware of that condition?

TALKER.NAME: Senator CROWLEY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Family Services and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women)

TALK.START.PARA: —The advertisements were placed on 12 December. Very soon after that the relevant people sought information and they were advised that the Government's offer referred to money raised and money spent. From 14 December application forms and eligibility criteria were forwarded, generally by fax, to all agencies indicating an interest. It was the grant offers, including the conditions of contract, that went out on 21 December.

—I presume that unless they specifically asked, they would only have known when they got the guidelines. The Prime Minister (Mr Keating) had made a statement on the Sunday program indicating that it was moneys collected by these major organisations during their Christmas appeals. In his two press releases on 6 December and 11 December he said the Government would match money raised during the Christmas appeals. The press release of 11 December detailed the organisations that would be eligible, but there was nothing about the fact that it was money spent over a specified time. What action did the Government take to inform the donors to these major organisations that the situation was not as it had been expressed in the Prime Minister's press releases or in his interview with Laurie Oakes on 6 December?

TALKER.NAME: Senator CROWLEY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Family Services and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women)

TALK.START.PARA: —The first part of the question asked when people became aware of the dollars raised and dollars spent. I cannot speak for the awareness of people, but I do know that very soon after that advertisement was placed—and certainly from 14 December—people could have been advised of the eligibility criteria if they had sought them. I cannot say when it was in the minds of anybody.

PARA.TAB: It was very clear to people that this was concerned with the Christmas appeal, and was designed to address the material needs of people over Christmas time. The Prime Minister was speaking on this matter and that statement was included in his press release. The contributions at Christmas show that people in this country have an extraordinary characteristic: a remarkable propensity for generously putting their hands in their pockets. They do that at Christmas, they do it in winter; they do it all the time. Over the weekend we saw the extraordinary generosity of people in response to the Salvation Army appeal.

At Christmas time Australians are very aware of needy people, and they are prepared to put their hands in their pockets and make a contribution. I think when people were making that contribution they were not doing anything more than they do every other time. They were making their contribution to make sure that other people had a share in the benefits of Christmas.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister has not answered my question. I asked what action did the Government take to ensure that the public understood the conditions under which they were donating. People expressed concern to me that they gave on the basis that the Government would match their donations dollar for dollar. They may still have donated but should have known the terms and conditions. The advertisement does not give them any clear idea. It says, `Only cash donations will be matched and eligible organisations will. . . ', and it goes on. If I had read the advertisement in the newspaper, that is the impression I would have got. If I had heard Mr Keating on the Sunday program, that is the impression I would have got. If I had read news reports that emanated from the two press releases that the Prime Minister gave, that is the impression I would have got.

PARA.TAB: It appears to me that the Government made no attempt whatsoever to advise the public that that was not the case. It would be interesting to know when the decision was made to impose the condition that the offer referred to dollars spent over a specified period. If that was made known after the advertisements and after the Prime Minister's press releases, that might place a slightly different colour on it, but not totally. When was the decision made to match only those dollars spent? Or was that decision made before the advertisements were placed and before the Prime Minister issued his press releases?

TALKER.NAME: Senator CROWLEY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Family Services and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women)

TALK.START.PARA: —There is really not much more that can be said. I think most Australians understood the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) when he made that statement. Over and above the near enough to $20 million which this Government gives to emergency relief organisations for their ongoing good works and concern for people, the Prime Minister was prepared to say, `Look, at this Christmas time, because Australians are the sorts of people they are, let's make sure that those in need over the Christmas period are offered extra help through our preparedness to assist the Christmas appeal'. I really cannot add much more to the detailed answers that I have already given the honourable senator.
—I ask the Minister: who made the decision to match those dollars spent over a designated period and when was that decision made?

—I am advised it was always clear that this money was to be raised and provided over Christmas for material needs. That has been the statement all along. It was always understood that it was not dollars contributed by Government to assist with the administration or the ongoing work—the tremendous work—of the voluntary agencies. It was a specific addition to the Christmas appeal: for material aid spent, for cash contributions, for Christmas hampers and for those things that were needed at Christmas time. It was always understood that if people were going to provide material needs at Christmas it meant just that.

—Thank you. The Minister has confirmed exactly what I thought: that in fact she knew all along that it was material aid spent, not dollars raised. There is a very big difference in the amount of money those charities will get as a result of that. Senator Crowley had the hide to stand up and tell me today that in fact the Government and the Prime Minister knew—the Prime Minister ought to have known when he appeared on that program with Laurie Oakes and said that it was money collected. What he should have said was that all the aid given during a specified period—money raised in the Christmas appeal and used during that specified period; spent not on administration, but on aid—would be matched by the Government dollar for dollar. That would have been a clear and unequivocal message to the public about what was going on.

PARA.TAB: What the Prime Minister said was not clear. What he said deceived the donors of Australia and, initially, deceived the major organisations. They were enlightened as they got further into it. They were quite surprised, let me tell you—very grateful for the money, but surprised. It also placed enormous administrative burdens on them to try to spend that money over that period of time.

But that is not what the public understood. The Prime Minister and this Government deceived the Australian public. The Minister has just confirmed that by telling us that she knew all along that it was money to be spent on material aid over a specified period of time. It was not what was expressed in either of the Prime Minister's press statements or on the program with Laurie Oakes. As I said before, I find it despicable that in the Christmas period the Government would dupe the Australian public, the donors.

TALK.START.PARA: —Oh!
—Do not say `Oh' to me like that, Senator Richardson.
—Why not?

—They might be the sorts of tactics that are used in the right wing of the Labor Party in New South Wales. The Government duped the Australian public. The public gave donations on the basis that they would be matched dollar for dollar, and the Government lied to them. That is what it did. It lied and deceived the Australian public. But half of those on the government side would not know truth from fiction—and this was a fiction. The Government duped the Australian public and it is absolutely appalling. In relation to the St Vincent de Paul winter appeal, Senator Crowley told us on 19 May that the Government had matched the dollars raised by these charities. Is that so?

TALKER.NAME: Senator CROWLEY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Family Services and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women)

TALK.START.PARA: —(6.15 p.m.)—I quite object to and differ with Senator Patterson's suggestion that I or the Government have misled people. It is very clear—
—The public will make up their minds.

—I do not wish to claim that how Senator Patterson understands things is how I understand them, but the people of Australia have their own view. They have made it quite clear that they were prepared to welcome this contribution at Christmas for people in need. That is really all that needs to be said about it.

—I asked Senator Crowley: did she tell the people at the launch of the St Vincent de Paul winter appeal that the Government matched, dollar for dollar, the money raised by these charities during the Christmas appeal?

—It is an interesting thing that Senator Patterson should ask. I was actually at a celebration where people very much involved in assisting this Government to provide care and relief for people were only too pleased to have the Government there launching the winter appeal. What I might do is refer to my notes, in as much as I have notes of what I have said, and see whether I did say exactly that.
—Senator Crowley told us in the chamber, in answer to a question asked by Senator Reynolds, that is what she said.
—Did I?
—Did she say it? That is the question. Now she cannot even say what she said without a brief. Heavens above!
—Mr Temporary Chairman, can we join in the conversation or is it private?
—Order! I am about to call Senator Crowley.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crowley Sen The Hon R.A.

TALKER.NAME: Senator CROWLEY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Family Services and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women)

TALK.START.PARA: —I have a Hansard record here. What it tells me that I said is:

SPEECH.PARA: As I said in this place last week, when I was asked to launch the winter appeal for St Vincent de Paul a couple of weeks ago, I was able to say then that yes, the Government had matched those dollars of the Christmas appeal—that is, dollars raised by the major non-government organisations.

TALK.START.PARA: —So Senator Crowley continues to perpetuate the falsehood that what the Government did was match dollar for dollar the money raised. How much money would the Government have paid if it had matched dollar for dollar all the money raised by these charities in the Christmas appeals?

TALKER.NAME: Senator CROWLEY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Family Services and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women)

TALK.START.PARA: —I will have to take the final part of that on notice. The Government, in agreement with the organisations, after signing contracts in December, provided a certain amount of money that related to the amount already raised by appeals up to 11 December.There was an estimate made of what those organisations expected to raise between 11 December and 31 December. There is also a finalisation of that money upon acquittal of the actual money expended. Some of those final acquittals are in but many of them are still not finalised, so I cannot give Senator Patterson a detailed answer on that at this stage.

—Could the Minister take on notice these questions: how much money would the Government have paid if it had matched dollar for dollar the money raised by these charities in their Christmas appeals, and how much did the Government provide as a result of the Prime Minister's promise—the details of which were not really revealed to the Australian public—to match the money spent over a specified period in regard to money raised during the Christmas appeal?

PARA.TAB: I want to know the difference between the amount of money raised by all those organisations in their appeals and the amount of money that they actually spent on material aid, and therefore that the Government matched dollar for dollar. That is on notice and, as soon as that data is available, I would appreciate it if Senator Crowley could provide it to all honourable senators.

TALK.START.PARA: —This subprogram was a compassionate one, and I think most Australians agreed with it. Most Australians recoiled a bit from the fact that Mr Keating was trying to say to people, just curiously in that pre-election period, that it was his money. It was being suggested that the Government was being good and giving it over, but it was the Australian taxpayer who was giving it and the Australian taxpayer would give it quite willingly in a voluntary capacity.

PARA.TAB: As the Minister for Family Services (Senator Crowley) quite rightly said, the Australian public is renowned for its generosity in helping people less fortunate than themselves and, as I said, in many instances they give voluntarily. They would not mind giving it through the tax system if only they were not helping an election campaign by doing so. I wonder whether the Minister could indicate if the need for the compassion that was evident in December of 1992 is still there.

TALKER.NAME: Senator CROWLEY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Family Services and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women)

TALK.START.PARA: —One thing that is very clear is that, however we measure the criteria, need is special around Christmas time. That is precisely what the Government and the voluntary agencies recognise each year. The agencies certainly recognise this need each year in their Christmas appeals, as does the Government in its ongoing commitment to emergency relief.

PARA.TAB: I have launched one winter appeal; Premier Kennett was reported the other day as launching another appeal; and at the weekend the Salvation Army, recognising that as winter comes on people have perhaps even a very simple need for blankets, conducted its doorknock. Many appeals are called blanket appeals. There are two peaks of special need that the voluntary agencies particularly focus on.

TALK.START.PARA: —In relation to the winter appeals—one of which the Minister opened, Premier Kennett's appeal and the Salvation Army appeal that the Minister referred to—is the Commonwealth going to match that dollar for dollar, either on receipts or on expenditure? I do not want to pursue Senator Patterson's point any further.
—No.
—So the Government will not match with Commonwealth funds this appeal. What is the difference?

TALKER.NAME: Senator CROWLEY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Family Services and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women)

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not think that the question is properly asked as what is the difference. As I said before, in 1992-93 the ongoing expenditure for emergency relief to assist the work of the agencies is about $20 million. That is a recognition by government of the way the voluntary agencies enormously assist in that process of delivering aid and in its ongoing care for people in those sorts of circumstances. At Christmas time, as is recognised by the agencies themselves, their Christmas appeals strike a particular chord in people.
—Especially when an election is coming.

—I think Senator Panizza's interjection has been made before during questions. During Question Time in the Senate, I made it clear that one could not conclude that way. The appeal was proposed in mid-December and, as I said, it was to conclude by 31 January.

PARA.TAB: The agencies especially requested an extension of time to 31 March to allow them to fully acquit the dollars raised, and the Government was very pleased to accept that extension. I suppose one could have said the Government did not have to do that, but it did want to assist as much as possible in the giving of aid to needy people at Christmas time. That decision was made on 29 January, which was well outside any election commitment. We also have to recognise the excellent work the voluntary agencies are doing, and it is being done in conjunction with the excellent welfare system that this Government has established.

One would have to be concerned about what might have been the effect of Fightback on the very people we are concerned about here. Many millions of dollars would have been taken away from those people. They would have benefited much less. I am certainly very clear that we are principally acknowledging the generosity of Australian people at Christmas time; that generosity was remarkable given the time. It is also very useful to acknowledge the generosity of this Government and the best combination we have—the private or non-government agencies in conjunction with the Government's welfare system.
Progress reported.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I table a letter from the Department of Health, Housing, Local Government and Community Services which has just been received by the Estimates Committee C secretariat which relates to a correction to additional information received by Estimates Committee C.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Transport and Communications)

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek the leave of the Senate to table a document and to make a very short statement.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I advised the Senate some time ago that I had made a formal request to the secretary to my department, the Department of Transport and Communications, to provide advice to me on the question of the tender processes in terms of his account of it and what he proposes to do in respect of redressing the problem. I gave an undertaking to the Senate that I would table that advice from the secretary as soon as it was made available to me. It is now available to me and, in accordance with the undertaking I gave to the Senate, I table the document.

DEBATE.TITLE: APPROPRIATION BILL (No. 5) 1992-93SUPPLY BILL (No. 1) 1993-94APPROPRIATION (PARLIAMENTARY DEPARTMENTS) BILL (No. 2) 1992-93APPROPRIATION BILL (No. 6) 1992-93SUPPLY (PARLIAMENTARY DEPARTMENTS) BILL 1993-94SUPPLY BILL (No. 2) 1993-94

PARA.TAB: Consideration resumed.

TALK.START.PARA: —The committee is considering Appropriation Bill (No. 5) 1992-93 and the motion moved by the Minister for Defence for the report of Estimates Committee C to be adopted. When the Bill was last considered, the committee was considering subprogram 6.3 relating to the Department of Health, Housing, Local Government and Community Services. The question is that the motion be agreed to.
—I ask the Minister for Family Services: what funds did the Government give to the Christmas appeal of 1991?

TALKER.NAME: Senator CROWLEY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Family Services and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not exactly sure what Senator Macdonald's question means. If it means matched funds for the Christmas appeal, as in the 1992 appeal, I am advised that no officer here knows of any extra contribution apart from the emergency relief funds that were given in 1991.

—Just before we broke for dinner, the Minister finished in a flourish with a long dissertation about the tragedy of people needing that relief, with which I agree. I think the Minister also went on to say how generous the Australian people are, with which I agree. She then went on to say how generous the Government is, with which I do not agree. The Government is pretty good at spending other people's money.

PARA.TAB: The Minister gave that dissertation in response to a question, to which I did not really get the answer. I was asking her to explain—in fairly simple words because I am a fairly simple person—the Government's difference in thinking. She indicated that the Government had given about $14 million for the Christmas appeal around December 1992. She indicated that she had just opened a winter appeal for the Salvation Army, that Mr Kennett had opened an appeal and that there were other appeals running. I was asking her to explain in fairly simple words what the difference is, in the Government's view, between the Christmas appeal of 1992 and the winter appeal of May-June 1993. What different feelings or approaches does the Government have to those two appeals?

TALKER.NAME: Senator CROWLEY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Family Services and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women)

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to correct what Senator Macdonald said. I think he said that $14 million was given in December. That is not correct. An amount of $8.75 million has been given and there is an expectation of at least another $3 1/2 million. I have also said that those figures cannot be exact until the final acquittals are in.

PARA.TAB: As to the rest of Senator Macdonald's question, more than enough has been said about emergency relief. I will not try to hypothesise what is in the so-called mind of the Government. The intention was quite clear: recognising that people like to contribute, the Christmas appeal was matched by the Government last Christmas. Also appreciating that in these tough times there are a number of people who would not have the opportunities they might otherwise have at Christmas, the Government decided to make the offer that it did.

As I said before, it will also make roughly—I do not have the exact figure and I would rather Senator Macdonald did not hold me to it—$20 million this year in contributions to emergency relief for the ongoing care that the voluntary agencies provide. It is a matter of great generosity. The emergency relief picks up and assists the Government in its concern about people in need. More than enough has been said about this matter. I do not believe that there is much point in trawling over it further.

TALK.START.PARA: —I understand what the Minister says about Christmas. It is a happy time. Just because people are down and out, mainly as a result of her Government's action, it is appropriate that the rest of Australia tries to give them something. In case the Minister has not noticed, it is absolutely freezing outside at the moment. For people without a house or any clothes or blankets, it is pretty hard to get by.The Government added some money to the appeal at Christmas. Why will it not add some money over and above the $20 million that is normally given to this winter appeal?

TALKER.NAME: Senator CROWLEY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Family Services and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women)

TALK.START.PARA: —I can only reiterate that this year the Government is spending $20 million or thereabouts on emergency relief. That compares to the $2.5 million that was being spent when we came into office in 1983.

PARA.TAB: Opposition senators—Ha, ha!

TALK.START.PARA: —It compares very extensively with that. Opposition senators laugh. I am afraid that I do not wish to address whatever it is that they are laughing at. I do not think emergency relief is a matter for laughter or fun. Emergency relief is something to which this Government is very seriously committed. As I said, the Government is providing something like $20 million towards ongoing emergency relief. In the course of events, that is expected to provide assistance along with the huge contributions made by people during these appeals, such as the winter appeals.

PARA.TAB: I do not really quite understand what Senator Macdonald is asking. If he is making some kind of cheap point, I do not know what he expects to get out of it. What is at issue is whether this Government is serious about providing assistance through emergency relief. It is. It has put out the dollars; it is providing a massive contribution towards helping those who are in need at this time. It addresses the question of the needs of people seasonally, if you like—the special needs that people feel at Christmas and, of course, the needs of winter time. That ongoing emergency relief is committed. I do not think I can add anything further at this time.

TALK.START.PARA: —If the Government is serious about providing emergency relief, as the Minister indicates it is, can she tell me what her bid for the Christmas appeal in 1993 is in the Budget discussions?

TALKER.NAME: Senator CROWLEY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Family Services and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women)

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Macdonald knows that that question is quite inappropriate. I will certainly make no comment about what is in the Budget.
—Can we assume that there will be at least $12 million in the Budget for the 1993 appeal, the same as there was for the 1992 Christmas appeal?
—We are looking at the Additional Estimates, but we are straying from them a little.

TALKER.NAME: Senator CROWLEY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Family Services and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women)

TALK.START.PARA: —Thank you, Mr Chairman. I am assisted by your comments. I am not making any comments about any assumptions.

—The Minister had to call on the assistance of Senator Richardson earlier. I do not think the Government is genuine about emergency relief. It has provided some money. There was a Christmas appeal in 1992. There are officially one million people unemployed; the Minister knows that there are a lot more. There are a lot of people without homes and there are a lot of people without food. That situation existed at Christmas of 1992 because of what the Minister's Government has done.

PARA.TAB: I ask the Minister to look at the present. It is a very cold winter. Compared with last year, there are as many people, if not more, out of work. There is the same number of people, if not more, without houses and clothes—and they need more clothes—and there are appeals. The people of Australia will give to the Christmas appeal and to the winter appeal. Can the Minister tell me the difference between the situation at Christmas and the situation now, and the difference between the appeals of Christmas and now? Why will the Minister not say to me what the Government is going to give for Christmas in 1993? I just want the Minister to make a commitment to the people who rely on the appeals that they will get some relief in 1993.

I and a great many people in Australia think that the Minister's Government is an absolute fraud. It will play with people's lives and with our money in a period before election time. There was only one difference between the Christmas appeal of 1991, the Christmas appeal of 1992 and the current winter appeal. The only thing that encouraged Mr Keating to give more money in Christmas of 1992 was that he knew there was to be an election within three months.

If the Minister cannot tell me why the Government is not giving the same additional amount per dollar over and above the $20 million that apparently is normally allocated, why the Government is not giving an additional amount of money now in the winter appeal, and guarantee me that there will be some provision in the Budget for additional funding for Christmas of 1993, it will not be just my opinion—the rest of the people of Australia will be well within their rights to agree with me—that this Government is nothing but a fraud and uses welfare agencies and the money given out to people in need of welfare simply for its own very crass political purposes.

TALK.START.PARA: —I indicated earlier that we were looking at the Additional Estimates and that questions in relation to the next Budget are not in order. I will call the Minister if she wishes to make any response.

TALKER.NAME: Senator CROWLEY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Family Services and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women)

TALK.START.PARA: —Thank you, Mr Chairman. You have actually outlined the answer. The essence of the answer to that question really is that they are matters for the next Budget.
—Why can the Minister not guarantee some money out of this Budget or out of these estimates for the winter appeal?
—I call the Minister.
—I assume from the Minister's non-response that she does not intend to answer. Mr Chairman, I think you have nicely assisted the Minister, as well you should—

—Order! Take a seat. Senator Macdonald, do not cast aspersions on my integrity in the chair. I am looking after the procedures of the committee. I am not looking after any particular person in the chamber.

—I agree with you, Mr Chairman. That is what I just said: `as you should'. It is your duty to look after the proceedings and make sure they are carried out properly. I do not disagree with you at all. But the fact that the Minister is unable, incapable, too embarrassed—or has just that shred of decency in her which means that she is not going to lie further to the Australian public as a member of the Government—
—Order! Senator Macdonald, you know quite well that that is definitely out of order. If you continue like that, I will not call you. I ask you to stand and withdraw that comment about lying.
—I withdraw that comment about lying, Mr Chairman, as you direct. I will say that the Government, of which this Minister is a member, has spent the election telling lies—
—You will not say that either. You will not use the term `lies' in this chamber.
—Mr Chairman, I do not intend to have an argument with you over that, so I will not say it, if you say I will not. But during the campaign this Government told mistruth after mistruth—

—You cannot camouflage your allegations about lying by talking about mistruths. If you like, I can refer you to a statement made by President McMullin on 31 October 1967 in the Senate, a statement by me on 15 October 1991 in the Senate, a statement by President Sibraa on 9 December 1992, and a statement by President Sibraa on 14 December 1992. If you look at those particular references, you will see that you cannot camouflage your suggestions about lying by using other words that are similar. I ask you to get on with your question.

—Mr Chairman, I would be grateful for your further assistance. What do I say when people—that is, members of the Labor Party—go out and say one thing that they know is not correct, deliberately telling the people of Australia things that they know are not correct? Is there some way I can encompass that in a speech in this Parliament? Are there some words I can use?
—You just have.

—It is going to take a long time if I have to use three sentences to say each thing that I want to say. If the Minister cannot assure me that there is money in this appropriation for the winter appeal, I will say again that her Government, the Government of which she is a member, is a fraud and uses people in destitute circumstances for crass political purposes. As with many other things her party did before the election, members of this Government will go out and tell people one thing when they know quite well that it is not accurate. It applies so much to these proceedings. The Minister's refusal to answer my questions in this regard simply puts fact to the statement I have made.

TALKER.NAME: Senator CROWLEY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Family Services and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women)

TALK.START.PARA: —I have grave doubts about Senator Macdonald's last comment about assuring him that there is money in these appropriations for something or other. I thought the whole point of being here was to debate what was clearly designated for these appropriations. If Senator Macdonald has that wrong, I take his abuse across this chamber as nothing more than some childish display.

PARA.TAB: Most of these comments do nothing but bring some discredit to the extraordinary generosity of the people of Australia and also on those voluntary agencies who have been very pleased to cooperate with government in this matter, appreciating just how they can assist people in need. I do not believe that the emergency relief program or the work of the voluntary agencies is in any way edified by those last contributions.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not want to get into this debate totally, but I would like to pick up some of the statements the Minister just made.
