My colleague Senator Macdonald was simply trying to ascertain why the Minister does not have anything in this appropriation, dollar for dollar, for the winter appeal. She does not want to answer, and that is her prerogative. Before that, he was just trying to ascertain why the Government supposedly decided to match the funds raised by the benevolent societies in the Christmas of 1992 but did not do it in 1991.

PARA.TAB: I could draw two conclusions from the Minister's non-answer. The first is that from Christmas 1991 to Christmas 1992 the economy dropped away so badly that the Government had to match those donations; or that the Government simply used that allocation in the Christmas of 1992—and the Minister is not giving us an undertaking as to 1993—to shore up its chances at the Federal election. That is exactly what my colleague Senator Macdonald has been trying to extract from the Minister. The Minister should answer him so that we can carry on with the rest of the appropriations. As soon as she answers, we will carry on.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Chairman, I wonder if you could answer a question regarding your ruling of a moment ago?

—As to my ruling of a moment ago, I will read out the references and Senator Walters can look them up. Statement by President McMullin on 31 October 1967; statement by me on 15 October 1991; statement by President Sibraa on 9 December 1992; and statement by President Sibraa on 14 December 1992. If Senator Walters would like to look up those statements, she will discover the reason for my ruling.

—Mr Chairman, I ask you a question regarding your ruling of a moment ago. Are you saying that we cannot say the Government—not an individual but the Government—has lied? I would say that word has been used in this place since the election at least 300 times. I was wondering whether that was the effect of your ruling.
—Well, it will not be used 301 times while I am in the chair.
—Mr Chairman, you are making a specific ruling that no-one in this chamber can say that the Government lied.
—I have answered your question, Senator Walters. Take a seat.
—That is a new ruling, Mr Chairman.
—Are there any more questions on subprogram 6.3?

—Yes, Mr Chairman. When the Minister launched the winter appeal for St Vincent de Paul, did she represent the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) on that occasion and, if so, did she read a statement from the Prime Minister. If she did, would she be prepared to give the Senate a copy of that statement?

TALKER.NAME: Senator CROWLEY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Family Services and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women)

TALK.START.PARA: —As my memory serves me, I believe that I had a message from the Prime Minister. I will see if there is anything further I can find out for the honourable senator on that.

—I would not risk making a psychological diagnosis, but surely—I do not know when it was, but it was not very long ago when the Prime Minister launched the appeal—Senator Crowley would remember whether she represented the Prime Minister or whether she just had a message from the Prime Minister. If she did have a message from the Prime Minister, did she read that message? Can she tell me that or can she not remember that?
—I will check the facts for the honourable senator.
—Is the Minister telling me that she cannot remember whether she read a statement or whether she made a speech on her own behalf? Is that what she is telling me?
—I have said that I will check the facts for the honourable senator.

—Could the Minister please tell me when she will give me that information? I would like an answer to my question before I can be satisfied that Estimates Committee C has been dealt with appropriately. Can I have an answer from the Minister?
—I am sorry; I thought I was indicating across the chamber to Senator Patterson that I will do that as soon as I can.

—Does `as soon as I can' mean before we have completed these estimates? I would like to know. I do not want Estimates Committee C completed until I have an answer to whether the Minister when reading a statement was representing the Prime Minister and to whether she is prepared to give us that statement.
—I am here with no way of actually pursuing this matter, so I will do it as soon as I can.

—I am still not satisfied, Mr Chairman. I would not be satisfied to move on from Estimates Committee C, or at least adopt the report of Estimates Committee C, until I had an assurance that I will have an answer before we rise this evening.

—Are there any questions in relation to subprogram 6.4 or program 7, particularly subprogram 7.2? If not, the committee will move to the Department of Social Security. The first matter is all questions taken on notice before and during the committee's hearings, for which answers had not been received prior to 18 May 1993. Are there any questions in that area?

—I placed a question on notice in which I asked the department to give me a comparison of the annual cost of the old voucher system for telephone rental and postal concessions and the estimated annual cost of the new telephone allowance. In the answer provided, the department gave me the estimated expenditure on telephone allowances for 1992-93. That is not the question I asked. I repeat: I asked for a comparison of the annual cost of the old voucher system and the estimated annual cost of the new telephone allowance.

TALKER.NAME: Senator CROWLEY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Family Services and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am advised that in 1991-92 the department spent $47.7 million on vouchers and in 1992-93 it is estimated that it will spend $57.4 million on telephone rental.

—Are there any further questions in relation to questions taken on notice? If not, we will move to the non-program specific variations. We will proceed according to the running sheet. The first matter is compensation through the extension of fringe benefits.
—I ask the Minister: was the decision to extend fringe benefits to all pensioners a unilateral decision by the Commonwealth or was it a joint decision made with the States?

TALKER.NAME: Senator CROWLEY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Family Services and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am advised that the Commonwealth Government took that decision in the Budget context.
—I asked the Minister whether that decision made in the Budget context was a Commonwealth decision or a decision made jointly with the States.
—I am advised that that was a Commonwealth Budget decision taken by the Commonwealth Government. It did follow some discussions with the State welfare Ministers.

—Has the Commonwealth given any commitment that it will fund any or all of this extension of State and local government fringe benefits beyond 30 June 1993? Did the Commonwealth promise the States that it would provide 100 per cent compensation for this extension of State and local government fringe benefits? For how long was this commitment?

TALKER.NAME: Senator CROWLEY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Family Services and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am advised that the Government has promised to cover 100 per cent of the costs up to 30 June and it has already committed $70 million in the Budget in Forward Estimates for further costs against fringe benefits. The matter of further sums is to be negotiated with the States at the soon to occur Council of Australian Governments.

—Does the extension of these fringe benefits beyond June 1993 mean that the State and local governments will have to fund the loss of revenue or the difference between the $70 million and what the overall cost will be? Victoria has estimated that its cost will be $45 million in one year.

TALKER.NAME: Senator CROWLEY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Family Services and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women)

TALK.START.PARA: —I perhaps did not make it clear, but I said that that is a matter to be negotiated with the States.

—If the States are unable to meet this, does this mean that the Government will not be able to meet its promise of extending fringe benefits to all those to whom that is now available beyond June 1993?
—There is really nothing I can add to what I have said already. This is a matter to be negotiated with the States. I can give no further comment than that.
—Could the Minister tell us what the Commonwealth's estimate is of the additional money that will be required to provide the 100 per cent compensation for the extension until 30 June.
—That is also a matter to be negotiated with the States.

—The Minister has just said that the Government would provide 100 per cent of the costs of the extension—no negotiation with the States—until June 1993. She must have an estimate of what that is. What is that estimate?
—I am advised that that matter is currently being worked on between the relevant Ministers of the Commonwealth and the States and it is not yet finalised.

—Does the Minister mean that the Government made a commitment and has no estimate of the cost of that commitment? Is it right that the Government has committed 100 per cent of the extension of those fringe benefits until June 1993 and cannot give me an estimate of what the cost will be for this period up until June 1993?
—I am advised that the best estimate was $17.5 million. The final details are currently being negotiated between the States and the Commonwealth and a report is being prepared.
—Can the Minister advise the committee what the Victorian Government has spent to date?
—No.
—Is it not the fact that the figure of $22 million has been bandied around and that the Victorian State Government is estimating that it will cost $45 million?

TALKER.NAME: Senator CROWLEY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Family Services and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am advised that figures of the sort that the honourable senator has quoted are figures prepared by the Victorian Government from its own estimates. They are not the figures under consideration by the Commonwealth and the States in this matter.

—That is because they would be well in excess of what the Government has guesstimated. It seems to me that the Minister will have to yet again tell the Australian public, especially the older people and pensioners, `We are sorry, we actually did not tell you the facts before the election; we told you something else'—I am not allowed to say `We lied'—in our brochures. We told you that we were going to take you out of the tax system by 1995 but, dear me, that was an error in our platform. We should have said five days after the election that we had something different in mind'. The public should be told that the Government cannot fulfil its promise to extend fringe benefits because it cannot get the States and local governments to come to the party.

PARA.TAB: The Government also did not make allowance for the fact that a lot of people would now apply for fringe benefits or a pension who perhaps would not have applied before because the amounts involved were fairly minimal. With the carrot of fringe benefits, they have decided it might now be worth while to make the effort to do the paperwork. There are all sorts of other reasons why the guesstimates might be out. I hope it does not come to it, but I guess that the Minister will have to tell the Australian public that the Government does not have the money for yet another promise and will have to face pensioners and older people with yet another broken promise.

TALKER.NAME: Senator CROWLEY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Family Services and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women)

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not understand how Senator Patterson can conclude as she has. It is mere hypothesis; it takes absolutely no account of the question she had previously put and the answer I had given. Those matters are currently being negotiated between the States and the Commonwealth and it is very presumptuous to make conclusions at this time.
—I ask the Minister whether it was a pre-election promise to extend fringe benefits to all part-pensioners from April 1993 by giving them a discount on council rates.

TALKER.NAME: Senator CROWLEY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Family Services and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am advised that in the Budget the Government promised to extend the fringe benefit cards to all pensioners. As I understand it, Senator Macdonald wanted to know whether that included local government rates. That is a matter for local government and the States to determine, not the Commonwealth.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macdonald Sen I.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I see that the Minister is asking the public servants. I was asking her about an ALP policy matter related to these estimates. The document that I have in front of me states:

SPEECH.PARA: From April this year retirees who receive as little as one dollar per week in pension will also be eligible for the full range of Commonwealth and State provided fringe benefits for services such as hearing aids, electricity—
and the one I am interested in—
rates and transport.

I am reading from the ALP policy document, Policies for Older Australians. I ask the Minister to confirm whether the Government promised retirees and part pensioners that from April 1993 they would have a discount on their rates. Did the Government make that promise? I do not know that the Minister will get the answer from public servants; it was the Government's policy.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crowley Sen The Hon R.A.

TALKER.NAME: Senator CROWLEY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Family Services and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women)

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not have in front of me the Labor Party document that the honourable senator is referring to but—
—Would you like a look at it?

—Not yet, thank you. I thank the honourable senator for the offer. Did the statement use the words `these benefits include'? On my understanding, that does not mean that one can conclude that they are therefore all definitely to be part of the promise. If there is something that is troubling

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Macdonald, perhaps he could make it clearer?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macdonald Sen I.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I repeat what it says:

SPEECH.PARA: From April this year retirees who receive as little one dollar per week in pension will also be eligible for the full range of Commonwealth and State provided fringe benefits for services such as hearing aids, electricity, rates and transport.

I will ask the attendant to take that over to the Minister. That is from the ALP policy document. Can the Minister confirm for me that that is what the ALP—the current Government—did promise at the federal election?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crowley Sen The Hon R.A.

TALKER.NAME: Senator CROWLEY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Family Services and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women)

TALK.START.PARA: —Much as I can take this paper to be what it claims to be—and I do not suspect it is not—it says on the top in somebody's handwriting that it is the ALP policy document, and it is obviously a faxed piece of paper. I am assisted, and maybe the committee would be, by a copy of a letter I have here that probably makes all this clearer. It is a letter from the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) to the Premier of New South Wales, Mr Fahey. It states:

SPEECH.PARA: My dear Premier,

At the December 1992 meeting of the Council of Australian Governments Premier and Chief Ministers agreed to extend State and Territory concessions to all pensioners and certain other groups from 1 April 1993 and to accept the Commonwealth's offer of financial assistance in 1992-93 with the cost of this extension.

That is what that policy document spells out, and I think that I have already made clear that the Government is committed to that up until 30 June. The details of how that will be continued are a matter of continuing negotiations between the Commonwealth and the States.

TALK.START.PARA: —I keep trying to protect the public servants. I was simply asking Senator Crowley about a matter of ALP policy in an area that she is now Minister for—
—It doesn't give dates on it.

—I have no idea what date that letter was that she read from. Anyhow, it does not matter. I am really after what the policy of the Government was. I take it from the lengthy delays we have had while the Minister referred to public servants for some inspiration on ALP policy that she really has no idea what her party went to the election promising. That is not surprising, because it really did not matter; it just told them anything. It had no or very little intention of doing anything about it. It seems pointless asking the Minister further about the policy of her party. I simply refer the Minister to that document.

PARA.TAB: I have just come across a press release from the Minister for Social Security (Mr Baldwin) which indicates that that was along the lines of what the Government was promising. Is the Minister aware that, because compensation to councils has only been provided until 30 June 1993 and not beyond, some councils are refusing to give any discounts to pensioners as they are not sure where the moneys are coming from. Is the Minister aware of that?

TALKER.NAME: Senator CROWLEY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Family Services and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women)

TALK.START.PARA: —In answer to the first part of the question, I am not aware of any of the councils indicating that kind of difficulty. I am advised that a report is going to the COAG meeting on 8 June. That should assist the States and Commonwealth in the matter that Senator Macdonald has just raised. That is very much a matter I imagine the States will be bringing. The date of the letter, which I failed to give Senator Macdonald—I beg your pardon—was 4 February 1993. While I know that politics is played at any time—he can find one part of the Labor Party policy that I might not be hot about—I simply remind him of his reputation in his party's policy in the last election campaign.

—If the Minister wants to trade insults, this is her area; this is a very important policy her Government put to the Australian people. It told pensioners that they would get fringe benefits. What happens if a council will not give a discount in rates?

TALKER.NAME: Senator CROWLEY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Family Services and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women)

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government is concerned that pensioners be assisted in this matter and it will be interested to try to assist local governments. The offer has been made that up until 30 June the expenditure will be met by the Commonwealth. If local governments are in difficulty, they should bring that to the attention of their States prior to the Council of Australian Governments meeting in early June.

—Before the election, the Minister's party said it would give discounts on rates to pensioners. Does she agree with that? We have probably established that by me helping her with her policy. The Government has said that. It has provided some money until 30 June.
—Not enough.

—Not enough, but some money. Can the Minister give me an assurance now—this will probably finish it off and I can go home and we can move on to the next matter—that the Commonwealth will fund all local authorities for the discounts they give to pensioners. It is very simple. The Government said it would give—
—June 1993.

—June 1994. The Government said pensioners would have the discount. Can the Minister assure me that councils will be reimbursed by her Government for the amount of discount they give to pensioners, pursuant to her party's policy. It is simple.

TALKER.NAME: Senator CROWLEY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Family Services and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women)

TALK.START.PARA: —I can give an assurance that any discounts up to 30 June will certainly be covered 100 per cent. In answer to other questions, I have said to Senator Macdonald on a number of occasions already that further to that it is a matter for negotiation between the States and the Government.
—Senator MacDonald, I do not want to stifle debate, but I think that we should look at possible repetition, if I call you.

—I have something to do with local governments as the shadow Minister. A lot of councils have contacted me because they do not know what to do with the discounts. Many of the councils, because of droughts, are simply struggling to make ends meet now and they simply cannot fund discounts themselves. In the current appropriations therefore—money apparently appropriated for these fringe benefits—many councils are not prepared to make the precedents of giving discounts in this year when they are not sure if come 1 July they are going to be compensated again. Once a discount is given, it can never be taken back. That is why many councils will not pass on this current discount. They cannot be assured that they will be compensated for the discount in the next financial year.

PARA.TAB: Relevant to this year's estimates, and making sure councils pass on the discount this year, can the Minister give them an assurance that, once they start the discounts, they will be able to continue them into the next year and be compensated by her Government? It is a very simple question.Her Government has made the promise. Surely she can give me that assurance.

TALKER.NAME: Senator CROWLEY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Family Services and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women)

TALK.START.PARA: —I have said as clearly as I can that the Government has committed itself to covering 100 per cent of any costs up until 30 June. Also, it has allocated $70 million in the Forward Estimates to cover exactly the sort of payment, the compensation, that Senator MacDonald is talking about. What is for negotiation is the exact final figure. That is not yet determined, but the $70 million already in Forward Estimates does cover the point that Senator MacDonald is making.
—I am very grateful for that. Is the Minister saying that there are moneys to cover the discount promised in the next financial year?
—Yes.

—I thank the Minister. A lot of local governments will be very pleased to hear the Minister commit the Government to that. There is a suspicion going around that that is not going to happen. I am gratified by the Minister's assurance and I will make sure that all local governments know of it.
—Are there any further matters in relation to compensation for the extension of fringe benefits? If not, we will move to the next item on the running sheet—increased salary costs from the APS.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macdonald Sen I.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Chairman, just before we go on: my colleague Senator Walters has raised a question about your ruling that I could not say that `governments lie'. I did not pursue the matter because I did not want to waste the time of the committee by arguing about it. But my colleague Senator Walters, in one of her final acts before she goes—she is giving me the benefit of her long experience in the Senate—has indicated that if you make a ruling such as that and it is not challenged, then it itself becomes relevant.

PARA.TAB: Mr Chairman, I would refer you to page 2591 of the Hansard of 10 November 1992. In reply to a point of order, the President said:

SPEECH.PARA: Order! In the past people have said that governments have lied. That has not been ruled to be unparliamentary.
On 12 November, again in reply to a point of order, the President said:

Order! I ruled on this matter yesterday. As I heard the Minister, he was referring to the Victorian Government. The remark was therefore in order. However, if he had referred to the Premier, Mr Kennett, I would have asked him to withdraw.
Senator Cook then went on to say:
The Victorian Government lied to its electors before the election.

That was a definite ruling by the President, Senator Sibraa. Senator Cook then took full advantage of that ruling by accusing the Victorian Government of lying. The Victorian Government, of course, is a Liberal government. I do not know whether it is permissible to say that Liberal governments lie but not permissible to say that federal Labor governments lie. Mr Chairman, in view of the precedents that I have just mentioned, I seek clarification of your previous ruling on my comments.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The CHAIRMAN

TALK.START.PARA: —In those circumstances, I would refer you to a number of documents. I turn first to the sixth edition of Australian Senate Practice. There are some relevant matters on page 214, which I will not go through. On page 215 there is a paragraph which reads:

PARA.TAB: It is submitted that there is no mitigation of an offensive remark by making it general; indeed, the offence may be aggravated. In 1979 Speaker Sir Billy Snedden changed the House of Representatives rule with reference to collective reflections and applied the test of whether language was unparliamentary and should not be used . . . In the development of that ruling, Speaker Snedden in 1981 stated that he would not permit unparliamentary expressions to be used against a group if they would be unparliamentary if used against an individual.

INTERJECT.PARA: Secondly, on 31 October 1967 President McMullin made a statement which dealt in very good detail with the use of expressions such as `lie', `distortion of the truth' and `not telling the truth'. President McMullin said:

PARA.TAB: I now state as a general principle that statements or imputations that a Minister or senator is deliberately not telling the truth will not be allowed.

INTERJECT.PARA: I will skip the rulings I made; otherwise I might be regarded as being biased. Honourable senators can look at the ruling I made on 15 October 1991—it must have been while the President was overseas and I was Acting President—if they wish. On 9 December 1992, President Sibraa said this:

After Question Time today Senator Evans asked Senator Bjelke-Petersen, who was in the chair, to refer to me the question of whether it is in order to accuse an honourable senator of telling a `monstrous untruth'. Recently honourable senators on both sides of the chamber have been guilty of accusing other senators of lying. Sometimes I have ignored this when it has occurred in interjections or at times of some disorder. My forbearance should not be taken as condoning the use of such terms.
He went on later to say:
Interjections such as `Why don't you tell the truth?' are therefore also disorderly.

There is another statement by the President on 14 December 1992 which is fairly long and I will not try to precis it here. The rule which I adopt, and which I think in general the President would adopt, is probably summed up by saying that it is sometimes suggested that it is not disorderly to use offensive words against groups of members of either House as distinct from individually named members, but there is no basis for this suggestion in the rules of the Senate. On the contrary, offensive words against a group of members of either House may be regarded as a worse offence than directing such words to an individual member. In making those comments, I refer to rulings made by President Givens on 7 December 1916 and by President Sibraa on 10 December 1991. It was under those circumstances that I made the ruling that I did.

TALK.START.PARA: —Thank you, Mr Chairman. Still on the point of order, I am not going to flout your ruling by repeating the words, but there does seem to be a contradiction between your ruling on the subject and the ruling of the President. I am not sure what the precedents of the Senate are, but in the courts you would be likened to the lesser judge and the President to the superior judge. Mr Chairman, so that it will not be taken as an accepted precedent, I object to your ruling and challenge it.

—Do you formally wish to do that? I was going to say that I would refer this matter to the President, but if you wish to challenge the ruling now you have to do so in writing. I will have to leave the chair and we will have to reconvene the Senate and get a ruling there.

—Mr Chairman, if you are going to be formal on this matter, I will take counsel from my leader and see whether he chooses to do that tonight. If he does, we will challenge the ruling while you are still in the chair during the night. At this stage, I do not want to distract the committee from its course; I simply raise the point so that your ruling does not go unchallenged and so that it cannot be taken to be a precedent that I have accepted. I am quite happy to pursue the matter at some time with the President. I will seek the advice of my leader during the evening to see whether something should be done about it now. But you have put me on the spot—

—I am not trying to put you on the spot; I am trying to point out what we have to do if a ruling is challenged in committee. I would have no option but to say at that stage that we would go back to the full Senate where the matter would be debated and we would come back to the committee stage later. I suggest that I discuss the matter with the President and get him to bring down a ruling.
—We are running out of time. Subject to any instructions to the contrary from our leader, I would agree with that.
—That would also allow the President to look at the transcript and put the whole thing in context.

TALKER.NAME: Senator CROWLEY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Family Services and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women)

TALK.START.PARA: —To make things absolutely clear, I am advised that local government is obliged to extend rate concessions under State legislation. As I have said, those obligations and concessions are a matter of negotiation between the Commonwealth and the States. I am also advised that some local governments give additional concessions over and above those. That is something that the local governments decide and they are not a matter for these discussions, nor for compensation.

PARA.TAB: In case that point was not clear, I am pleased to put it beyond doubt. I hope there was no confusion before. I am also advised that the States are largely responsible for the lack of clarity after 30 June because they have insisted that the concessions be reviewed with the Commonwealth.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Minister for her clarification. Perhaps for her edification, I wish to say that for many years councils have given discounts of their own volition and paid for them out of their own budgets. Prior to the election, the party of which the Minister is a member promised pensioners that they would get additional discounts. It did not consult individual councils; it said, `We will ensure that you get discounts'. It is like someone promising something and someone else having to pay and deliver.

PARA.TAB: Discounts can be a matter of state government legislation in so far as local authorities are concerned, but that varies from State to State. I am telling the Minister that some councils are refusing to pass on the discounts that her party offered because once one gives a discount, one cannot take it back. The Government has provided some money until 30 June 1993, but the councils do not want to give the discounts and they will refuse to do so unless they can be guaranteed that someone will pay for that discount starting 1 July 1994.

What I sought from the Minister and what she gave me—I thank her for that—was an assurance that money would be provided to local authorities to cover those discounts. Whether it is the States or the Commonwealth which provides it, I do not really care; I am inquiring on behalf of local authorities. If the States are to provide it, I suspect some of them would be interested to learn that they have to fund it because they are not getting the money from anywhere else. Some of the States are saying that they do not have too much money these days either. I assume from that—the Minister gave me an assurance earlier—that the Commonwealth will somehow provide moneys, whether it be to the States to pass on to local government or whether it be straight to local government, so that local governments can give those discounts with the certainty that they will be compensated.

I thank the Minister for her assurance. I will probably even mention her name when I write to all the local authorities to tell them that a Minister of the Crown has assured them that they can give the discounts promised by the Labor Party with absolute confidence, knowing that they will get the money from the Commonwealth. To give the Minister some of the credit for this, I will probably copy the Hansard and send it to all the councils when I write to tell them the good news. I thank the Minister again.

TALKER.NAME: Senator CROWLEY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Family Services and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not one to be beyond a good joke, so I will smile. I hope that Senator Macdonald is clear about my explanation.
—I will just send them the Hansard.

—It should be the complete Hansard, including the understanding that the concessions that the Commonwealth is talking about making with the States are those that deal with matters of State legislation and are part of the Commonwealth-State negotiations. They are not the ones that local government independently might add over and above the others.

—I am confused. I want the Minister to tell us whether the Government's undertaking to subsidise the local government cut in rates ends on 30 June 1993 or 30 June 1994. Could she simply tell me which date it is.

TALKER.NAME: Senator CROWLEY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Family Services and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am afraid that I am not absolutely clear what Senator Panizza's question goes to. I think we are agreed that there will be 100 per cent compensation up to 30 June 1993 and a commitment in the forward estimates of $70 million to cover the Government's commitment, consequent upon Commonwealth-State negotiations for a final figure. That final figure will presumably be more than $70 million. The negotiations for the final figure have yet to happen, but the commitment is there into the forward estimates for three or four years.

—There being no further questions in relation to increased compensation for the extension of fringe benefits, we will move to the next matter, which is increased salary costs from the APS workplace bargaining agreement.

—I would like to ask a couple of questions. Can the Minister please tell me when the department will finalise the productivity improvements in each of the seven designated areas that it will be aiming to achieve under the APS workplace bargaining agreement? Senator Cook claimed that the APS workplace bargaining agreement would be revenue neutral. If the taxpayers are required, as they have been in these additional estimates, to pay an extra $10.8 million to the DSS for this initiative, which will not be paid back, when will the efficiency gains take place?

TALKER.NAME: Senator CROWLEY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Family Services and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am advised that a service-wide agreement was settled and finalised before the Industrial Relations Commission on 4 December 1992. Further productivity measures are subject to negotiation with the Public Service Union within the DSS, so I cannot give Senator Patterson a final date on that. The efficiency gains are 50 per cent in the first year, 1993-94, and 100 per cent in subsequent years. So there is some up-front cost in 1992-93.

—The Minister has not answered my question. Senator Cook said that implementation of the agreement would be revenue neutral. I see puzzled looks on the faces of some of the bureaucrats. Senator Cook said that the workplace bargaining agreement would be revenue neutral. If it is, why do we need to appropriate an additional $10.8 million to DSS?

PARA.TAB: It would seem to me that in many other organisations the productivity gains are made first and then the pay increases are given. But it seems that in this situation it is being done back to front. Is there provision for a reduction in pay if the efficiency gains are not achieved, or is Senator Cook's claim that productivity-based wage increases will not be paid if the required productivity improvements do not occur incorrect?

Senator Cook was saying that the process would be revenue neutral because if the productivity gains are not made then there will be no wage increase. We have got the wage increase, but we have not seen the productivity gains. What happens if we do not get the productivity gains? What will be the outcome?

TALKER.NAME: Senator CROWLEY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Family Services and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am advised that the department will not be funded through the Budget for wage supplementation from 1994-95 for these wage increases, and, no, wages will not be reduced because the advice is that the department is confident that productivity gains will be achieved.

—Is the Minister aware of agreements in the private sector where productivity-based wage increases are paid before productivity gains are made, or even before the nature of these gains are finalised? Is the Minister aware of any instances in private enterprise where that occurs because that is what has occurred here. What will happen if the productivity gains are not made? Is this a net loss?

—by leave—Mr Chairman, while the Minister is consulting with her advisers, perhaps we could deal with that other matter of your ruling. Your course of action is acceptable to us. That sounds a bit condescending. We agree with your course of action, which, as I understand it, is that you will refer the matter of your ruling today, together with the President's rulings of 10 and 12 November 1992, to the President for him to rule upon tomorrow. Is that what you are proposing?
—I am not quite sure whether it was 10 November. I have something here from 10 December. If you have other references, I will get them from you.
—The ones I read out were 10 November at page 2590 and 12 November at page 3225.

TALKER.NAME: Senator CROWLEY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Family Services and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am advised that there are negotiations on enterprise agreements in the private sector that include a wage increase and a package of productivity gains to be achieved after the wage increase. I am advised that there is a list of examples of this sort that could be provided if Senator Patterson would like it. Senator Patterson indicates that she would like it.

—I would like to move on now to ask a question on telephone rental and postal concessions. To save all the State electricity authorities receiving phone calls from all the thousands of people who listen avidly to the proceedings of this chamber late into the evening as they ring up and complain about the intermittent broadcasting while the Minister goes off to get advice, I will put this next series of questions on notice rather than have the Minister go off and get answers to them now.

PARA.TAB: When was the first quarterly instalment of the telephone allowance paid to pensioners? If a voucher system only ceased in September 1992, did pensioners get a one-off windfall because they received the first instalment of the telephone allowance while still able to use their telephone vouchers? Secondly, was there any evidence of vouchers being accepted by Telecom after 30 September 1992? If so, how widespread was the use of late vouchers? Has the department checked for the late use of vouchers? Could this late acceptance of vouchers explain the apparent lag in presentation of accounts by Telecom to DSS? Thirdly, how much, if any, of this additional appropriation resulted from the extension of fringe benefits to all pensioners on 1 April 1993? I do not expect an immediate answer. To enable the speeding up of the process in the chamber this evening, I ask that those questions be taken on notice and treated as expeditiously as possible.

TALK.START.PARA: —There being no-one wishing to speak to the other non-program specific variations, we move on to program 6; in particular, subprogram 6.5.

—Could the Minister confirm or deny whether Minister Howe gave the Australian Institute of Family Studies an oral agreement that the living standards survey would be fully funded prior its undertaking that survey?

TALKER.NAME: Senator CROWLEY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Family Services and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women)

TALK.START.PARA: —I cannot remember the question: can I give an assurance that Minister Brian Howe promised to fund to 100 per cent the research project on living standards? No, I cannot inform the honourable senator that that was the case.
—Would the Minister give the Senate an undertaking to find out from Minister Howe whether that was the arrangement that he made with the Australian Institute of Family Studies?

TALKER.NAME: Senator CROWLEY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Family Services and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women)

TALK.START.PARA: —I can remind Senator Patterson of the decision by Cabinet; that was, to fund the research project for $1 million. I do not think there is anything further I can add in relation to the other part of the honourable senator's question.

—Is the Minister not prepared to ask Minister Howe whether that was what he believed to be the arrangement when the institute undertook to initiate the living standards survey? If the Minister is not prepared to give that undertaking, can she explain what the Government will do about some of the problems associated with the fact that the institute undertook that survey on the belief that it was to get full funding for it?

PARA.TAB: A lot of the institute's programs are now being jeopardised—interstate seminars and the publishing of research results. In fact, on a visit to the institute, I discovered that it has stopped buying a number of journals so that its series of journals is now not up to date. Its major library, which is used and relied upon by many people doing research in the area of family studies—and I thought the Minister would be interested in this, given her portfolio—will be depleted and less effective because of the hiatus in its purchasing, especially of journals, as a result of the institute's budgetary problems resulting from the fact that it undertook this living standards survey on the understanding that it would be fully funded.

TALKER.NAME: Senator CROWLEY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Family Services and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women)

TALK.START.PARA: —It is certainly something I can put to Minister Brian Howe. I have no idea of what his response would be. But I do not suppose it would be a problem for me to put the honourable senator's question to him.

PARA.TAB: I think there is one error or misunderstanding in what the honourable senator has said. It is clear that the Government committed $1 million to this study. It was after that commitment of $1 million that the Institute of Family Studies—in the face of knowing the sum of money it was getting was $1 million and no more—decided still to go ahead with the full program. That was the institute's decision. I believe Dr Edgar made it clear in the Estimates that, even though the institute had been given the amount of $1 million and in spite of it wanting or asking for more for the full study, the institute made the decision to proceed with the full study recognising the amount of money that was cleared by the Cabinet to go to it.

Finally, I think the points that the honourable senator has raised here, about the challenges confronting the institute in terms of library journals and so on, she also made in the Estimates. It is precisely to assist the institute by addressing some of those matters that the Government has appropriated $749,000.

TALK.START.PARA: —Are there any further matters in relation to subprogram 6.5? There being no further matters, that concludes Estimates Committee C. The question is that the report of Estimates Committee C be adopted.

—I am sorry, Mr Chairman, that does not conclude Estimates Committee C because I have asked Minister Crowley some questions. I was not satisfied with the answer and I have indicated that we would not finalise Estimates Committee C until we got those answers. I am quite happy for the matter to be adjourned until a later time and for us to go on to Estimates Committee D, but Senator Crowley did say she would get the answers. She will now be free to get that information from the relevant sources. It is appropriate for us not to complete Estimates Committee C until she does that and returns to the chamber with the information.

—Whilst the Minister is getting instructions, I believe the proposition put by Senator Patterson is quite reasonable. That is what we did this morning with Estimates Committee A. There were outstanding questions concerning the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet. If the Minister cannot give us an indication as to when those answers will come before the committee, our only course of action is to move that any further debate on Estimates Committee C be postponed until we get those answers. Perhaps we will now get an indication from the Minister as to when those answers will be forthcoming.
—I am sorry, I am not clear what Senator Panizza is asking me.

—There are some answers outstanding to questions asked by Senator Patterson earlier in the day. I suggest that, if the Minister does not have those answers, we postpone further consideration of Estimates Committee C until those answers are forthcoming, as we did with Estimates Committee A this morning. I do not think we should reopen every estimates committee later tonight because, if we agree to negate the adjournment, we will be working well into the night as it is. I suggest the Minister tells us when those answers will be forthcoming.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crowley Sen The Hon R.A.

TALKER.NAME: Senator CROWLEY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Family Services and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women)

TALK.START.PARA: —I have the answers. It is a good thing that I checked. I was requested to represent the Prime Minister and I also received that request in my own right. It is a little difficult to know in what capacity I attended, but I am pleased to make it clear to Senator Patterson.
—I can understand that.

—I am pleased, although I am not sure that Hansard can understand it when I stop halfway. I suppose I attended in both capacities. I have here a copy of a message from Prime Minister Keating which I read on his behalf and I am happy to table that for Senator Patterson.

PARA.TAB: Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.PARA: REPORT OF ESTIMATES COMMITTEE D

PARA.TAB: Motion (by Senator Crowley) proposed:
That the report of Estimates Committee D be adopted.

TALK.START.PARA: —The first department to be considered is the Department of the Arts and Administrative Services. We will again go according to the running sheet. The running sheet begins with `All questions taken on notice by witnesses at the committee's hearings and not answered by Wednesday, 19 May 1993'. Are there any matters to be considered there?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crane Sen W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister and the officers here to the heading `Non-program specific' and in particular to workplace bargaining. I wish to refer in particular to the matters that were raised by Senator Kemp and I with regard to the enterprise agreement arrangements that were being negotiated between the Government and the ACTU. I particularly want to refer to the Hansard of the estimates committee hearings—and I see that Senator McMullan has now come in to join us—where Mr Mellors said:

SPEECH.PARA: The current status of negotiations over that in DAS are that we have held a first formal meeting with the central bargaining unit that has been established to negotiate that agreement for DAS and we are now into substantive negotiations.
Then Senator Kemp asked the questions:
And what is the union request? Can you indicate that? What are they seeking?

Mr Mellors went on to say that there were `from memory about 19 or 22 items', which Senator Kemp asked to be enlarged on and which were not. Further on in the discussion I raised the issue of the five different bands and what existed there. I then asked, in view of these negotiations, whether or not I could have a copy of the log of claims that had been placed before them. I have received an answer to that and I must say to the Minister that it would have to be one of the most outrageous answers ever delivered in this Parliament. The answer as to why that log of claims cannot be delivered to this Parliament—and it should be a public document; I must remind the Minister that we in this Parliament are the custodians of the public purse and must be accountable to the taxpayers for the payment of salaries and wages—is:

The Unions have advised that the matters they have raised for negotiation under workplace bargaining have been provided "in confidence" to the Department pending the outcome of negotiations, and accordingly should not be released.

I have to say here quite clearly and precisely that, if the Government accepts that direction—and I presume it is from the Public Service Union—that the log of claims is not available for public scrutiny and that it is not to be released, the document should be sent straight back to the union involved. It should be made a public document. As I said, as custodians of the public purse, we in this place are entitled to know what is in that log of claims. We are entitled to know what is being negotiated in terms of workplace agreements. We are entitled to know the propositions and the directions being adopted by the Government.

PARA.TAB: It has been publicly stated by a number of members of the Government that these workplace agreements or negotiations will become pacesetters for the private sector. Without wishing to prolong debate at this time, I once again ask the Minister whether he is now prepared to have that log of claims tabled. I will give him the opportunity at this stage to correct the wrong that has been put in this answer because we, as senators in this place, and particularly as members of this committee, have every right to view a log of claims that impacts on this place. It is not acceptable practice for a union to say to the Government, `That log of claims is in confidence' and for the Government to accede mildly and meekly to that proposition.

TALKER.NAME: Senator McMULLAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Arts and Administrative Services)

TALK.START.PARA: —There is a lot of passion in what Senator Crane had to say, and I appreciate that he is motivated by a concern to protect the interests of taxpayers. That is a proper concern, but there are a couple of things to be remembered. One is that we are not talking about a government document. This is not some proposal by the Government to spend the taxpayers' money. It is a letter somebody has written to us. It is not our letter; it is their letter. They wrote to us and said, `We would rather you did not make our letter public'. Let us get that clear first of all. This is not a government proposal. This a proposal that has been sent to us.

PARA.TAB: Secondly, in the sense of what constitutes a log of claims, this is not one; there is no log of claims. The unions have outlined some issues which they would like to have discussed under the aegis of workplace bargaining. It is no more than an indication of matters the union would like to have addressed. Certainly, any decision that flows from it could not be kept secret. I imagine nobody would want to, but if they did it would be impossible and inappropriate. But there is not as such a formal log of claims.There is a letter from the union to the Department raising some issues it would like to have as a basis for further discussions.

I am not aware of precedents for those sorts of letters being made public, and I do not actually understand the basis upon which that is considered to be in the public interest. If it were a log of claims, it would have been registered with the Industrial Relations Commission, it would be a public document and everybody would have access to it; but it is not that sort of document.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Parer Sen W.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would just like to take that up with the Minister for the Arts and Administrative Services (Senator McMullan). The Minister has said this is not a government document. This is a letter that has been written by the unions with demands in it. It was pointed out in the estimates hearing by Mr Mellors that the list was 19 to 22 items. To quote from the Hansard:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . some of which are perhaps more significant than others.
Then he says:
There is a proposition, for example, that there be a four per cent increase—

that is, in salaries. For the Minister to come in here and flick it out by saying, `This is not a government document', surely the Government has some responsibility to the shareholders, who are the taxpayers of Australia, to let this chamber know of the demands on the Government, because inevitably the taxpayer is going to pay the bill, whatever that might be.

PARA.TAB: It does raise some other concerns that I have. In years gone by, if a log of claims had been made to the Government, it would have been before the then Arbitration Commission, if it was seen to be a dispute, and that would have been known to everyone. One of the things that is said about enterprise bargaining is, `In going to enterprise bargaining, we can reach agreements at each individual workplace'. It concerns me that it is now taking away the accountability. There is nothing wrong with enterprise bargaining per se. In fact, it is an area where everyone would agree this Labor Party has stolen the Liberal Party's coat. But if claims are to be made—call them what you like; it is really a log of claims under an enterprise bargaining system—and if the Government is to come in here saying, `We are not going to tell you what those claims are', then I think there is something very wrong with the accountability or the lack of accountability that is emerging.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not satisfied with the answer given by the Minister for the Arts and Administrative Services (Senator McMullan). He can now change the terminology if he likes from a log of claims to a letter of demand—and obviously he has done that on the advice of the departmental officers—but no reference was made to that fact in producing the answer to me. As Senator Parer said, there should be accountability in this place and we should have right of access to that document.

PARA.TAB: If a letter of demand has been placed before this particular department which will lead to government expenditure—that is, the pay-out of taxpayers' dollars—we have an absolute right to know what is in that letter. In terms of that log of claims I would like to know how many of those 19 to 22 items which have not been claimed are of such a nature that they cannot be disclosed to this Parliament? In terms of setting up enterprise bargaining, as I have said, this has been espoused as being the model for private enterprise. We have not heard one reason why any of those should not be subjected to scrutiny by this Parliament and by the public.

I would hate to think that we have to go and use other measures in order to get hold of that particular letter of demand. That would be a very sad situation indeed. I think the present position is absolutely outrageous and totally unacceptable. The Minister, in his previous answer to my question, said I spoke with passion on this particular matter. Maybe I am speaking with passion, but I am also speaking with right on my side. I am concerned to get the best outcome for these enterprise demands. I pick up that terminology from the Minister, even though I do not particularly like it. It is imperative that the letter detailing those 19 to 22 demands which were outlined to us in the additional estimates hearing the other night be put on the table forthwith.

TALK.START.PARA: —I briefly want to add my strong support to the views put forward by my colleagues Senator Crane and Senator Parer. I put to the Minister for the Arts and Administrative Services (Senator McMullan) that what has been revealed in this estimates process are, I regret to say, deals which have essentially been kept secret from the public who ultimately pay the money to finance these deals. In relation to performance pay cash bonuses, one can point to documents which have been available in the public arena but they have virtually received no attention and no press. We have found that some deals have been struck which essentially have been kept secret from the public. Very substantial benefits have been delivered without proper public debate or proper scrutiny.

PARA.TAB: In the old days the Australian Labor Party used to be very strong supporters of the IRC. At that time those sorts of agreements would have had to be registered with and perhaps arbitrated on by the IRC. My understanding is that the Minister seems to be loath to enter into this debate, but perhaps he could address this specific question. When the deal is struck with the public service unions, am I right in saying that it will be registered with the AIRC but that body will not have a role in arbitrating on the agreement or in ensuring that the agreement is fully in line with the public interest? Perhaps the Minister could address the more general comments and then give me a specific answer to that question.

TALKER.NAME: Senator McMULLAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Arts and Administrative Services)

TALK.START.PARA: —I will reply in general and deal with the specifics of Senator Kemp's question so far as I can do so. There is talk about secret deals being done. There are two problems with that assertion and in resolving them I will deal with Senator Kemp's question. First, no deal has been done—somebody has written to us. A lot of people write to the Government and say that they would like us to do this, that or the other. Often we do not do it; sometimes we do; and sometimes we negotiate with them about what it is that we will do. So there is no deal.

PARA.TAB: Secondly, as Senator Kemp correctly says, if an agreement is reached—I assume that at some stage one will be—it cannot be a secret deal because it has to be registered with the Australian Industrial Relations Commission. If Senator Kemp wants to talk in more detail to DIR about the role of the industrial relations commission in dealing with section 134 agreements, I will be happy to deal with it then on the basis of the advice from the responsible department when we come to dealing with its additional appropriations. It is a legitimate question but is not particularly relevant here. I do not have detailed advice available to me on that. I am happy to get it. Those officers will be here because we will deal with that department shortly. However, Senator Kemp is correct in thinking that any agreement that is reached arising from these discussions will be a public document registered with the Industrial Relations Commission.

The TEMPORARY CHAIRMAN (Senator Teague)—Before calling Senator Parer, I note that there has been a degree of repetition in questions that have been put by honourable senators in this stage of the committee, and indeed by insisting that the Minister reply to those questions. I ask that new material be raised and that we address ourselves to the matters strictly in front of us on this committee.

TALK.START.PARA: —The most extraordinary thing about this matter of the so-called log of claims is the reply given by the Government on the request for the log. I ask the Minister for the Arts and Administrative Services (Senator McMullan) to tell us who is running this Government. Is it the Labor Party or is it the unions? The Government's response is, `No, we're not going to give it to you because the unions say this is a confidential document'. Who is running the show? Perhaps that is a rhetorical question; I think we might know the answer.

PARA.TAB: I would like the Minister to tell me whether the Government is making that decision or whether it is the union saying, `No, you cannot give that to the Senate because we say that this log of claims'—or letter of demand, or whatever one wants to call it under enterprise agreements—`which has been served on the Government is confidential'. We have not yet heard from the Minister the Government's reasons as to why it will not provide to the Senate this letter which contains 19 to 22 demands. Inevitably some of them will be agreed to and some will not, but certainly they will have to be paid for by the taxpayer.

TALKER.NAME: Senator McMULLAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Arts and Administrative Services)

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a pity that question did not pay much attention to your very good advice, Mr Temporary Chairman. It was fundamentally a rhetorical question. In the literal sense, neither the trade unions nor the Labor Party are running the country—although I hope most of those in the Cabinet who are running it are members of the Labor Party; I would be rather surprised if they were not. Of course, the country is being run by those people who constitute the Cabinet and the Ministry of this Government. I am very pleased about that and so are the Australian people; that is why they voted for them rather than for those opposite.

PARA.TAB: The reason we refer to the trade unions with regard to this document is that it is their document and they have expressed their view. The sensible conduct of public affairs—in this instance, the negotiation of industrial agreements between an arm of the Government and its employees and their representatives—cannot take place in public. For those reasons, people are entitled to approach their employer with reasonable requests without every detail being on the public record. Senator Parer is absolutely right: they are not entitled to come to an agreement that will cost the taxpayers money without the public knowing what that agreement is. They will not be able to do that and they will not do that. I do not imagine they would seek to, but if they do they will not succeed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crane Sen W.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Temporary Chairman, I take note of your earlier comments with regard to rhetorical questions. I must also say, without endeavouring to defy your comments at all, that there has been some rhetorical discussion because of the unreasonable stance adopted by the Minister. In answer to the previous question, the Minister said that because it was from the union letter of demand, it was a union document. But surely once that letter was addressed—I presume to the appropriate Minister, but I could not be certain to whom it was actually addressed—the ownership of that letter and the demands contained within it became more than the property of the union; they also became the property of those to whom the letter was addressed. Hence, in becoming the property of those to whom the letter was addressed, it rightfully becomes the property of those people who represent, or who are the custodians of, the taxpayers in this place. I emphasise that particular point very strongly.

PARA.TAB: I refer particularly to the answer that was given at the estimates committee hearings which shows quite clearly that this is more than a letter which has just arrived in the mail. It shows that negotiations are at a fairly well developed stage. It says:

SPEECH.PARA: The current status of negotiations over that in DAS are that we have held a first formal meeting for the central bargaining unit that has been established to negotiate that agreement for DAS and we are now into substantive negotiations.

I emphasise very strongly those words `substantive negotiations'. We are not asking for the detail of those negotiations but we are asking for the ambit that is contained within the letter that was sent to the Government. By beginning negotiations, the ambit of that letter of demand has been made the property of the Government and hence the property of this chamber.

PARA.TAB: In the next part of the answer that was given, Mr Mellors said:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . from memory, about 19 or 22 items.

If the Minister is not prepared to table the ambit that is contained within that letter of demand, maybe he is prepared to give us a detailed explanation of where each of those 19 different claims are at. I am not asking for the detail of those claims; I am asking for the parameters. Do they include a 30 per cent pay increase? Do they include reduced working hours? What are the arrangements for overtime? What are the arrangements for holiday leave, and what are the arrangement for a host of other matters?

PARA.TAB: I come back to the point that I raised earlier—that this will become the pacesetter for the private sector. I think we are entitled—in fact, I know we are entitled—to know the extent of the ambit contained in that letter. If the Minister is not prepared—and I think he has a responsibility in this regard—to table the ambit claims in the document, he should at least give us some idea of the extent of the claims.

TALKER.NAME: Senator McMULLAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Arts and Administrative Services)

TALK.START.PARA: —I apologise to the committee for going over this again. I did not at any stage indicate that the Government does not have the right to present this document—Senator Crane was correct in making that point. I was explaining why the union's view is relevant. If Mrs Smith wrote to us, I would ask her what she thought about her letter being tabled. If she said no, I might still table it, because having been written to us, it becomes a document in the possession of the Government. But I would certainly ask for her point of view before I tabled her letter.
—This doesn't stand up. This is not a letter from Mrs Smith.

—How insightful of Senator Crane! I think everybody else in Australia understood the point I was making. All I am trying to say is that whoever it is, we would consult that person. I do not feel bound by that but I would advise the Senate of it, as I think it would wish to be advised. I have already expressed the significance that flows from that letter.

PARA.TAB: I cannot see how I can accommodate Senator Crane's more recent question without achieving the same mischief that I am trying to avoid with regard to the letter itself.

TALK.START.PARA: —It's not a mischief.

—I use the word carefully; I am not implying that honourable senators as individuals are trying to make mischief. I think I used the word in its proper meaning. I was certainly not trying to imply a criticism of those who are raising this point and their motives. I do not and was not intending to, but I cannot really add anything to what I have already said.

—I will finalise my comments on this matter because I have no intention of pursuing it all night. I would like to put on the public record that the position is totally unsatisfactory. I repeat what I said by way of interjection: to use an analogy of a letter from Mrs Smith cannot be described as anything but outrageous. One cannot compare the two situations. We are asking, quite legitimately, to have put before us the extent of an ambit letter of demand. I believe that on the basis of longstanding industrial practice and precedents, and as the custodians of the public purse, we are entitled to know what that is.

PARA.TAB: I would request in all sincerity that when the Minister goes home tonight, he sleep on this issue and reconsider his position. I do not want to sound as if I am making a threat, but I guess I am. Until such time as we have rightful access to the contents of that letter of demand, we will pursue this issue relentlessly.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to ask the Minister just one question. It has intrigued me that the Government has found it cannot feel free to give the details of a request for a pay rise to the chamber because the union has requested that it does not. Does that mean that the individual members of the Public Sector Union, the employees of DAAS, have no idea what the union is putting to the department? Is that what it means? If it does not mean that but means that the individual members of the Public Sector Union—the employees of DAAS—do know, what is the problem with giving it to the chamber?

PARA.TAB: I am pursuing this issue because it seems to me that, if we are genuinely going down the track of enterprise bargaining, we have this very quaint situation where the union is saying to the department, `Here we have 19 to 22 requests to make, part of which is a three per cent to four per cent pay rise, but we do not want the employees of DAAS, the public or the committee to know what is in it. It is only between you and us'. Is the implication that the members of the Public Sector Union, the employees of DAAS, do not know what the union is taking to the Government?

TALKER.NAME: Senator McMULLAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Arts and Administrative Services)

TALK.START.PARA: —I assume that it is not the case. But it really does not have anything to do with me. That is a matter between the union and its members. I do not have any responsibility for it, cannot possibly have and do not know the answer.

PARA.TAB: The TEMPORARY CHAIRMAN (Senator Teague)—I will move on to program 5, which is corporate management and performance based pay rises extended to the senior officer service of the Department of the Arts and Administrative Services.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have received some answers to issues put forward during the estimates hearings. However, a number of other issues have emerged in relation to other departments. I ask the Minister to check with his officers whether any agencies associated with the department have granted performance based pay rises to everybody on the same level. Apparently, a number of departments, agencies or sections of departments have given, for example, a level 4 pay rise to every officer in the section or agency.

TALKER.NAME: Senator McMULLAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Arts and Administrative Services)

TALK.START.PARA: —Not as far as I know. As Senator Kemp would be aware, a very large number of small agencies are associated with the department. For example, there are a number of very independent bodies in the cultural area. That does not mean that we could not ultimately find out. As to the core department, the answer is no, but I cannot give Senator Kemp a definitive answer with regard to all the outriding agencies.

—I thank the Minister. I do not expect this to be provided now, but perhaps in the next week or so the Minister could arrange to provide a general summary of what has happened with the performance based pay rises in the core department. A number of departments have given me this material. I think I am right in saying that this department has not.
—Have you asked for it? Is it on the list?
—It is what I am asking for now. We touched on this point during the estimates hearings and I would like a breakdown of the core department.

TALKER.NAME: Senator McMULLAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Arts and Administrative Services)

TALK.START.PARA: —I think we did give a fair bit of information during the hearing, perhaps not in a tabular form because the proceedings were in question and answer form. I am advised that there is no further information, but if when Senator Kemp goes through it he finds that there are certain extra pieces of information which he did not ask for then and which are within the parameters of what we were discussing—I do not want to open up a whole new area—he can drop me a note about them and I will seek to get the information. But the officers think most of the matters Senator Kemp is dealing with were dealt with in the committee and that there is nothing further to add. But if there is something extra and Senator Kemp wants to get in touch with me, I will see what I can do.

—If it appeared that an agency or a subsection of the department had decided as a matter of policy to give everybody in that section or agency a rating of 4 or 3, would that be in line with the whole theory and philosophy behind performance based pay rises? For example, everyone working in agency X would receive a performance based cash bonus at a level 4. Can I get a statement from the Minister as to whether he would regard that as being in line with the philosophy of performance based cash bonuses.

TALKER.NAME: Senator McMULLAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Arts and Administrative Services)

TALK.START.PARA: —It is getting a bit hypothetical for me, but there could be circumstances in which that might be the appropriate outcome. I would not expect it to be the normal outcome. There are so many diverse organisations of different size, structure and complexity that a circumstance in which that would be the appropriate outcome is conceivable, although I would not expect it to be the norm. But we are hypothesising, really. To try to be helpful, that is about as far as I can go.

—We will move on to program 6 of the Department of the Treasury which is taxation administration. The first item is scrutiny of the Australian Taxation Office in relation to alleged computer fraud on the part of two or more ATO employees.

—I know there was some brief discussion by my colleague Senator Bishop during estimates committees with regard to alleged computer fraud. During the debate at the estimates hearings I think the Minister, Senator McMullan, suggested that Senator Bishop provide him with information that could be used as the basis for a follow-up. At the time the officers from the department indicated that they had not heard about this alleged computer fraud. If my memory is correct, Senator Bishop talked about an ASO6 as a person who might have been involved in this computer fraud. I ask the Minister whether there has been any follow-up of that claim by Senator Bishop following the estimates committee hearing.

TALKER.NAME: Senator McMULLAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Arts and Administrative Services)

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes. The second commissioner who had been the senior officer at the hearing met subsequently with Senator Bishop.
—This is like taking teeth out without an anaesthetic! What happened?

—I was not trying to be evasive; it was a total answer to the question. As I understand it, there was subsequent discussion, I think probably the next day. I do not want to be held to that exactly, but I think it was the next day. There was not an enormous amount of extra information forthcoming.

PARA.TAB: There was a matter which was at that stage under internal investigation and which bears some similarities to those points which Senator Bishop raised, although it is not precisely the same. That limited amount of further information provided did not make it absolutely clear whether we are talking about the same case although, on the balance of probabilities, I imagine we are and that the information is just a little off key but broadly correct. I cannot go far into the inquiries simply because, if they proceed any further, they will be a matter for reference to the DPP.

I suspect it is the same matter. The facts are not exactly the same, but they are sufficiently similar. I imagine it is a rumour which has grown a bit, as rumours tend to do in the telling. If we are talking about the same matter, the internal investigations people were inquiring into it at the time and continue to do so. There may well be further action taken, although it is a bit hard to take it any further here.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to have my reservation incorporated in Hansard.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.
The reservation read as follows—

SPEECH.PARA: SENATOR JOHN WATSON
Senator for Tasmania
Parliamentary Secretary to
Deputy Leader and Shadow Treasurer
2nd Floor AMP Building
46 John Street
PO Box 662
LAUNCESTON 7250
Mr J Carter
Secretary
Estimates Committee D
Parliament House
CANBERRA ACT 2600
Dear Sir,
I refer to the meeting of Estimates Committee D on Thursday May 11 1993 and wish to have the following matter included in the Committee report and reserved for further consideration by the Senate.

Without notice and contrary to past practice in reviewing the Supplementary Estimates of the Australian Taxation Office (ATO) within the Department of Treasury, questions about the administration of taxation law were, at the direction of the Minister and the Chairman, not answered by the ATO representatives present, rather I was directed to place such questions on the Senate Notice Paper.
Not only was I not given the courtesy of prior notice of such a change, but the large number of ATO officers present to respond to specific areas, were confused by the unexpected Government move.
Scrutiny by, and accountability to the Parliament is more than money issues. In the case of the ATO that accountability extends to the discharge of responsibility of the Commonwealth Taxation Laws.

I ask that an alternative mechanism be found to facilitate questioning by Senators. If the Government intention to restrict questioning is to prevail, such actions in limiting scrutiny is not in the best interests of a public image of the ATO.

Senators are entitled to an assurance from the Government that such a containment of questioning as occurred during the Supplementary estimates, will not be repeated, curtailing the Senate's examination of the Annual Estimates.
The Senate needs a formal opportunity to raise questions on such contentious matters as:
(a)ambit claims
(b)simultaneous raids on prominent sports people at 6.30 am
(c)harassment by tax auditors, and
(d)statements by ministers and senior taxation officials which are in conflict with later released determinations and rulings
Yours sincerely,
JOHN WATSON
Senator for Tasmania

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the committee. I wish to add to that reservation. Subsequently, on Friday, 21 May 1993, the Chairman of the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration, Senator John Coates, arranged for the committee to meet with officers of the Australian Taxation Office to respond to the technical issues associated with the administration of taxation law in Australia. Unlike the Hansard report of the Senate estimates committee hearings, the proceedings of the committee are not distributed as a Senate Hansard but are limited in their distribution in an A4-type format. Therefore, I ask that listeners to this broadcast and readers of the Senate Hansard who have an interest in these issues contact the Secretary of the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration, Mr Peter Hamburger, to obtain a copy of the proceedings.

PARA.TAB: The limitation of the distribution of the answers from the various Senate estimates committees obviously limits the benefits of these inquiries in their new format.
