The purpose of the inquiries that the Senate estimates committees carry out can be properly fulfilled only if the dissemination of the information elicited from the hearings is sufficiently widespread.

We note that in the past the ATO has stated that it will abide by the answers given in the Senate estimates committee hearings—the Senate estimates hearings have a certain status—particularly those answers which are responses to questions on notice. Could these sorts of answers be expressed in the form of rulings? If they have that sort of status, they probably have a status at least equivalent to that of rulings. So we do have a problem.

I follow up that question by asking: what is the status of the answers given in the new format that we temporarily adopted the other day in referring questions to the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration rather than any formal Senate estimates procedures? For example, are the answers given and do they have the same status as those given to a Senate estimates committee?

TALKER.NAME: Senator McMULLAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Arts and Administrative Services)

TALK.START.PARA: —It was always my intention that the hearing of the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration should in every way have no less weight or significance than those of the estimates committees. I have confirmed that the Tax Office regards them as of equal weight. I was not aware of the problem with the Hansard. I did not pick up all the details of it. Perhaps we can discuss it on another occasion. I would not wish it to have any less status in that regard than the estimates committees. In fact, I regard it as a superior forum—in a sense, a better and more effective forum. That was the purpose in my being happy to cooperate with Senator Coates in developing that alternative forum. If there is a problem with it in some way, I am happy to cooperate in resolving it.

PARA.TAB: With regard to those answers being rulings, there is a rulings program and some of them will be caught up. Some matters of a different nature are better dealt with by way of answers to committees. I do not think we would want to make a generalisation about that, but obviously there is an overlap. Some of the same issues would be dealt with by rulings, but my first reaction is that I do not think we would want to generalise about that. I am happy to discuss it further—perhaps here, but not necessarily here—with Senator Watson to try to get some agreed position on the general question of the status of the committee proceedings.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Minister for that very encouraging response. The point that the Minister did not address concerns the limited distribution of the committee proceedings and the transcript. They are available from the secretariat so they are available only on request, whereas all members who subscribe to the Hansard automatically get the Senate estimates transcripts. It is really a question of dissemination of information to a wider section of the audience than just those people who perhaps pay for a particular service through the reporting service of this Parliament. I am concerned that perhaps nowadays tax issues are not being disseminated widely enough throughout the community and are increasingly becoming the preserve of a few highly specialised tax practitioners. I think that is an unfortunate development and I want to try to loosen it up somewhat.

TALKER.NAME: Senator McMULLAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Arts and Administrative Services)

TALK.START.PARA: —The problem that the honourable senator has outlined is one that I was not aware of until this evening. I was a bit surprised. I have just checked and had it confirmed. Now of course, in retrospect, I can see it is similar to other committee hearings of that sort with which we have all been involved. I suggest that we might have a discussion with the chairman of the committee, Senator Coates, about whether this forum is to continue—and I understand that it was seen as very successful—and, if so, we might advise a range of people through the journals of the professions, et cetera. Let us talk about how we will do this, but I would like to see the report of proceedings better distributed or disseminated, and I am happy to cooperate in any way that will achieve that outcome. It was my intention that it would have equal weight and status. I am happy to cooperate in any way that will achieve that objective. I do not have the solution immediately to hand—the problem has just been drawn to my attention. But let us talk about that and resolve it before the next occasion arises.
—I have been out of the chamber for some time, but I believe we are looking at program 6 and any matters under that program, not necessarily in order.

—I understand that before I came into the chamber my colleague Senator Parer asked some questions of Senator McMullan concerning the allegations that I made—which have since been substantiated—about fraud with regard to computer theft and a scam whereby two Australian Tax Office officers had set up a company to supply computers to the department by pretending that officers' existing hardware was defunct, taking that perfectly serviceable equipment and selling it through an outlet, and pocketing those profits as well as taking the proceeds of selling in new equipment.

PARA.TAB: In the estimates committee hearings, I said to the tax officers that I would be prepared to give them additional information so that they could identify whether or not they had, in fact, been investigating this matter themselves. My information was that they had already found the scoundrels, if you like. But it did seem to me that the matter was not proceeding in a timely way, as this occurred back in July and August of last year and here it is May of this year and still there has been no prosecution.

Mr Nolan did in fact come to see me. I declined to give him the name of the officer, which I still have in my files. I declined to give it to him on this basis: outside the chamber there is no privilege in operation and if I gave the name to him I would be defaming that individual, because I would be publishing his name. On that basis I did not give the name to Mr Nolan. Of course, I could do it here in this chamber tonight, but I do not intend to do that either.

However, I do want to see an appropriate outcome of this matter; it is a scandal. In the information provided in volume 2 there is an estimate that some $15,000 worth of new terminals were provided through this scam. It provides me with no details of the value of the terminals taken and sold through the outlet which, as I said, was in Double Bay. I understand that those computers, or the hardware sold, were of the Apple Macintosh variety and that they were not on the assets register. I have had no satisfactory answer as to why they were not on the assets register; neither have I had any satisfactory answer as to why the matter has not proceeded in a more timely way to the DPP for prosecution. In the information provided it is said that they are still in the process of preparing the case.

I simply do not think that is sufficiently timely. Although Mr Nolan said to me that he suspected I would take some credit for bringing this to attention and getting the matter resolved, I can only say that if it had been dealt with properly and expeditiously and charges had in fact been laid, disciplinary action taken and the officer stood aside, then we might be seeing some sort of justice. What we are seeing is one rule for some people and another rule for others. We saw it in terms of those officers who use credit cards in an illegal way as was pointed out by the Auditor-General. They were not penalised or in any way dealt with other than to be patted on the hand and given a little counselling.

I would have thought that perhaps Neil Pickard, who found his use of credit cards spread across the front pages of newspapers, would have thought that counselling might have been in order there too. We cannot have one rule for one and another rule for others. In this country we have the rule of law and we say the same set of principles must apply.

In this case of computer fraud I want to know precisely the dates that these people were apprehended thieving—and the word is theft—those terminals from the Australian Taxation Office, which means from the taxpayer. What date were they found to be doing this? Why has it taken so long for the file to be prepared and sent to the DPP? Why has the matter been so slow to progress? It simply is not good enough when ordinary Australians are suffering and being pressured to see that there is one rule for some and another rule for others.

I do hope that the Minister will be able to provide me with the value of the hardware that has been stolen, whether or not it has been traced through the outlet—the details of which I gave to Mr Nolan—and when we can expect prosecution to take place in this matter.

TALKER.NAME: Senator McMULLAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Arts and Administrative Services)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not in a position to provide a lot more information at the moment. As the Senate is aware, as a result of documentation provided, an investigation is under way. Whether it has taken too long or not will be best able to be judged when the full nature of the matters that needed to be inquired into, their ramifications and consequences, become public if charges are laid. I have to say `if' because none of us can make assumptions; one would expect on the evidence that it is highly probable. If charges are laid, we will get indications of the depth and complexity of the matter which we may or may not accept at that time. I might not accept—or I might accept and others might disagree—that the matter has been investigated sufficiently comprehensively or sufficiently expeditiously. I am not in a position to judge that at the moment, though I share the concern that it needs to be comprehensively and expeditiously investigated. But obviously there is a limit to the capacity of the Minister responsible—
—Order! It being 10.30 p.m, under Standing Orders I put the question:

PARA.TAB: That the Chairman do now leave the chair and report to the Senate.
Question resolved in the negative.

TALKER.NAME: Senator McMULLAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Arts and Administrative Services)

TALK.START.PARA: —There is a limit to the extent to which even the Minister responsible can directly monitor the actual progress of such an investigation, and it is even more difficult for me merely representing him in this chamber. I certainly am concerned that it is a matter that needs continuing attention. To the extent that I can influence that, I will do what I can to ensure that is what happens.That will be a matter, I am sure, of continuing interest to the Senate on the other occasions that arise to examine matters such as this. I am sure the Tax Office will be aware that its performance on this matter will be being scrutinised on each occasion it comes forward, as it should be.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bishop Sen B.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will be watching with great interest to see the expedition with which this matter is dealt and the outcome. The second matter I want to raise tonight deals with the infamous time-outs which I raised during the estimates committees. I asked for particulars of these time-outs—holidays away for groups of people at taxpayers' expense. I asked the Department of the Treasury about those that have occurred over the last three years.

PARA.TAB: I am looking at page 262 of volume 2 of the additional information. Going through to page 270, I notice the various venues, the number of people involved and the bills that the taxpayer has picked up. One that appealed to me most was the group of people who went from 29 June to 3 July 1992 to Hungerford Hill in Pokolbin. That was for the infamous Chatswood office, Hurstville and the CBD. That little exercise cost the taxpayer $14,805. When we look at attachment "P" for what they achieved out of all that, we find they had a nice time. The outcome for $14,805 was:

SPEECH.PARA: 1 Team members identified the strengths which they as individuals bring to their team, and assessed their collective strength as a team.
2 Team members clarified senior management's expectations of them, and provided feedback to senior managers in an open discussion forum.
3 Team members identified the characteristics of an effective team, and evaluated their team's performance against these criteria.

That is an outcome for which the taxpayer paid $14,805 in that wonderfully convivial atmosphere of Hungerford Hill in the Pokolbin area well renowned for the making of wine. As I go through I find many other examples of this, and this is just for the period from July 1992 until April 1993.

PARA.TAB: The Australian Taxation Office did not bother to add up the figures. That is a quaint little habit we seem to see whenever we see published figures. So my staff has had to go through in a very quick manner to give a rough calculation. We come out with $950,000—nearly $1 million—of taxpayers' money for teams of people to know that they can get on well together in convivial atmospheres.

In the last few days I have had come to see me a number of people, taxpayers, who have gone through all the proper procedures and to the trouble of having private rulings made concerning undertakings of a business nature that they wished to set up. In some of these cases, it was to deal with providing for education of children—a laudable aim I would have thought in a country that wishes to be the clever country.

The private ruling was given, the modus operandi approved, money spent on the part of the taxpaying organisations to establish organisations in accordance with the private ruling—and 12 months later what happened? There was a reversal of the private ruling. All the money that had been spent to provide a facility for educating children was rendered useless. The money that has been spent has been wasted, and all this at the whim of the Australian Taxation Office.

We hear around the traps the reason for the ATO reversing its ruling. It is a wonderful one: `We are a bit worried', said the tax officers, `that too many folk might get in on the act.' Then the people who have been subjected to this arbitrary behaviour look at the remedies they may pursue either through the AAT or through the courts. Do honourable senators know what they hear back, what the scuttlebutt is? If they deign or dare to take action—to uphold the rights that they might otherwise have had—it may invite retaliatory action from the ATO for all of their undertakings.

It is not good enough. The Australian Taxation Office is seen as a body which retaliates, which wastes taxpayers' money. It can spend a million dollars in one year for its staff to have a nice time getting to know each other, yet ordinary taxpayers, who are trying to provide for themselves, for their families or organisations to which they belong, not only are penalised at the whim of the Tax Office but they are also threatened with being retaliated against if they pursue their lawful remedies.

It is an appalling situation to find that in a democracy like Australia we have a bureaucracy which is out of control. I would very much like the Minister to comment upon it, and indeed I ask him to do so.

TALKER.NAME: Senator McMULLAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Arts and Administrative Services)

TALK.START.PARA: —I have no idea how that last diatribe falls within consideration of the report of Estimates Committee D. It is just a bit of cheap populism and another stunt because Senator Bishop—
—One million dollars is not cheap.

—It had nothing to do with the million dollars. I am happy to deal with that in just a second. I am talking about the second half of that diatribe, which must imply that Senator Bishop has not had her name in the paper for 48 hours so she has to be rude to a lot of people who are not in a position to respond. Let me respond briefly for them.I will be very brief, because I know that otherwise you will rule me out of order, Mr Chairman, because this actually has nothing to do with the estimates. The Australian Taxation Office is an organisation of a large number of individuals. As in every organisation made up of a large number of individuals, including the Parliament, it has some good ones, some bad ones and a whole lot of middling ones. It has a majority of well-motivated people, but in 10,000, 15,000 or 20,000 people there will be some that are good, some that are bad and some that are middling in their motivation.

PARA.TAB: I do not stand up here and say that they are all saints, but I have met a lot of them and, if I had to judge the relative commitment to the service of the public and industry of the tax officers I have met as against that of the parliamentarians I have met, the officers certainly would not come off badly. That is all I will say about it.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is that a reflection on members of parliament?
—If Senator Panizza thinks it is a reflection on parliamentarians, I ask him to think further about it. It is simply a cheap shot, but it has nothing to do with the estimates.
—There is nothing cheap about it. One million bucks is a lot of money.

—It had nothing to do with one million bucks. Senator Bishop just uses it as a loose peg to be rude to people because she cannot find an innocent victim here. So off she goes being rude to people. Let me talk about the million dollars for a second.
—Please do.

—Senator Bishop comes in here and thinks, `There is nobody here to respond so I will kick a few poor old public servants and get a few cheap shots, and a few people in the Liberal Party will write me more letters saying I should be the leader'. Good luck to her. The fact of the matter is that there is no organisation of any size and complexity—the Labor Party, the Liberal Party, private sector, public sector, non-government and government—which can efficiently operate its business without holding planning meetings of some sort, without getting groups of staff together to conduct planning arrangements. If somebody chose a stupid title like `time-outs' instead of `planning meetings', they should have their head read, but I do not think it is a capital offence. It is exactly the same thing. If people choose to have their hotel and food expenses paid instead of receiving TA—
—They get that too.
—My understanding from the instances with which I am familiar is that one cannot get—
—I am reading from the document. Try it.

—I realise it is a terrible shock to Senator Bishop that not everybody sits here breathlessly waiting on her every word. Senator Bishop can wait until I have finished and then ask me what she likes. It is not my understanding that an individual can simultaneously have his or her expenses met and receive TA. That is advice which I have had confirmed. It may be that some individuals get TA and others get their expenses met but no individual, to the best of my knowledge, can get both. To the best of my knowledge, nobody has got both. I understand the information that has been provided confirms that. It is not something on which I have checked every dot and comma, but it is my understanding, my experience and my advice.

PARA.TAB: If one chooses to be paid expenses instead of TA, it does not seem to me to affect the efficacy or cost effectiveness. I do not vouch for every one of them; some are undoubtedly more effective than others, as is the case with every organisation. But to say that one can run an organisation of 19,000 people without ever arranging for any of them to get together to conduct a meeting to discuss how they should conduct their business is just absurd.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Before I call on the next contributor, I would point out than all comments in this area must relate to the reservations or matters in the report.
—I am dealing, Mr Chairman, with matter that is contained in additional information received in volume 2 and listed in the report.

PARA.TAB: In contradistinction to what the Minister for the Arts and Administrative Services (Senator McMullan) has just said, I draw his attention to one time-out, one get-together, conveniently timed for 13 to 19 December 1992. Somebody might be forgiven for thinking that was a Christmas party. It was held at the Holiday Inn, Coogee, and 22 people attended. The function cost $28,018. In addition to that, the cost of consultants amounted to $21,000 and TA amounted to $8,285. The total cost of that little Christmas get-together was $57,000. I wonder whether the taxpayer enjoyed that. I wonder whether those ordinary Australians who could not afford to buy Christmas presents for their kids enjoyed the fact that the taxpayer was paying for a time-out to the tune of $57,000.

When people in the private sector get together—I will be addressing a conference like this tomorrow—they pay their own bills; they pay their own way. We are saying that it is impossible for the Australian Taxation Office to have meetings together unless the taxpayer foots the bill to the tune of something in the vicinity of $57,000 for 22 people. Any one of these examples could be gleaned; they seem to take place about every two months. Any private sector organisation that was pruning its management and pruning its cost expenditure would simply not have these meetings occurring at all.

We will have to look at the whole question of the way the public sector uses the so-called training levy and the way the system is abused and perhaps refer it to one of the suitable committees to look into it in detail. When we look at the descriptions of the outcomes, they are in the same banal terms as the one that I read out earlier.

When the Minister chooses to simply insult people, me included, for taking umbrage at the fact that $1 million of taxpayers' hard-earned money is used—where the Taxation Office applies the book and applies tactics that many ordinary Australian citizens find distasteful and oppressive—so that the Taxation Office can afford to have a nice time in resorts and other venues, I think most people would agree with me that it is time we took a look at how the Government can do some belt tightening.

The other question that I raised—the one that the Minister seemed to think was not relevant—relates to a comparison with the way in which the Taxation Office is using its ability to make rulings and overturn them without any consideration of how that affects the running of business—

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Bishop, could you perhaps help the Chair and indicate under what reservation that matter is being raised.

—Yes, I can do that, Mr Chairman. It is pursuant to the information that I sought with regard to the way in which the Taxation Office has spent taxpayers' money on these time-outs and how that compares with the way that money is raised for it to spend. If it does not raise it, it cannot spend it.
—That is drawing too long a bow.

—If that is your ruling, Mr Chairman, I am happy to leave the question of the manner in which the Taxation Office is using the private system of rulings and overturning them with public rulings—and, indeed, the whole question of the way the public rulings are to be used under a self-assessment system—for another time.

—I had a question on notice regarding possible fringe benefits tax liability by the department along the same lines as these time-outs that Senator Bishop spoke about. The answer was given to me by way of seven sections which set out the conditions under which FBT applied. I thank the department for that information—I did know what those conditions were—but it did not answer my question.

PARA.TAB: The fifth paragraph says that recreation—that is, sporting activities, sightseeing, et cetera—is subject to FBT whether or not held in conjunction with a business seminar or a time-out or whatever. The Auditor-General's report stated that there was misuse of credit cards for such things as horse riding, dance lessons and, I think, golf lessons; the Minister should correct me if I am wrong. Earlier the Minister said that small sums in the region of $20 were not taken into consideration when calculating FBT. Seeing that those figures given in the Auditor-General's report ranged from $14 to $1,660, do I take it that those activities that I have just mentioned—horse riding, dance seminars and golf lessons—would have attracted FBT?

TALKER.NAME: Senator McMULLAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Arts and Administrative Services)

TALK.START.PARA: —I think the use of credit cards to pay for golf lessons is Senator Panizza's memory playing tricks on him. I do not know about the dancing lessons, but the principle is the same. As far as I can tell—I am no tax expert—it seems fairly straightforward that one would have to pay FBT on horse riding lessons in whatever circumstances they were paid for.

—I thank the Minister. He said earlier when answering one of my questions that income tax exempt employers, such as government bodies, are subject to FBT on the value of the entertainment provided to employees and associates. I ask the Minister: this money having been expended, what did the department do regarding the FBT liability that this would have incurred?

TALKER.NAME: Senator McMULLAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Arts and Administrative Services)

TALK.START.PARA: —Every FBT return of the Australian Taxation Office is being reviewed to ensure that any of the matters caught up in this which should have been subject to FBT have been. It may well be that they all have been, but there are a number of arms of the Taxation Office and they are ensuring that they have all the facts right. But if they are liable to pay FBT, an FBT return has been submitted—and it may well cover all these matters but that is being rechecked to ensure that all the matters raised by the Auditor-General which might properly be subject to FBT have been.
—I thank the Minister. Do I take it from his statement that the Taxation Office does lodge an FBT return to itself?
—Yes.
—And that the Minister will check that these things have been included?
—Yes.

—Further, if the Taxation Office lodges FBT returns to itself and pays FBT to itself, who checks the FBT returns that the office puts in to itself? It seems a peculiar situation to me, but I would like an explanation to prove that Caesar is not judging Caesar.
—It is a matter that is open to be reviewed by the Auditor-General if he so chooses.

—I refer to a question that was put on notice and to which a response was given. The question concerned the assessability for fringe benefits tax of outplacement services provided by employers. Many of us are very concerned that the provision of a number of these sorts of services can attract fringe benefits tax. In times of recession, it seems to be an unfortunate extension of fringe benefits tax law where certain assistance provided by the employer to a departing employee is certainly needed.

PARA.TAB: Perhaps the response should really come from the Minister to ensure that, as well as counselling and retraining to enable employees to undertake alternative work, there is the provision of other office services to enable retrenched staff to organise interviews and have resumes typed. Training in interview techniques and the preparation of resumes, which are the sorts of things that a responsible employer should do for his retrenched and departing employees, unfortunately now attract fringe benefits tax.

I refer to the obvious psychological stress that retrenchment places on people. Having been associated with it, I am well aware of the traumas that affect families where these notices are given to a member of the family.

I think this is a good time to ask the Minister to consider the appropriateness of the fringe benefits tax regime being extended so widely to these very necessary services. The extension of this tax will discourage responsible companies from engaging in some very worthwhile activities. It is most unfortunate that the tax law has been interpreted in such a way as to allow the imposition of a tax which I believe nobody really intended should be imposed in the first place. We would like the Minister to look at this. Perhaps some people have taken up this matter. In any case, it should be attended to as a matter of some priority.

TALKER.NAME: Senator McMULLAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Arts and Administrative Services)

TALK.START.PARA: —There are two issues involved: one is the interpretation of the law as it stands and the other is whether the law as it stands should be changed. One, of course, is a matter for the Australian Tax Office; the other for the Minister.

PARA.TAB: I think the office is of the view that the interpretation it is giving is the only one open to it under the law as it stands. I understand the policy issues that Senator Watson has raised. I expect that the Assistant Treasurer (Mr Gear) is aware of them, but I will make sure that the concerns Senator Watson has raised are referred to him so that in his review of tax policy he can take the matter into consideration.

TALK.START.PARA: —When I spoke previously about the misuse of credit cards within the department, mention was made of misuse from $14 and $1,660. I think the Minister told me during estimates that there were no prosecutions for misuse of those credit cards. The Minister also told me that 100 credit cards have been cancelled. Could the Minister put me in the picture as to what he has done to recover that misused money? Is he still trying to recover it?

TALKER.NAME: Senator McMULLAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Arts and Administrative Services)

TALK.START.PARA: —As I am advised, the difficulty arises from the fact that the people who misused the cards were not the beneficiaries of the goods in question. So there was some difficulty in taking action to get the money back. But the action that has been taken as a result of the investigation is that which was outlined to the estimates committee itself and nothing further.

—I thank the Minister for that answer, but I do not go along with his reasoning that because whoever misused the credit card did not benefit, an offence had not been committed and the department should not try to recover. If the cardholders did not benefit, why did they use them? Maybe they were trying to curry favour with somebody. Perhaps they were trying to make big men of themselves by shouting someone in the department or by buying someone an expensive present. The fact that the people concerned did not use the goods which they bought is not the point. The fact is that they misused the cards and I reckon they are responsible for that. I cannot see the Minister's reasoning for saying that they should not be held responsible.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Parer Sen W.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Minister for the Arts and Administrative Services (Senator McMullan) for his detailed response in answer to the question on credit cards. I would also like to refer him to the various requirements for people who have credit cards. The instructions, which obviously everyone would know about, state that all cardholders should be reminded that the AGCC may not be used for private purposes in any circumstances. That is underlined. The instructions continue:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . and their attention should be drawn to the penalty provisions of section 64 of the Audit Act, which states that a person who uses a Commonwealth credit card for the intention of obtaining cash, goods or services other than for the Commonwealth is guilty of an offence punishable upon conviction by a fine of $20,000 or imprisonment for a period not exceeding five years, or both.

There was another piece of paper, presumably put out by the department—I am not sure because it is not clear—called a fact sheet. It starts off with: `Hello and welcome to our first edition of the fact sheet'. There is no date on it, so I am a bit unsure about whether this has come about as a result of the questions asked or was put out previously. A few remarks are made in the fact sheet to which the holders of cards are welcomed, such as:
You should not expend funds on gifts, chocolates, trinkets, et cetera, to staff as a means of recognising their worth or contribution to the achievement of goals.
It further says:
You should exercise extreme care in deciding what to spend public funds on.
It is interesting that the sentence ends with a preposition; it shows what is happening to the English language! It continues:
You should constantly be asking yourself: what would a member of the public think about this expenditure? In particular, be careful—
I am not sure whether that means do not do it or do not get caught—
what you spend money on at timeouts.

Auditors from the Australian National Audit Office were particularly interested in funds spent on team building activities such as horse riding and boat hire. The boat hire is a new one. The fact sheet says:
The expenditure on items such as these are now considered to be not the most efficient and effective use of funds.

Here we have one very clear instruction, and that is that under no circumstances must one spend money on anything unless it is for services or goods required by the Commonwealth. Offences may result in fairly extensive fines and years of imprisonment.

PARA.TAB: Why in face of these specific instructions—quite specific and tough instructions—was this abuse of the credit cards not discovered by the department itself but by the audit office? It was almost as if the policeman coming in had to discover the abuse. These people were guilty of a sin against the 11th commandment: they got caught. The first question I am interested in is why it was not picked up by the department.

Secondly, why was section 64A of the Audit Act, which is very specific about abuse of this kind, not brought into play? As pointed out in the estimates committee hearings and, I think, in the Auditor-General's report, the Auditor-General did not clear these people, but it seemed that the Tax Office itself said that this was not a deliberate breach of rules and that no budget holder sought personal gain from any of the expenditure. Irrespective of that, it was an improper use of a credit card and was clearly in breach of section 64A of the Audit Act. So why was that not pursued?

TALKER.NAME: Senator McMULLAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Arts and Administrative Services)

TALK.START.PARA: —I think Senator Parer in the main has answered his own question, although I do have some things to add in response to the specific matters he has raised. Senator Parer has given a fairly clear exposition of why it was that these officers were considered to have misused the cards—not to have acted criminally; that is not what has been found—and to have acted improperly in misusing these cards; that is, that the officers used those cards not for personal gain but for things beyond the purposes for which they were authorised to use the cards. They should not have done so, and that is why the use of those cards has been found to constitute a misuse.

PARA.TAB: As to why the Auditor-General was required to come along and discern these problems rather than the department itself picking them up is not something that I can answer with hindsight. It is certainly something that I think the office would want to, and should, take up in its own internal audit function—I do not know if they are quite the right words—or in its own internal operations. If its officers have not already done so before tonight, I am sure they will in response to this evening, although I suspect that they have already done so.

As I say, we need to get this in perspective. These people acted unwisely and sometimes too enthusiastically in what they saw as the interests of the efficient conduct of the Commonwealth's business. But that does not justify their behaviour. They misused these cards and they should not have done so. But they were not doing it for their own advantage; they thought this was the way to get the best outcome in the circumstances. I do not in any way condone people's misuse of these cards or their acting outside the guidelines for proper use or outside the Audit Act, et cetera.

One of the constraints of working within the public sector is that there are fixed rules to protect the taxpayers' money, and we all have to work in accordance with them. Whether we are the most senior or most junior or in the most central or most minor organisation, we are similarly constrained, just as are the various departments of the Parliament. We all have to operate accordingly. I am not trying in any way to say that this is not a matter that should properly be given the attention of the Auditor-General or the estimates committee. I am just trying to put it in perspective. I do not have much more to add. I think Senator Panizza and Senator Parer have essentially outlined the arguments, and I will let the case stand there.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Parer Sen W.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have just one final question. I refer in the attachments to the answer given by the department to what is called `Australian Government Credit Card Guidelines'. It is Commissioner's Direction No. 14 of 11 March 1991, so it goes back some time. I think it is worth quoting from this document in a situation where clear directions are given and are then not pursued. People, quite rightly, expect integrity and principle from all government departments, particularly the Australian Taxation Office which must be perceived by the public to be, like Caesar's wife, totally beyond reproach. In part, that Commissioner's Direction on page 162 states:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . the card is issued to you on trust—trust that it will be used properly and strict care will be taken of it. Abuse of that trust will result in swift punitive measures being taken. When the AGCC is issued you will be required to acknowledge in writing that you understand—
I emphasise `acknowledge in writing that you understand'—
-strict care over custody and use of the AGCC will be taken at all times;
-the AGCC is to be used only for official purposes;

-misuse of the card (eg unauthorised purchases, whether or not restitution is made) will result in charges being brought under s64 of the Audit Act (which provides for imprisonment or fine if found guilty) and an immediate recommendation for dismissal under the Public Service Act. People charged under s64 of the Audit Act will be suspended immediately; and
-loss or theft of the AGCC must be reported immediately.

That is just a final point. I am raising this matter because the Taxation Office is so strict in the implementation of rulings and on the interpretation of the taxation law. Yet, when it breaches the law, it says, `Well, this really was not for any personal gain—although they did buy chocolates, go for horse rides and hire a boat'. The Taxation Office is able to absolve itself. The point I raised earlier with Senator McMullan is that, irrespective of the fact that some excuse was given, there was clearly a breach. It seems that the Taxation Office is not prepared to actually abide by its own directions.

TALK.START.PARA: —Physician heal thyself.

—Exactly. `Don't do as I do; do as I say' or `Physician heal thyself', as Senator Kemp said. It seems that the Minister has not explained satisfactorily why a breach of the quite clear credit card directions occurred and why, after the directions were not followed, the penalties were not pursued.

TALKER.NAME: Senator McMULLAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Arts and Administrative Services)

TALK.START.PARA: —It is very difficult to respond without seeming to condone that which I do not condone—that is, the action of the officers concerned. When I respond as to why no charges were laid, I do not want my remarks to be interpreted as in any way justifying people misusing their credit cards. However, the judgment was made that the nature of the offences was such as to not warrant charges.

PARA.TAB: All of us, in our daily lives in constituency offices and wherever, are aware of the consequences for individuals of charges being laid. It is not something that is done lightly, nor should it be. A judgment was made, and the nature of accountability is such that it is for the Parliament and the public to say whether they agree with the judgment made by the officers at that time. I do not intend to seek to overturn it retrospectively. I simply outline it and we will each make our own judgments now and if any incident should recur.

TALK.START.PARA: —Are there any further matters in relation to taxation administration? There being no further matters, we will turn to the Department of Finance, program 7, the Australian National Audit Office. There being no questions, we will turn to the Department of Industrial Relations. We will go according to the running sheet—all questions taken on notice by witnesses at the committee's hearings and not answered by Wednesday, 19 May. Are there any questions in that area? Are there any questions under program 1? There being no questions, I turn to program 2 and, in particular, subprogram 2.1.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kemp Sen C.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have a number of questions to raise which follow on from the reservation I made which, in turn, arose from the questions and answers I received during the Estimates Committee D hearings. A number of issues have emerged in relation to this whole scheme of performance based cash bonuses to the senior levels of the Public Service. We have already had a number of debates in this chamber on this issue and Senator Childs has had a chance to contribute to this debate also.

PARA.TAB: I think the concerns can be summarised in this manner. First, there was the surprising agreement struck between the Government and the ACTU initially on this matter. That is a matter of history. It was before the election, and it was an agreement which allowed significant cash bonuses to members of the senior officer service and the SES and more limited rises to those at the lower levels of the Public Service.

I am aware of the stated reasons for these rises. However, whereas the ACTU was able to endorse rises to senior public servants, the ACTU, presumably with the Government's concurrence, was willing to defer rises promised during the election period. Under the accord mark 7, I think it was, senior public servants would become eligible for an $8 a week increase after 1 July—which, ironically, was the same date at which members of the senior executive service were becoming eligible for cash bonuses of up to $15,000. That is the first aspect on which there has been considerable debate, involving both the timing of these pay rises and the subsequent election promise and the breaking of it.

The other point that has come up in relation to the way this whole issue of performance based pay is actually working out is whether it is working out in a manner which will add to the effectiveness and efficiency of the Public Service and fulfilling its own objectives, or whether we are seeing just another way to deliver a pay rise to senior officers as distinct from encouraging, at least according to the theory, a more effective Public Service.

The third part of the debate relates to what impact this will have overall on both public sector wage movements and wage movements in the wider community. We have had that debate before, but there is a feeling around that the Public Service, under the guidance of Mr Keating and Mr Kelty, is becoming the wages pacesetter, as we saw in the period of the Whitlam Government, which senior Ministers in that period such as Mr Cameron believed was not only bad policy but also bad for the country.

I want to get clear in my mind some issues which have emerged. I would like the Minister to assist me with this and I see that officers from his department are present for this debate. A number of public servants have pointed out to me what they see as the practices of their own departments or sections of departments and agencies in granting a single across-the-board pay rise, whether it be at level 4 or level 3. The point has been made to me—I do not know whether this is correct—that, for example, everyone in the DPP's office received a performance based pay rise at the level of the so-called level 4, which I understand is described as being of superior performance. My attention has been drawn to an article by Jack Waterford in which he says:

SPEECH.PARA: Some agencies have found the process rather daunting. One agency is known to have graded all of its staff four. At Finance, two in every three officers got something; in some Customs areas, it is understood, everyone got something.

Every day different public servants indicate to me what is happening in their own area and ask whether it is within the philosophy of performance based pay rises that whole agencies or departments should be granted exactly the same performance pay cash bonus. Whereas we can say that everyone has a superior performance or everyone is fully effective, the fact of the matter is when we get past more than a handful of people that is a most unlikely outturn. I would be interested to see whether the Government has any view as to whether an agency deciding it is all too hard and giving everybody a level 4 cash bonus is in line with the philosophy of performance based cash bonuses which the Government has outlined.

TALKER.NAME: Senator McMULLAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Arts and Administrative Services)

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not have much to add to my previous response. The officers indicate they are not aware of any examples of where that course of action has been undertaken. Although it would not necessarily be the case, I imagine that they would be aware. If a decision were made to pay people without having made the necessary individual assessments, that would seem to me not to be in accordance with the guidelines as set down. It is a bit hypothetical, as I said before. It may well be that in a small agency an assessment could turn out an extraordinary result. But it would not be in accordance with the guidelines if it were not based on individual assessments, because that is what drives the system. I have nothing further to add.

—I thank the Minister for that. In the coming months, particularly as the SES officers become entitled to their cash bonuses—these are the glittering prizes; up to $15,000—I suggest it will become a matter of community interest and debate. Certainly, as the results of the first rounds come in, there will be a heightened level of public interest to see just how agencies are adapting to the use of performance based cash bonuses, or pay rises as they are more commonly known.

PARA.TAB: I am sorry that the Minister could not give me a clear answer. I understand that he is hedging on this, and I understand the reasons why he is doing that, but I put it to him that commonsense would indicate that, where substantial numbers of officers all receive the same performance based pay rise in the same department, that is going to be seen as really another way to give a wage rise. I think that will lead to further debate and concerns in the Public Service.

The topic of the next question I would like to put to the Minister was touched on in a number of conversations I have had with public servants. An officer assessed at level 3, for example, gets a cash bonus if he or she is fully effective. Commonsense would indicate that an officer who is fully effective is probably doing his or her job. Senator Burns nods in approval. Therefore, it seems to me an odd thing to be saying to those people, `If you are fully effective you will get a cash bonus for doing your job'.

Again, I ask the Minister to ask his officers, in their assessment of the first round of the performance pay cash bonuses for the Senior Executive Service, whether this concern has been expressed to them; that is, that it is an odd thing to be giving a person a cash bonus for doing the job which he or she was originally employed to do when he or she appears to be doing it in a fully and effective manner.

TALKER.NAME: Senator McMULLAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Arts and Administrative Services)

TALK.START.PARA: —The little word games we are playing will not advance the sum of human knowledge any further. I do not intend to pursue this matter much more at 11.25 p.m. I simply indicate that in the normal course of the agreement this program will be reviewed early next year. If there is widespread concern of the sort which some people, for reasons known only to themselves, have chosen to raise with Senator Kemp, I imagine it will come up in that review.

—I do not think that answers my question. I guess that people who are interested in this topic will judge the hesitation of the Minister and the fact that on this particular issue he is not being his usual forthright self. Last night and this morning there was an interesting and in some ways a very productive debate with the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Senator Gareth Evans) in relation to the Department of Foreign Affairs in which Senator Evans recognised—I think that I am being fair to him—that clashing principles are involved on this issue.

PARA.TAB: On the one hand, there is a desire to maintain privacy about people's performance and any cash bonuses flowing from that and, on the other hand, there is a recognition that the payment of cash bonuses to unnamed officers, decided by their superior officers, who are also unnamed, could lead to undesirable consequences. Putting it as nicely as one can, it could lead to the favouritism of certain officers at the expense of other officers; putting it somewhat harshly, it could lead to the problem of corruption that was expressed in the debate this morning. Senator Evans recognised this dilemma and said that he would be raising the issue in writing with the Prime Minister (Mr Keating). Senator Evans did not make a judgment on the issue, but he recognised that there was a problem. Maybe this is a matter which should be reviewed to see whether the Government should address these concerns.

I ask the Minister whether he agrees with the concerns expressed by Senator Evans and whether he will ensure that these sorts of problems about which Senator Evans will be writing to the Prime Minister are speedily addressed. I am not sure but I suspect that the Department of Industrial Relations will have to deal with this matter.

TALKER.NAME: Senator McMULLAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Arts and Administrative Services)

TALK.START.PARA: —I think Senator Evans indicated to the chamber that he was going to write to the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) about it. I am aware of what Senator Evans said about that relevant paragraph, and I agree with him. I do not think there is any need for me to ensure that it is dealt with expeditiously because Senator Evans will do that. I am aware of what he said in this matter. I share his view and support his action.

—One answer which I received earlier on from the Department of Industrial Relations that was less satisfactory was that the SES would become entitled to cash bonuses after 1 July. Senator Evans did not seem at all sure as to when those cash bonuses would become available in his department. Could the Minister seek advice from his officers as to whether the understanding of Senator Evans was correct, whether the guidelines as far as his own department is concerned had not been fully established, and whether there are any other major departments in this position?

TALKER.NAME: Senator McMULLAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Arts and Administrative Services)

TALK.START.PARA: —I understand that it is the responsibility of the Public Service Commission and not DIR to approve the guidelines, so we would not know particularly. However, the general point is that if the appraisal cycle has not been undertaken by 1 July the payments will not be made at that stage but after that appraisal has been concluded. I imagine that it would be a matter for individual agencies to take the necessary action to set the programs in place. As I understand it, it is not a DIR matter.

—If I can briefly raise one matter which follows on from Senator Kemp's questions, it relates to a previous matter that I raised earlier tonight when we dealt with DAAS. It was identified, to use the Minister's words, that a letter of demand from the Public Service Union had been received by the department—as we were told in the estimates committee hearing the other night—and that it included between 19 and 22 items. Have all departments received the same letters of demand? If there are letters of demand, how many letters are there and what is the extent of the variations?

TALKER.NAME: Senator McMULLAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Arts and Administrative Services)

TALK.START.PARA: —The system does not require agencies to advise DIR if they have received such a letter. I cannot give Senator Crane a full and comprehensive response. As I am advised, it is almost certain that all of the agencies have not received the same letter. I suppose there would be agency specific matters in all of them; if not, then at least in some of them. One would expect it to be in all of them, but that is not something that I can confirm. They would not all have received the same letter. In fact, all of them may not have even received the letter as yet. There is not a central register. They do not necessarily all have to be drawn to the attention of the Department of Industrial Relations.

PARA.TAB: The TEMPORARY CHAIRMAN (Senator Childs)—If that concludes the examination of subprogram 2.1, we will move to program 3, subprogram 3.1.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer to a series of questions that I asked on promotions of awards during the estimates committee hearing. I have received answers to a number of those questions, most of which I understand quite clearly but one or two of which confused me somewhat. The question I was asking at that time related to the expenditure of $1 million for advertising. The answer which came back on that matter was that when the campaign was planned in January 1993 the sum of $750,000 was allocated to be spent on print advertising. The answer went on to say—and this is the part that confused me—that, although no final placement schedule has been decided, advertisements would have appeared in almost all newspapers of each State, including the ethnic press. I got the impression at the estimates committee hearing that this campaign had been carried out and that there had been a positive response to it. The terminology used in that answer indicates to me that the campaign has not been carried out as yet. Could I be advised as to whether the whole campaign or just a portion of it has been carried out and how much of the $1 million allocation has been spent at this time?

TALKER.NAME: Senator McMULLAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Arts and Administrative Services)

TALK.START.PARA: —No, it has not been conducted and none of the $1 million has been spent. I cannot know what Senator Crane is recalling but I imagine there was some reference to a prior, much smaller campaign specifically targeted at women, in the course of research for which the need for the broader campaign became evident. I imagine that was the matter which gave him the impression something had already been undertaken. This campaign was much smaller and quite distinct from the $1 million program which has not been undertaken.

—I thank the Minister for his answer. I do not believe I was confused or mixing up the two. It was just that the figure of $1 million was in the additional estimates. I asked for detail of the expenditure believing, from the answers that were given, that that program had been at least partially carried out. The Minister has cleared up that aspect. I did have a specific question relating to the $58,000 with regard to the targeting women program which, from the answer to this question, I know was conducted in January and February, which was immediately prior to the election. Has any assessment been made since that program? I understand that research was done prior to it. If an assessment has been made, could we have copies of it? If research has not been done to ascertain the effectiveness of the dollars spent, could the Minister tell me why that is the case?

TALKER.NAME: Senator McMULLAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Arts and Administrative Services)

TALK.START.PARA: —I cannot unequivocally say that there has not been subsequent research. Of course, there are other forms of assessment of advertising campaigns but, to the best of my knowledge, there has been no further research. This was a very small campaign. I am now going from memory, but I think we are talking about an amount of $50,000. Research is very expensive. We would wind up spending more on assessing the program than on carrying it out, which does not seem to be cost-effective. If some objective measurement such as research has been carried out, I will make it available. I think it has probably not been done, because with such a small campaign it would be unlikely that we would do such a thing. In my various capacities I have never been involved in a campaign of such a small size where one would have done any post-campaign research because it just would not have been cost-effective. But if such a thing has taken place—anything that is measurable—I will seek to make it available.

—I thank the Minister for his answer. The point I wish to make is that from the information that was given to us at additional estimates, as I remember it—and I do not have the actual documents in front of me—this type of campaign was a first. I remember that quite clearly. I would have thought research of this type may have been appropriate. Nonetheless, research was carried out prior to the program which is contained in the booklet I have here, which I am grateful to have received. Could the Minister advise me of the cost of the research carried out prior to the advertising program?

TALKER.NAME: Senator McMULLAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Arts and Administrative Services)

TALK.START.PARA: —I will have to take it on notice, maybe not formally because of the nature of the estimates process, but I will certainly provide that information to Senator Crane. I do not have it available but I will ensure it is provided to him.
—I have one more question. In view of the fact that the $1 million program has not been carried out at this point in time, is it envisaged that it will be this financial year?

TALKER.NAME: Senator McMULLAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Arts and Administrative Services)

TALK.START.PARA: —It will not be conducted this financial year. It is proposed that the money be carried over to the next financial year when a decision will be made as to whether such a campaign will be conducted.
—If there is nothing further in relation to subprogram 3.1, we will move to subprogram 3.3.

—I wish to raise a matter relating to the additional estimates and a direct request to Australia from the ILO for information with regard to ILO convention 87. I have a series of questions about this and I have only had this document for a short time. With the permission of the Senate and the understanding of the Minister, I would like to list formally the questions coming out of this document rather than wander through a fairly lengthy document with a series of questions. I do not think there is anything too controversial about it; it just relates to additional information that was supplied. If the Minister and the Senate are happy with that, I shall proceed to take that course of action rather than keep going until 2 o'clock in the morning.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McMullan Sen The Hon R.F.

TALKER.NAME: Senator McMULLAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Arts and Administrative Services)

TALK.START.PARA: —For the record, I say to Senator Crane that I am happy with that process. I will try to ensure that the response is forthcoming quickly. I understand that he has other forums in which to raise his concerns if they are not. I am sure that the Minister will want to provide it and I will pass on those questions as quickly as I can. I thank Senator Crane for his cooperation.
—If there are no further questions, that concludes the consideration of Estimates Committee D.

PARA.TAB: Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.PARA: REPORT OF ESTIMATES COMMITTEE A

PARA.TAB: Consideration resumed.

TALK.START.PARA: —Further to discussions that I had earlier this evening with the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs, Mr Tickner, and the CEO of ATSIC, I was under the impression that the Minister at the table would be making a statement with regard to issues that were raised in consideration of Estimates Committee A on Monday and that the Minister would be responding to various issues that had been raised. In fact, the reason why we postponed consideration of this report was to enable the Minister, Mr Tickner, to take further advice and to provide information on a number of unanswered questions.

PARA.TAB: In the course of today I have received answers to just about every one of the outstanding questions. I wish to pursue a number of issues that do not specifically relate to the matters that were on notice to ATSIC itself. I am reasonably satisfied with those answers. Those that I am not satisfied with I can pursue with officials in other places and through appropriate channels. A number of questions were posed to the Northern Land Council, some of which went back as far as the September Estimates of last year, which did invite and need further consideration and deliberation by the Minister. If I invite the Minister to make the statement first rather than try to tease the matter out, my response will be abbreviated.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALKER.NAME: Senator GARETH EVANS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Foreign Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Tambling for his contribution. As he has acknowledged, the questions have been answered to the best of the ability of the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs (Mr Tickner). The Minister has asked me, on his behalf, to read this response into the record. I hope that it will be satisfactory to Senator Tambling. Where I use the personal pronoun `I', it refers to the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs.

PARA.TAB: The statement reads as follows:

Certain issues of concern have been raised in the Senate Additional Estimates process by Senator Tambling regarding the operation of the Northern Land Council and some associated issues. I would emphasise that I have reached no final conclusion on the accuracy, substance or otherwise of Senator Tambling's concerns. In the interests of my continuing commitment to open and accountable government, however, I have decided to take the steps outlined below. It is in the interests of Aboriginal people in the Northern Territory, including the staff and councillors of the Northern Land Council, that urgent action be taken to clarify concerns and, where appropriate, to remedy any deficiencies and shortcomings. In summary, I propose to take the following action.

First, I wrote on 3 May 1993 to the Auditor-General after receiving representations from Senator Tambling on certain allegations made to him. In that letter, I sought the Auditor-General's views as to whether further investigations were warranted. Although I have not yet received a reply to that correspondence, I have determined nevertheless to formally request the Auditor-General to undertake an investigation of the matters raised by Senator Tambling and will ask the Auditor-General to put forward suggestions for any improvements in the NLC's administrative systems and management structure as a matter of priority.

Secondly, I propose to direct that the Northern Land Council, under section 37 of the Act, henceforth submit its annual reports in the format used by the Central Land Council for its annual reports. This will include the requirement to identify all consultancy agreements entered into by the NLC.

Thirdly, I have determined to withdraw my delegation to the state manager of the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission's Northern Territory office to approve payments under section 64(7) of the Act for land council administrative costs. That delegation will henceforth only be exercised by the chief executive officer of the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission, who will advise me in each case when the delegation is exercised. This is not to be taken as any criticism of the state manager in the Northern Territory, who has always authorised payments strictly in accordance with the requirements set out in section 64(7).

Fourthly, after obtaining the agreement of the chairperson of ATSIC, Ms Lois O'Donoghue CBE, AM, I am prepared to release to Senator Tambling a confidential draft report prepared by the Office of Evaluation and Audit on the Aboriginal benefit trust account on the express undertaking that the report is a draft and its contents confidential for a period of two weeks to allow responses to be prepared by ATSIC to the report.

I would emphasise that the final draft version of the report was only made available to the director of the OEA on 13 May 1993, and the OEA has not yet had the opportunity to obtain responses to the report's recommendations. The draft was only provided to my office late yesterday afternoon and I have not as yet had the opportunity to read the document myself. I have consistently stressed that issues of public accountability are non-negotiable. It is my strong view that it is in the interests of the NLC that Senator Tambling's concerns be investigated.

SPEECH.PARA: I hope that that constitutes a pretty comprehensive response by the Minister to Senator Tambling. It might be possible under those circumstances for us to be detained no longer on this matter tonight.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tambling Sen G.E.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Senator Gareth Evans), and I thank the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs (Mr Tickner) for the very positive and constructive response that he has given. As I have mentioned, this issue goes back to the September estimates of last year and the unsatisfactory responses by the Northern Land Council in the manner in which it has prepared and provided information to the Senate committee.

PARA.TAB: I was very pleased today when Mr Tickner initiated the phone calls to me as he had obviously appreciated the concerns I expressed and the issues I raised at the Senate estimates on 10 May and the very great concern of many Aboriginal people regarding this particular matter. I am very pleased that the Minister has now initiated a full inquiry by the Auditor-General into all of the issues that have previously been referred to him and all of the issues that I raised last September, with the Minister in the interim, on 10 May and subsequent to that. I am very pleased that the Auditor-General has been given this specific brief.

I trust that when the reports come forward we will also be acquainted with the Auditor-General's comments relating specifically to a number of very important issues—in particular, the administration of the royalty trust accounts that are currently administered by the Northern Land Council. Whilst a number of the questions and answers that have been tabled here today are provided by the Northern Land Council, they are totally inadequate with regard to the degree of the problem that has been represented to me by Aboriginal constituents, particularly with regard to the administration of those royalty trusts. The trusts themselves attract millions and millions of dollars in any particular year.

Whilst one of the answers, I noted, implied that the funds did not flow out of the royalty trust and into the administration account of the Northern Land Council itself, it has been submitted to me by Aboriginal constituents that in fact many disbursements are paid from the royalty trust accounts on account of

SPEECH.PARA: expenses that would more appropriately be described as administrative costs.

PARA.TAB: I hope the Auditor-General's inquiry will reveal whether or not the proper minuting of all of those royalty trust accounts takes place, whether their administration is strictly in accordance with what would apply to the trust accounts of any solicitor or any person acting in trust, and whether all disbursements from those royalty trust accounts can in fact be properly acquitted to the proper owners of those funds, who are the Aboriginal traditional owners and many other Aboriginal people in the Northern Territory. I am very pleased at the action and the response the Minister has initiated. I am only sorry that it has taken so long.

With regard to the report that was mentioned, the Walter and Turnbull report into the Aboriginal Benefits Trust Account, I accept the offer of the Minister to make it available to me on a confidential basis for the next two weeks and for it then to be made publicly available through the Senate estimates committee, together with the responses from both ATSIC and the Aboriginal Benefits Trust Account. It is terribly important that this degree of accountability flow forward.

There are several other issues that I would briefly comment on that arise from the many questions that were tabled today. As I said, I am basically happy with the answers that have been provided by the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission and I will pursue a number of those issues privately with the commission where further action is needed.

With regard to the answers that have come forward today from the Northern Land Council, it is interesting to note the dates on which they were prepared and the dates on which they were sent. One can always ascertain this, of course, from the dates on the top of the facsimile. I note that the major set of answers, which were forwarded under a letter dated 19 May, was dispatched through a directorate fax of 25 May at 12.34. Subsequently to other representations that I and ATSIC made during the day, further information was provided, again on a facsimile response, dated 25 May at 18.22.

There are a number of issues that still concern me that I will refer specifically to the Auditor-General for his detailed inquiry. A couple that I draw to the Minister's attention relate to the fringe benefits tax arrangements for staff members of both the Northern Land Council and the Central Land Council. The Northern Land Council answers identify that some 18 staff currently enjoy employment packages that attract significant fringe benefits tax exemptions. I notice in an earlier answer through ATSIC that the Central Land Council has a total of 17 staff enjoying these exemptions. That is a matter that I have drawn very specifically to Mr Tickner's attention, and I hope that his response in that area will also now be accelerated for earlier consideration.

One of the principal issues that concerns me in the Northern Land Council's response relates to the personal use of the Northern Land Council as the private bank of the chairman of that commission, Mr Galarrwuy Yunupingu. I asked a number of questions with regard to Mr Yunupingu's personal indebtedness for book-up funds—funds that he had, in effect, put on account at the Northern Land Council. My initial question requested information as to whether or not these personal debts were in the order of $25,000.

I asked that question on 10 May. The answer that was first provided said that the chairman was indebted as at 10 May in respect of advances made by the land council, but that the advance had been repaid and the chairman was no longer indebted to the land council. So between 10 May and today, a fortnight later, obviously he has been given the opportunity to remedy this situation. No account has been offered as to the levels of indebtedness. However, in one of the subsequent questions that has turned up with regard to the second dispatch this afternoon from the Central Land Council—and earlier this morning I sought additional information in this regard—a table of indebtedness was prepared as a supplementary answer for amounts owing as at 25 May 1993 for both financial years 1992-93 and 1991-92.

It is interesting to note that at the end of the 1991-92 year Mr Yunupingu as chairman had an outstanding debt of $4,466, but that does not appear in the answer to the question for the period dated 25 May 1993. What was the level of indebtedness of the chairman? Is this just another rort where the Northern Land Council has been used as a personal bank? At some stage during the year did the sum exceed $25,000? What were the conditions? Was any interest paid? Were any disclosures made to the board or to other appropriate levels? I accept that some of the other people who owe a minor amount are indebted in respect of expenses such as accommodation allowances. That is understandable in the answer, but obviously once again the Northern Land Council has attempted to camouflage the type of answer that it gives.

Similarly, I note a response to a question about whether or not guidelines of the Public Service apply equally to the Northern Land Council's granting of consultancies. The issues that were outstanding from last September, where it took some four or five months to solicit replies, related to over $1.2 million worth of consultancies. The answer that came in this morning was that the council enters into consultancy arrangements in accordance with its powers under section 27 of the Aboriginal Land Rights (Northern Territory) Act 1976 and that Public Service guidelines do not apply to the land council. It said that the very nature of the council dictates that consultants required by the council have to have particular qualifications, experience and background. It also said that before offering any consultancies, all aspects relevant to the consultancy are closely considered and include, as a matter of course, `obvious matters of propriety'. What waffle! What consideration of Sir Humphrey!

It is patently obvious that the Northern Land Council has not set out, as it should have with that answer, the guidelines and the principles that it does adopt; the disclosures that it makes of the consultancy matters, particularly as to the engagement of family of other staff members or of council people themselves directly, to ensure that there are not accusations of nepotism or inappropriate engagement of consultants in this particular area. Very specifically, I hope that this is a matter to which the Auditor-General will give very close attention. I would have thought that the Northern Land Council in the conduct of its business would not have come up with such pious statements as these.

There are, of course, many other issues that I am sure have been revealed in these questions and answers that will interest not only the media who have taken a particular interest in this matter, but the Aboriginal constituency generally across northern Australia. This is a matter of controversy within the Aboriginal community. I am very pleased now to note the Minister's action—even though it has had to be pulled out like a tooth at a dentist's—to change it. But the fact that there is now a major inquiry by the Auditor-General into the operations of the Northern Land Council I think vindicates the action of this Senate when earlier this week it postponed the consideration of these estimates.
The CHAIRMAN—If there are no further matters of discussion in that area, we will move to the Department of Primary Industries and Energy, subprogram 3, which was deferred some time ago.

TALKER.NAME: Senator GARETH EVANS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Foreign Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I draw the committee's attention to the fact that there was an outstanding question raised by Senator O'Chee in relation to AQIS and the importation of second-hand farm machinery. A detailed response has now been communicated to the committee and I believe to Senator O'Chee from the Minister in this respect. I hope that will be a satisfactory conclusion to this matter.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: O'Chee Sen W.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Minister for the promptitude with which the matter has been addressed this afternoon. I wish to clarify the matter a little further because I think it can be quite easily resolved. From the content of the answer given to me, I understand that the arrangements in relation to inspection of imported second-hand farm machinery are handled by the Customs Service with the consent of AQIS. The answer also states that AQIS has no objection to the importer being present when the goods are unpacked. The problem is not with AQIS, it would appear, but with the importer. At the time of the hearing I did draw to the Minister's attention a number of rather strange conditions.

PARA.TAB: Perhaps it will be possible for AQIS to give an undertaking to instruct the contractor that it should not prevent people from being present when goods are unpacked for inspection. That would solve the problem. So that there can be no misunderstanding as to the difficulties that are being experienced, perhaps I might just briefly detain the Senate to read into Hansard just a few portions of a double-page set of standard conditions. These show the severity of the conditions being imposed by the contractors on the importers which would appear to be unknown to AQIS. For example, at clause 6, which is amongst the 21 conditions that are placed on the customer by the contractor under what are called `standard trading conditions of contract', the document reads:

SPEECH.PARA: All goods are stored and/or carried and all services are performed at the sole risk of the customer. Interport shall not be liable either directly or vicariously for any loss whatsoever, howsoever and by whom it may be caused and wherever it arises whether in contract, quasi-contract or for negligence, inadvertence, breach of statutory duty or any other tort or torts or as a carrier bailee or otherwise.
It goes on to say:

Without in any way limiting the generality of the foregoing Interport shall in no way be liable for any loss arising from or contributed to by Acts of God, acts of the Queen's enemies, civil commotion, strikes, lockouts, shortages of labour, burglary, warehouse breaking, larceny, theft, pillage, stealing, fraud, malicious damage . . . fire explosion, water, lightning, tempest, rain, earthquake, exposure, flooding from any source, moth, damp, heat, sweat, mould, mildew, decay, deterioration, vermin, rats, mice, insects, leakage, inherent vice in any goods, deviation in route, mode or place of storage, wear, tear, loss of market, loss of profits, negligent advice, rust, oxidation or any other cause whatsoever. This paragraph shall apply whether the loss is due to the goods being stored and/or carried with those of another person or persons or otherwise.
That is a fairly wide and comprehensive denial of any liability at all. The document contains clauses like the following:

The customer shall be deemed to authorize any deviation from the usual route or manner of carriage of goods which may in the absolute discretion of Interport be deemed reasonable or necessary to the circumstances.
That is notwithstanding the fact that clause 3 states:
Interport is not a common carrier. . .
Clause 15 states:
