Interport does not warrant or admit the accuracy of any of the matters contained in its Receipts for Goods lodged for storage and/or carriage or other documents, or the accuracy of weights, measurements, qualities, quantities, gauges, strengths or values endorsed on the Receipts for Goods lodged for storage and/or carriage or other document.
The best one is clause 21 which states:
Insofar as it is possible to do so, all statutes and by-laws which might impose liability on Interport are hereby excluded.

Again, I find that to be a rather extraordinary clause. I will conclude my comments by seeking some confirmation from the Minister. It does appear that the conditions of contract required by the contractor are extremely onerous. Perhaps the Minister would give an undertaking that AQIS and/or Customs will raise this matter with the contractor and ensure that people are allowed to inspect the goods and, in that way, we can get some progress.

TALKER.NAME: Senator GARETH EVANS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Foreign Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —First of all, I formally table that answer. I understand that is a procedural necessity which I have not complied with. Senator O'Chee has asked that AQIS give an undertaking that it will in effect ensure that no steps are taken to prohibit the presence of the importer.

PARA.TAB: The difficulty that AQIS has in giving that undertaking has nothing to do with the policy issue involved, because, as it has already said, it has no objection whatsoever to the importer's presence. The difficulty is that AQIS is not really in a legal relationship with the freight handling contractor, Interport, such as to make it possible for it to give such a direction. The contractual relationship was between the freight handling company, Interport, and the shipping company. There is a difficulty that AQIS wants to take on notice about how to get over that.

I do not think there is any difficulty about communicating a clear position on the matter at issue and that will certainly be done. There is just a worry about whether or not we can formally undertake to direct it or ensure that it does certain things when AQIS is not in any legal position to do that. I hope Senator O'Chee will appreciate that difficulty and perhaps allow some further course of consultation to take place as to how that result which is agreed might best be achieved.

TALK.START.PARA: —If it is agreeable to the Minister, I am happy to accept that undertaking. The undertakings the Minister has given today have been very reasonably met and I thank him for that. If it is acceptable to the Minister, perhaps further discussions with AQIS and/or the customs service manager in Queensland might ensure that this matter is handled to the satisfaction of all concerned.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOSWELL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —During the estimates committee hearings I raised some fairly serious allegations that were revealed in a review of the SES travel for 1991-92 of the Australian Quarantine and Inspection Service. I tabled a press release by Mr Core. During the debate that took place with Senator Cook, he told me that the Department of Primary Industries and Energy had investigated this review with a section 61 committee report and that that report—I do not have Mr Core's press release in front of me—cleared the officers that were being reviewed in this report. I subsequently asked Senator Cook at Question Time when he would be able to make this section 61 report available to the Senate. His reply then was `early next week'. After that I spoke to Senator Sherry and he told me that the section 61 report would be made available. I see that the Minister has an answer.

TALKER.NAME: Senator GARETH EVANS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Foreign Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Boswell did ask on 19 May that the report of the internal review in question be tabled. That request has been forwarded to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Crean), who has now indicated his preparedness to table the review document. Arrangements are being made to do that on Thursday, the day after tomorrow. That will then be put down with an appropriate accompanying statement.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOSWELL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Minister. Senator Sherry led me to believe that it would be tabled tomorrow. I ask whether that would be possible. Senator Cook told me that it would be early in this week. He is no longer here. He spoke to me privately on that matter. I am wondering whether it could be put down tomorrow.

TALKER.NAME: Senator GARETH EVANS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Foreign Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I cannot give a complete answer on that. I will simply convey that request to the Minister to see whether it can be done tomorrow rather than on Thursday. I do not know what the reason is—nor do the officers—for the hold-up in this matter, if indeed there has been one. We will do what we can to get it down tomorrow. If not, it certainly will be before we get up. That is all I can undertake to do at the moment, I am afraid.

—I have just one question that we did not deal with this morning. During the estimates committee hearing I asked questions about the cost savings that had been introduced through the changes in AQIS, particularly the cost of AQIS's services to its users or producers. We were told that the cost savings had been absorbed by virtue of the fact that the charge has been changed to 100 per cent for the users of the service. I note that, in an answer given by Minister Crean on 13 May to a question in the House of Representatives, it is anticipated over the next year or two there will be an additional $20 million in expenditure savings or even maybe more. Is it anticipated that those cost savings, or a portion of those savings, will be passed on to the industry? May we have some sort of indication of what the Government anticipates the impact will be in cost to inspection services.

TALKER.NAME: Senator GARETH EVANS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Foreign Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I have a paper which goes on for about a page and a half about export inspection charges, giving details of where the power is derived from, what the current charges relate to, the cost recovery targets and so on. Is this what Senator Crane wants? He can have this. I will hand it over to him. I am not sure whether this is responsive to the question he asked.

—My question related to the fact that in the additional estimates it was said that the savings that had been introduced into AQIS had not been able to be passed on to producers because of the 100 per cent charging. The Minister, in answer to a question in the other place on 13 May, anticipated savings of at least $20 million over the next year or so. Is it the intention for that particular portion of the savings to be passed on to the users of the service, or will they be absorbed in some other way?

TALKER.NAME: Senator GARETH EVANS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Foreign Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, it is the intention to pass them on to industry in that way. I will table a supplementary briefing on export inspection charges.

PARA.TAB: Question resolved in the affirmative.
Progress reported.
Motion (by Senator Gareth Evans) proposed:
That the Senate do now adjourn.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am glad that the Minister for Foreign Affairs is present because I wish to speak briefly on a matter which I have raised previously and because on previous occasions when I have raised such matters he has responded very well to them. It relates to freedom of religion in Vietnam, and to an incident that happened there last week. I shall not go over, as I have done previously, the issue of the property of the Buddhists and the matter of freedom of religion.

PARA.TAB: The patriarch was arrested in Vietnam last week. He was attempting at the time to post letters, to both the Prime Minister of Vietnam and the Prime Minister of Australia. Those letters were confiscated. Another monk took a copy of the letter addressed to Mr Keating to another post office in another town and attempted to fax it to Australia so it could, from this country, be posted to our Prime Minister.

When he went to the post office he was told that the fax machine was temporarily out of order. While he was waiting for the letter to be faxed, he was arrested at the post office. That very briefly tells the story of what occurred.

On previous occasions when I have raised these matters the Minister for Foreign Affairs has taken the issues up with the Australian embassy in Hanoi and I would ask that these matters, and the question generally of freedom of religion in Vietnam and the property of the Buddhists, be taken up with the Prime Minister of Vietnam when he visits in a few days time, both by the Minister for Foreign Affairs and the Prime Minister.

At this hour of the night, I shall not go into detail. The Minister for Foreign Affairs knows of the issues about which I am speaking. At this hour, it would be appropriate for me to leave it at that, but I ask that these significant matters be placed on the agenda and discussed and, in particular, that the Minister try to ascertain what has happened in Hanoi to the patriarch and the monk to whom I have specifically referred this evening.

The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Teague)—Senator Spindler, as Senator Evans was the Minister who moved the adjournment motion and, by speaking, he has closed the debate, you would need to seek leave to speak at this time.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—Tonight I wish to address the final report of the Democrats' Independent Parliamentary Inquiry into Tariffs and Industry Development. To produce this report, the inquiry took evidence from 129 witnesses in capital cities across Australia and in Victoria's regional centres and received 127 written submissions. I intended to ask for leave to formally table this report in the Senate. However, I have been informed that although the Government is prepared to grant leave, the Opposition will refuse to do so on the ground that I have used the term `parliamentary' in front of the word `inquiry'. It seems rather churlish and, in many ways, it continues the position that the Opposition adopted when it voted against my original motion to have a tariff inquiry established by the Senate. In other words, it simply did not want to know the facts. It still does not want to know the facts.

PARA.TAB: I received advice from the Clerk of the Senate that it was `well within the scope of your duties as a member of the Senate to conduct such an inquiry'. I believe that that entitles me to use the adjective `parliamentary', because I am conducting that inquiry as a parliamentarian. To use that technical subterfuge to now refuse me the option of formally tabling the report in the Senate is a reprehensible action for which the Opposition will be judged. As it is, I will be making the report available to all members of the Senate as well as to members of the House of Representatives.

I turn to some of the substance of the report. It is the result of an eight-month inquiry into the effects of current tariff and industry development policies and the action needed to increase Australia's industrial capacity to provide employment for its workers and to achieve a reduction in its foreign debt. The inquiry was initiated, as I have said before, as an independent parliamentary inquiry when both the Labor Government and the Liberal Opposition refused to support a Senate inquiry. The urgent need to find out what was going on in the real world was underlined—even then—by the mounting anecdotal evidence that the speed, timing and extent of tariff cuts was decimating Australian industries and that the policy had been largely replaced by reliance on free market forces on a mythical level playing field.

I repeat that the Clerk of the Senate confirmed that an individual senator could initiate and run an independent parliamentary inquiry. I am grateful for the support from industry associations, unions and individual enterprises which enabled me to fund additional staff and other costs not covered by parliamentary entitlements.

The evidence from a wide cross-section of industry associations, unions, individual enterprises, community organisations and research analysts established a direct and substantial link between tariff cuts and the abolition of quotas and the steep increase of imports and consequent job losses. The continuing tragic trend was confirmed a fortnight ago with the worst trade deficit in three years and a further 100,000 Australians giving up hope of even finding a job.

It is difficult to find a basis for this macho `smashing of tariff walls'—a quote from the Prime Minister (Mr Keating)—which makes no sense in economic or human terms. Certainly there is general agreement that we should neither maintain nor return to the uniformly high protection of the 1950s or 1960s and that we must develop industries able to compete on international markets. What is at issue is the timing, speed and extent of cuts in the protection and the stubborn refusal to modify them on a selective basis.

The disastrous social and economic consequences are clear: record unemployment and a record foreign debt for this and future generations. Yet there is little, if any, causal connection between the demolition of Australia's existing manufacturing industries and primary producers and the desirable development of an export culture.

Evidence before the inquiry shows that the largely semi-skilled workers retrenched from the textile, clothing and footwear industry and from the manufacturers clustered around the car industry are not being retrained for the industries of the future. In turn, factory owners do not establish high-tech new industries; they go bankrupt, relocate offshore or become importers.

The development of export industries depends on innovation and product quality, available venture capital, export incentives and high levels of education, research and management to supply the yeast for this export culture.

For existing industries and primary producers the central question is whether consumers are prepared to keep paying prices which enable industries to continue or to phase out at a speed which minimises social costs. Alternatively, they could buy cheaper imports but ultimately pay higher taxes to fund unemployment and other social benefits and to cover lost tax revenue and watch the sale of Australian public and private assets and the continuing loss of economic sovereignty to finance the mounting foreign debt.

It is likely that Australians would have enough of both moral backbone and commonsense to choose moderate, strategically selective and slowly reducing protection over the current scorched earth policy. Unfortunately, Australians will not be given that chance until the community and ultimately the Government recognise the continuing damage done by current policies.

The most frustrating aspect of the Government's intransigence is that Australia has gone much further than other countries to facilitate imports. Thus, we are now the only country with significant TCF and car industries to have abolished all quota restraints. Nor do we use the wide range of non-tariff measures employed by other countries, for instance, by the European Community which applies so-called NTMs to 243 Australian export items.

Finally, Australia does not use the emergency measures available under GATT's article 12—in the case of balance of payments difficulties—or article 19 when specific industries are under threat from a surge in imports. Many products now carry tariffs below GATT's `binding' requirements and thus could be increased by a stroke of a pen when the need arises as, for instance, in the current example of orange juice which is landed here from Brazil at a third of our production cost and where the United States protects its growers to the tune of 40 per cent against ours at 15 per cent.

As if all this were not enough, we disadvantage Australian producers, manufacturers and workers by poor labelling and inspection provisions which allow inferior products to be sold as Australian product and use anti-dumping procedures which appear to protect importers rather than Australian producers. The Prime Minister would not have had to establish a task force to find solutions to the problem of long-term unemployment had he accepted the key recommendations of the Australian Democrats' tariff inquiry some 12 months ago. The main inquiry recommendations are a 12-month pause in tariff cuts and a selective use of protection and other interventionist measures to stem imports and boost exports on an industry by industry basis.

If he had pursued these policies during the last 12 months, or even during the eight months of the inquiry, some 200,000 jobless Australians would still be in work. Even if he were to institute these measures now, Australia would be able to avert the gloomy future of rising unemployment, which, paradoxically, will get worse as the economy improves, as the April balance of trade and import figures have shown.

The Garnaut proposal to free up trade with China would make it easier to sell Australian wool. That is desirable, but it is the death knell for Australian textile manufacturers and the end of jobs for at least another 50,000 workers. The question must be asked: why should the protection excess of the 1950s and 1960s produce total paralysis in trade and industry policy when confronted with a selective and targeted use of tariffs and quotas as and when the need arises in particular industries which other countries are pursuing?

It is not surprising that there was one bewildering question that neither the inquiry nor the witnesses before it could answer: why does the Australian Government pursue policies which destroy Australian jobs, devastate Australian industries and increase our foreign debt while other countries are busily tilting the playing field to protect their workers and their industries?

In conclusion, I wish to record my sincere thanks to inquiry secretary and research consultant, Ms Lesley Vick, who made the wheels turn; Mr Ernest Rodeck, the National President of the Institute of Management, who provided valuable guidance as executive secretary; Mr Brian Harrison, the honorary accountant of the inquiry; my staff members, Beverley Irving and Stephen Merrylees, who cheerfully accepted the inevitable additional workload; and all the witnesses and contributors who provided the content for this urgent message to Australia's policy makers.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reid Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—At the beginning of his speech, Senator Spindler referred to the fact that he had sought to table this document entitled Independent parliamentary inquiry into tariffs and industry development and then attacked us for indicating that we would not agree to the tabling of it. I believe that that is the correct thing to do. I make no comment about the document's contents. I have not had the opportunity to read it in detail, and I do not wish to discuss it. I make no comment whatever and totally accept Senator Spindler's sincerity in pursuing this matter as something he regards as important.

PARA.TAB: The face of the document has a cartoon and the date April 1993. It is headed Independent parliamentary inquiry into tariffs and industry development. I put it to the Senate that it should be headed, `Australian Democrats' independent inquiry into tariffs and industry development'. That would make it a document that set out what it is. On the face of it, the document implies that it is something other than that which we believe it to be. The fourth paragraph of the tabling statement commences:

SPEECH.PARA: In the event the Clerk of the Senate confirmed that an individual Senator could initiate and run an independent Parliamentary Inquiry.

I do not challenge that an individual senator can initiate and run an inquiry, but I do challenge that it is entitled to be called a parliamentary inquiry, especially when the proposition had been put to and rejected by the Senate. Senator Spindler refers to that in another part of the document. Paragraph 1.3 reads:

Following the rejection of his proposed Senate Select Committee on Tariffs, Senator Spindler obtained advice from the Clerk of the Senate that it would be "well within the scope of your duties as a member of the Senate" for Senator Spindler to use his parliamentary facilities to conduct an inquiry into tariffs.

I have no doubt that the Clerk of the Senate gave that advice. Any of us would be able to conduct an inquiry that we saw as appropriate to our duties. That much, I think, sets out the facts. The paragraph goes on to say:
Acting on this advice, Senator Spindler announced his intention of conducting an independent parliamentary inquiry into the issue.

I challenge the use of the word `parliamentary' in that sentence. I believe it is totally outside the advice of the Clerk, totally outside the scope of this inquiry and an inappropriate use of the word. That has been referred to by Senator Kemp previously. I make those brief comments to explain why we feel it is inappropriate for this report to be tabled bearing the title that it bears.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Spindler Sen S.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I note the comments made by Senator Reid. I put the view to honourable senators that a document of this nature needs to be looked at in its entirety. The origin of the document, the nature of the document, the procedures and the way in which it was handled is described in detail. It is quite clear that the inquiry was conducted by parliamentarians and that it was conducted, in part, within the precincts of this Parliament.

PARA.TAB: Since I have tried not to hide anything about the nature of the inquiry or its origin,

SPEECH.PARA: I believe the term `parliamentary' is simply descriptive and that the document as a whole speaks for itself. I must say, I regret that this decision was taken on a technicality by the coalition parties.

PARA.TAB: Question resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Industrial Relations, upon notice, on 31 March 1993:

PARA.TAB: (1) Does the department routinely disseminate or circulate all or some of the media releases of its responsible Minister or Ministers, to organisations apart from national media organisations; if so, for what reasons are Ministerial media releases circulated by the department, and to how many individuals or organisations.

(2) For each, and which, Ministerial media release circulated in the past 18 months, what was the estimated cost of printing and circulating the releases, and how many copies of the release were circulated.

(3) Does the department circulate copies of some or all of the speeches made by the Minister; if so, for each of those circulated in the past 18 months, what was the estimated cost of printing and circulating the speech and how many copies of the speech were circulated.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Industrial Relations has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) No. Media releases are available on request.
(2) The small number of media releases distributed on request does not justify keeping comprehensive records.
(3) Ministerial speeches are distributed on request. The small number of ministerial speeches distributed in this way does not justify keeping comprehensive records.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: McMullan Sen The Hon R.F.

PARA.TAB: (1) In addition to the entitlement of each Senator and Member to electorate staff positions:
(2) The salary ranges of positions available to the Leader of the Australian Democrats and Independent Senators and Member are attached.
